mamaAdiHu Praiseworthy, commendable, or good, qualities or dispositions, &c.; contr of maqaAbiHu. (L, art. qbH.)
OumoduwHapN: see midoHapN.
mumad-aHN A man much, or greatly praised; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also mumotadaHN↓: (TA:) praised by every tongue. (A.)
mumotadaHN: see mumad-aHN.

1. madarahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoduru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. madorN, (Mṣb, TA,) He plastered it (a place) with [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud; as also md-rhu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tamodiyrN. (TA.) He repaired it (namely a watering-trough or tank) with madar; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. e., clay, or loam, or mud: (Mṣb:) he closed the interstices of its stones with madar: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he plastered its surface with clay, or loam, or mud, in which was no sand, in order that it might not cleave open, or in order that its water might not issue forth. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.

md-r, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tamodiyrN, (Ḳ,) ‡ Alvum dejecit: because he who does so makes use of madar [for purification]; and the excrement is metonymically termed clay: (A:) cacavit: (Ḳ:) mostly said of the hyena. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. OamodiruwnaA mino mamodaratikumo [Give ye to us some madar from your place whence ye take madar]. (A.)
8. Amtdr Almadara He took what is called madar. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: madarN [a coll. gen. n.] Pieces, or bits, [or lumps, or clods,] of dry, or tough, clay, (M, A, Ḳ,) such as is cohesive: (TA:) or [simply] pieces of clay: (Az, Mṣb:) or compact or cohesive earth: (Mṣb:) or tough or cohesive clay in which is no sand: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {madarapN}. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) In the expression AlHijaArapu waAlmidaArapu↓ [Stones and pieces of dry or tough clay,, &c.], the latter word is used after the manner of an imitative sequent, and is not used alone, as a broken pl.: (M:) or it is an imitative sequent. (Ḳ.)

‡ Cities [or towns or villages]: or a region, district, or tract, of cities or towns or villages, and of cultivated land; (Ḳ, TA;) because its buildings are [generally] of madar: (TA:) and its n. un., madarapN↓, ‡ a city or town or village; syn. balodapN, (Ḳ,) or qaroyapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because its buildings are generally of madar: (Mṣb:) or a town or village built of clay or mud and unburnt bricks: and also a large city. (L.)
You say, Oaholu Almadari waAlwabari ‡ [The people of the towns or villages, and of the tents]. (Ṣ.) And maA raOayotu fiI Alwabari waAlmadari mivolahu ‡ I have not seen in the desert and the towns or villages the like of him. (A.) And it is related in a trad., that the Prophet said to 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl, Become thou a muslim, and he replied, EalaI Oan-a liIa Alwabara walaka Almadara ‡ [On the condition that to me shall pertain the desert, and to thee the towns or villages]. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN say-idu madaratihi ‡ Such a one is the chief of his town or village. (Mṣb.) And banuw madoraMCa↓ ‡ The people of the cities or towns or villages and cultivated land. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: madarapN: see madarN.
banuw madoraMCa: see madarN.
madiyrN and mamoduwrN↓ A place plastered with [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud. (TA.)
midaArapN: see madarN.
maAdirN [One who plasters with madar:] one who plasters his watering-trough or tank with his ordure, in order that no one beside himself may water at it: pl. madarapN. (A.)
DiboEaAnN OamodarN: see DabuEN.
mimodarN An instrument with which one plasters with [madara, or] clay, or loam, or mud. (TA, art. sbH.)

mamodarapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mimodarapN, (Ḳ,) which latter is extr. [with respect to form], (TA,) or mamodurapN, like maqoburapN, (A,) A place in which is [madar, or] clay, or loam, or mud, unmixed with sand, (Ḳ,) prepared for closing the interstices of the stones of watering-troughs or tanks; (TA;) a place from which madar is taken for that purpose. (Ṣ.) See 4.
mamoduwrN: see madiyrN.
muco and mco: see art. mnc.

1. maciHa, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yamocaHu}, (L,) inf. n. macaHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) His (a man's, Ṣ) thighs rubbed each other: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) when he walked, (Ṣ,) by reason of his fatness: (Námoos:) or his thighs rubbed each other, and twisted, so that they became excoriated; as also mac-aHato↓ faxicaAhu: (L:) or the parts between the inner sides of the roots of his thighs (maA bayona Alr-ufogayoni) and his buttocks became inflamed: (Ḳ, TA:) [for AxtrAq, in the CK, I read AHtrAq, as in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA: see also waciHa.].
maciHa is said to signify It (a thing) rubbed against another thing, and became much cracked, or chapped, thereby. ISd thinks that it relates especially to an animal. (L.)
Also, maciHa He had his testicle much chapped by its rubbing against something. (Ḳ.)
maciHati AlD-aOonu, inf. n. macaHN, The sheep sweated in the inner sides of the roots of the thighs, or the parts called OarofaAg: (L:) or, in their thighs. (TA.)
2: see 1.
5. tamac-aHato xaASirataAhu His two hypochrondres, or flanks, became inflated, or swollen, by reason of his having satiated himself with drink. (Ḳ.) [See also tamad-aHa and tanad-aHa.]
OamocaHu A man whose thighs rub each other when he walks. (Ṣ.) [See 1.]

1. macirati AlbayoDapu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamocaru}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. macarN, (TA,) The egg became corrupt, or rotten. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And macirati Aljawozapu The nut became bad, or corrupt; as also tmc-rt↓. (Ḳ.)

macirato maEidatuhu His stomach became in a corrupt state: (Ṣ:) and macirato nafosuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and maEidanuhu, (Ḳ,) his soul [or stomach] became heavy; or it heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. xabuvato; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tmc-rt↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, raOayotu bayoDapF mcirapF famacirato licelika nafosiI I saw a rotten egg, and my soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit, thereat; syn. xabuvato. (Ṣ.)
4. Amcrt AlbayoDapa She (a hen) caused the egg to become corrupt, or rotten. (Ṣ, A.)
5: see 1, in two places.
Xacara macara and Xicara micara: see art. Xcr. The latter word is an imitative sequent to the former. (TA.)
bayoDapN macirapN A corrupt, or rotten, egg. (A, Ḳ.)
UimoraOapN macirapN A dirty, or filthy, woman, (Ḳ, TA,) whose odour is like that of a rotten egg. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. mar-a, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoruru}, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. mar-N [and mamar-N] and muruwrN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He, or it, passed; passed by, or beyond; went; went on; proceeded; passed, or went, along, or through, or over; went away; passed away; syn. jaAza; (M, Ḳ;) and cahaba; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and maDaI; (A, Mgh;) as also Astmr-↓. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, mar-a Alr-ajulu, (TḲ,) and Ald-ahoru, (Mṣb,) and AlOamoru; and Astmr-↓; (A, Mgh;) The man, (TḲ,) and time, (Mṣb,) and the affair, (A, Mgh,) passed;, &c. (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TḲ.) The saying in the Ḳur, [vii. 189,] Hamalato HamolFA xafiyfFA famar-ato bihi signifies i. q. Astmr-t↓ bh, (A, Ḳ,) which is another reading, (Bḍ,) i. e., [She bore a light burden in her womb, and] went with it, and moved from place to place, and rose and sat, not being oppressed by its weight: (A:) [or went on with it in the same course or manner:] or went and came with it, by reason of its lightness: (Jel:) or rose and sat with it, (Zj, Bḍ,) not being oppressed by its weight: (Zj:) so accord. to both the readings mentioned above: (Bḍ:) by the burden being meant the impregnating fluid. (Bḍ, Jel, TA.)
[It is also said of water, meaning It ran, or flowed. And one says, mar-ati Alr-iyHu The wind passed along, or blew.]

mar-a bihi, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and mar-a Ealayohi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) but the former is more common than the latter, (Mughnee, voce bi,) for which the BenooYarbooa say, mir-a Elyh, with kesr, (TA,) and mar-ahu, [respecting which see what follows the explanation,] (M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yamoruru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. mar-N and mamar-N (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and muruwrN; (A, Mṣb;) and Aimotar-a↓ bihi, and Aimotar-a Ealayohi; (M, Ḳ;) He passed, or went, by him, or it; syn. AijotaAza, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or jaAza Ealayohi, (M, Ḳ,) or jaAwazahu wacahaba. (A.) mar-a may be a verb trans. by means of a particle and without a particle: or in mar-ahu the particle may be suppressed: Jereer says,
tamur-uwna Ald-iyaAra walamo taEuwjuwA
kalaAmukumu EalaI-a UicFA HaraAmu
[Ye pass by the dwellings without turning aside and alighting: the speaking to you is therefore forbidden to me]: but it is said that the true reading is mararotumo biAld-iyaAri [Ye have passed by the dwellings]: which shows that he feared to make the verb trans. without a particle: IAạr says, that mar-a zayodFA signifies the same as mar-a bihi [He passed by Zeyd], without being elliptical, but as being properly trans.; but IJ, allowing this, says that it is not a phrase commonly obtaining. (M, TA.)

[mar-a Ealayohi also signifies He, or it, passed, or went, along, or over, or across, it. You say, mar-a EalaI Aljisori He passed, or went, along, or over the bridge, or dyke.]
And mar-a Als-ik-iynu EalaI Haloqi AlX-aApi The knife passed across the throat of the sheep, or goat. (Mṣb.)
[Also, It (a period of time) passed over him, or it: and it (a calamity) came upon him: see an ex. of the latter signification below, voce mur-N.]
mar-a bihi as syn. with Oamar-ahu↓, trans. of mar-a: see 4.
mar-a, aor. _a {yamoraru} and _u: see 4.
mar-ahu, as trans. of mar-a, of which the aor. is _a: see 2.

mur-a His bile, or gall, became roused. (A.) You say murirotu [I suffered an attack of bile], from Almir-apu, (T,) or murirotu bihi, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) aor. Oumar-u, inf. n. mar-N and mir-apN, (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ,) the latter of which [in the CK written mar-ap, but in the T, M, &c. mir-ap, and expressly said in the TA to be with kesr,] is also a simple subst., (T,) or, as Lḥ says in one place, mir-N is the inf. n. and mir-apN is a simple subst., (M, TA,) Bile, or gall, overcame me [by reason of it: app. referring to food]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. mr-rhu, (inf. n. tamoriyrN, TA,) He, or it, made it bitter; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Amr-hu↓: (IAạr, Ṣ:) or mar-ahu↓, aor. _u {yamoruru}, has this signification, and the first verb has an intensive signification [he, or it, made it very bitter]. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 3. mAr-hu, (inf. n. mumaAr-apN and miraArN, TA,) He passed, passed by or beyond, went, went away, or passed away, (mar-a,) with him. (Ḳ.)
See also 4, in five places.
4. Amr-hu, (inf. n. UimoraArN, TA,) He made him, or it, to pass, pass by or beyond, go, go away, or pass away; (A, Mṣb, TA;) as also mar-a↓ bihi. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] Amr- AlX-iEora [† He recited the poetry, especially, with fluency]. (Ḳ, art. cbr.)
Amr-hu bihi (in some copies of the Ḳ, Amtr- bh, but the former is the right reading, TA) [and Ealayohi] He made him, or it, to pass, or go, by him, or it, (Ḳ.)

Amr-hu EalaI Aljisori He made him to pass, or go, along, or over, the bridge, or dyke. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) Amr- Ealayohi yadahu [He passed his hand over him, or it]. And Amr- Elyh Alqalama [He passed the pen over it, or across it]. (A.) Oamorarotu Als-ik-iyna EalaI Haloqi AlX-aApi I passed the knife across the throat of the sheep, or goat. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., respecting the sound that is heard by the angels when a revelation is sent down, kaUimoraAri AlHadiydi EalaI AlT-aXoti, meaning, Like the dragging, or drawing, (in a trans. sense,) of the iron over the copper basin: and in another trad., Sawota UimoraAri Als-ilosilapi [the sound of the dragging, or drawing, of the chain]: or, accord. to the more common relation, Sawota miraAri Als-ilosilapi EalaI AlS-afaA, meaning, the sound of the dragging, (in an intrans. sense) and continuous running, of the chain upon the [smooth] rocks: (IAth, TA:) for maAr-a↓, inf. n. miraArN, signifies it (a thing) dragged, or became drawn along. (Ḳ, TA.)
Amr-hu He twisted it tightly; namely, a rope, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and a thread. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] Ald-ahoru cuw naqoDK waUimoraArK ‡ [Time, or fortune, as it were, untwists and twists tightly]. (A. TA.) [See art. nqD.]

Hence also, Amr-hu ‡ He struggled, or strove, with him, (Ṣ, A,) and twisted about him, (Ṣ,) or twisted his neck, (A,) to throw him down; (Ṣ, A;) as also mAr-hu↓: (Ṣ:) or this latter signifies he twisted himself about him, and turned him round, to throw him down; (Ḳ,) [for yudiyruhu, in the Ḳ, we find in the L yuriyduhu, which latter is preferred by SM; but I prefer the former; for it also signifies] he turned him round, (namely, a camel,) in order to throw him down: (M:) or mAr-hN↓ signifies he struggled, or strove, with him, and twisted his neck, (A,) to throw him down, (AHeyth, T, A,) (AHeyth, T, A,) the latter desiring to do the same; and the inf. n. is mumaAr-apN and miraArN: (AHeyth, T:) and UimoraOatuhu tumaAr-uhu↓ his wife opposes him, and twists herself about him: (A, TA:) and miraAru↓ AlHrobi is explained by Aṣ as signifying the striving to obtain the victory in war. (M.)

Amr-, (inf. n. UimoraArN, A,) It was, or became, bitter; (Ks, Th, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also mar-a↓, (Th, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but this was not known by Ks, and Th says that the former is the more common, (M,) aor. _a {yamoraru} (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u, (Th, M, Ḳ,) [whence it seems that the see. pers. of the pret. is both marirota and marurota,] inf. n. maraArapN, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst.: (Mṣb;) and Astmr-↓ (A, Ṣgh, TA.) You say, qado Oamar-a hacaA AlT-aEaAmu fiI famiI This food has become bitter in my mouth: and in like manner you say of anything that becomes bitter. (TA.) You say also, Oamar-a Ealayohi AlEayoXu, and mar-a↓ Ealayohi, ‡ [Life became bitter to him]. (A.) And Th cites,
tumir-u EalayonaA AlOaroDu mino Oano naraI bihaA
OaniysFA wayaHolawoliI lanaA Albaladu Alqaforu
[‡ The land is displeasing to us from our seeing in it man, and the desolate country is pleasing to us]: the poet makes tumir-u trans. by means of ElI, because it implies the meaning of taDiyqu [which is made trans. by means of the same particle]. (M, TA) You say also, Oamar-u waOaHoluw, and Oamur-u waOaHoluw, meaning ‡ I am bitter at one time, and I am sweet at one time. (IAạr, M.) [See also 1 in art. Hlw.]

But maA Oamar-a wamaA OaHolaI signifies ‡ He said not. (IAạr, Ṣ, M,) and he did not, (IAạr, M,) a bitter thing, and he said not, (IAạr, Ṣ, M,) and he did not, (IAạr, M,) a sweet thing. (IAạr, Ṣ, M.) You say, XatamaniI fulaAnN famaA Oamorarotu walaA OaHolayotu ‡ Such a one reviled me, and I did not say a bitter thing, nor did I say a sweet thing. (Lḥ, T.) And fulaAnN maA yumir-u wamaA yuHoliI ‡ Such a one does not injure nor does he profit. (M, Ḳ.*)
Amr-hu as syn. with mar-arahu: see 2.

entry.sense: 6. tamaAr-aA They two struggled, or strove, each with the other, and each twisted the other's neck, to throw him down. (A, TA.)
8. Amtr- bihi, and Ealayohi: see mar-a bihi.

hom.sense: 10. Astmr-: see 1, first signification, in three places.

Also. It (a thing, M) went on in one [uniform] course or manner: (M, Ḳ:) it (an affair, A, or anything, Mgh) had a continuous course, or manner of being, &c.; (A, Mgh;) it continued in the same state; (Mgh:) it (a thing) continued, or obtained: (Mṣb:) it (said of blood) continued in a regular, uniform, or constant, course. (Mgh.) [And it is often said of a man.]
[It also seems to signify It (a rope) became tightly twisted.]

[And hence, † He, or it, became strong, or firm, like a rope tightly twisted: as in the following phrases.] Astmr- biAlX-aIoCi † He became strong to bear the thing. (M, Ḳ. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce OaSomaEu.]) Astmr- mariyruhu ‡ He became firm; as also Astmr-t mariyratuhu: (A:) or his resolution, or determination, became firm, or strong; (Ṣ:) or he became strong, after being weak: and Astmr-t mariyratuhu his resistance (Xakiymap) became firm. (TA.) You say also, Astmr-t mariyratuhu Ealayohi ‡ He became firm against him, or it: and his resistance (Xakiymap) against him, or it, became strong: (Ḳ, TA:) and he became accustomed, or habituated, [or inured,] to him, or it: a tropical signification, from the twisting of a rope. (TA.)

[And hence, app.,] Astmr- also signifies † His case, or state of affairs, became right, after having been bad or corrupt: (ISh, T, TA) he repented, and became good, righteous, or virtuous. (A [but not given as tropical].)
As syn. with Oamar-a and mar-a, said of food, &c.: see 4.
He made water to pass, or go, upon the surface of the ground. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. tamaromara: see 1.

It (the body of a woman, TA) shook; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) quivered; quaked: (Ḳ:) or became in a state of commotion: (Ṣgh:) or became smooth like [the kind of marble called] maromar. (IḲṭṭ.) It (sand) moved from side to side, or to and fro. (A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mar-N: see mar-apN.

mur-N Bitter; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) contr. of HulowN; (Ḳ;) as also mariyrN↓ and mumir-N↓: (A:) fem. mur-apN: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. masc. OamoraArN, (T, Ṣ, M,) and pl. fem. maraAYiru, contr. to rule, (Mṣb,) because mur-apN means xabiyvapu AlT-aEomi [bad-tasted; and the pl. of xbyvp is xabaAYivu]. (Mṣb, voce Hur-N.) You say baqolapN mur-apN [A bitter leguminous plant]: and hacihi Albaqolapu mino OamoraAri Albuqowli [This leguminous plant is one of the bitter leguminous plants]. (T.) And XajarapN mur-apN [A bitter tree]: pl. XajarN maraAYiru: the only instance of the kind except HaraAYiru as pl. of Hur-apN. (Suh, in Mṣb, art. Hr.)

[Hence the saying,] riEoIu bnI fulaAnK Almur-ataAni, (so in two copies of the Ṣ,) or Almur-ayaAni↓, (as in the Ḳ,) The pasturage of the sons of such a one is the [bitter tree called] OalMC and the [bitter plant called] XiyH. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [For another application of Almur-ataAni, see Oamar-a.]

Hence also, (TA,) Almur-u [Myrrh;] a certain medicine, (Ḳ,) like AlS-abir [or aloes], (TA,) useful for cough, (Ḳ,) when sucked (UisotiHolaAbFA) in the mouth, (TA,) and for the sting of the scorpion, (Ḳ,) when applied as a plaster, (TA,) and for worms of the intestines, (Ḳ,) when taken into the mouth in a dry state, or licked up from the palm of the hand: (TA:) also said to be the same as AlS-abiru: (TA:) pl. OamoraArN. (Ḳ.)
EyX mur-N ‡ [A bitter life]: like as one says [of the contr.], HulowN. (TA.)
mar-ato Ealayohi OamozaArN ‡ Afflictions or calamities [came upon him]. (TA.)
nafosN mur-N ‡ A loathing mind, or stomach; syn. xabiyvapN kaArihapN. (TA.)
Oabuw mur-apa A surname of Iblees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said to be from a daughter of his named mur-apu [Bitter]. (TA.)

mar-apN A time; one time; [in the sense of the French fois;] syn. taArapN: (Mṣb:) one action; a single action or act; (M, Ḳ;) as also mar-N↓: (M, Ḳ: [but see what follows:]) [a bout; an instance; a case; and a single temporary offection or attack; a fit; as, for instance, of hunger, thirst, disease, and the like:] pl. mar-aAtN (A, Mṣb) and miraArN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mirarN and mar-N↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which mar-apN is the n. un.] and muruwrN; (M, Ḳ;) the last on the authority of Aboo-ʼAlee, and occurring in the following verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb:
tanak-arota baEodiI Oamo OaSaAbaka HaAdivN
mino Ald-ahori Oamo mar-ato Ealayoka muruwru
[Hast thou become altered since I saw thee, or hath an accident of fortune befallen thee, or have vicissitudes come upon thee?] but Es-Sukkaree holds that mrwr is an inf. n.; and IJ says, I do not think this improbable, and that the verb is made fem. because the inf. n. implies muchness and genus. (M.) You say faEalotuhu mar-apF [I did it once], (A, Mṣb,) and mar-aAtK and miraArFA [several times]. (A.) [And biQlomar-api At once.] And laqiyahu caAta mar-apK [He met him once]: only used adverbially: (M, Ḳ:) so says Sb. (M.) And laqiyahu caAta AlmiraAri He met him many times: (M, Ḳ:) [or this has a different signification; for] you say fulaAnN yaSonaEu celika AlOamora caAta AlmiraAri meaning Such a one does that thing sometimes, and sometimes he leaves it undone. (ISk, Ṣ.) Also, jiYotuhu mar-FA Oawo mar-ayoni, i. e., mar-apF Oawo mar-atayoni [I came to him once or twice]. (M, Ḳ.)
mur-apN: see mur-N.

hom.sense:
mir-apN a subst. from mar-a, and mar-a bihi and Ealayohi, and Oamar-ahu EalaI Aljisori, [The act of passing, passing by or beyond, going, going away, passing away,, &c.] El-Aạshà says,
OalaA qulo litay-aA qabola mir-atihaA QsolamiI
[Now say to this damsel, or this little female, (see taA,) before her passing, Be thou safe]. (M.)
A firm, or strong, twisting. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) ‡ Strength: (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) strength of make: (Ḳ:) pl. mirarN (ISk, Ḳ) and OamoraArN. (Ḳ.) In the Ḳur, [liii. 6,] cuw mir-apK is applied to † [The angel] Jibreel [or Gabriel]: (Fr, Ḳ,* TA:) whom God hath created endowed with great strength. (TA.) You say also rajulN cuw mir-apK ‡ A strong man. (A.) And it is said in a trad., laA taHil-u AlS-adaqapu liEiniI-K walaA liciI mir-apK sawiI-K ‡ The giving of alms to one who possesses competence, or riches, is not allowable, nor to him who has strength and is sound in limbs. (TA.)

[Hence also,] ‡ Intellect: (Ḳ:) or strength of intellect: (Ṣ:) and sound judgment: and firmness; syn. UiHokaAmN, (Ḳ,) and mataAnapN. (TḲ.) You say Uin-ahu lacuw mir-apK ‡ Verily he is possessed of intellect and sound judgment and firmness. (TA.)
Also, A strand, or single twist, of a rope; and so mariyrapN↓: (L,* TA:) pl. mirarN. (TA.)

Almir-apu [The gall, bile, or choler;] one of the humours of the body; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) which are four; (Ṣ, TA;) what is in the maraArap: (Ṣ:) or [rather] Almir-ataAni denotes two of the four humours of the body; [namely, the yellow bile (AlS-aforaMCu) and the black bile (Als-awodaMCu);] the other two humours being the blood (Ald-amu) and the phlegm (Albalogamu): (TA, art. mzj:) pl. miraArN. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: muraArN [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of tree; (Mṣb;) a kind of bitter tree; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or a kind of sour tree; (TA;) of the best and largest of herbs; (Ḳ;) when camels eat of it, their lips become contracted, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and their teeth appear: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {muraArapN}. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: mariyrN A rope that is slender (Ṣ, Ḳ) and long and strongly twisted: pl. maraAYiru: (ISk, Ṣ:) or that is twisted of more than one strand; as also p↓: pl. of both as above: (TA:) or mariyrapN↓ signifies a strongly twisted rope: or a long and slender rope: (Ḳ:) and a strand, or single twist, of a rope; as also mir-apN↓. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See an ex. voce saHala.] See also mumar-N.
[Hence,] rajulN mariyrN † A strong man. (Ṣ.)
[Hence also,] mariyrN and mariyrapN↓ † Resolution, or determination: (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and ↓the latter, strength (Eiz-ap) of mind. (Ḳ.) See also 10.
See also mur-N.
maraArapN (a subst., Mṣb) Bitterness. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Hence, maraArapu Aln-afos ‡ A loathing (xubovN wakaraAhapN) of the mind or stomach. (TA.)

[The gall-bladder;] that in which is the mir-ap; (Ṣ;) a certain thing adhering to the liver, (Ḳ,) and serving to render the food wholesome, or quickly digestible; (TA;) pertaining to every animal except the camel (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and the ostrich (Ḳ) [and some few others, as is well known:] pl. maraAYiru. (Mṣb.) [The camel is really destitute of a gall-bladder, as are several other animals; but] one says of the camel laA maraArapa lahu meaning ‡ He has no daring. (Ṣ, O voce TaHaAlN, q. v.)

entry.sense: mariyrapN: see mariyrN.

mur-iI-N A certain kind of seasoning, or condiment, eaten with food to render it pleasant or savoury; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like kaAmax; (Ḳ;) or also called kAmx; (Mṣb;) pronounced by the vulgar without teshdeed. (Ṣ.)

mur-aAnN A certain kind of tall tree [or plant of the cane-kind]; (Ḳ;) a certain kind of tree [or cane] of which spears are made: (Ṣ:) and spears made of canes; (Ḳ;) made of this kind of tree [or cane]: (TA:) but the word belongs to art. mrn, (Ṣ, L,) being of the measure fuE-aAlN. (L.)

hom.sense: maromarN [Marble: or alabaster: in the present day, more commonly the latter:] i. q. ruxaAmN: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) i. e., a kind of soft white stone: (Mgh:) or a hard kind of rxAm: (TA:) or a kind of rxAm, but harder and clearer [than what is commonly so called]. (Mṣb.)
See also maromaArN.

entry.sense:
maromaArN and muromuwrN↓ [in the L, TA written maromuwrN, which is app. a mistake, as SaEofuwqN is said to be the only Arabic word of good authority that is of this measure, and the fem. is expressly said in the Ḳ to be with damm,] and muraAmirN↓ (M, Ḳ) A body (M) soft, (Ḳ,) and that quivers, or quakes, [by reason of its fleshiness,] (M, Ḳ,) when the person stands up, or rises: (M:) or [simply] soft. (TA.)
And maramaArapN and muromuwrapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) [in two copies of the Ṣ written maromuwrapN,] applied to a damsel, or girl, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to a woman, (M,) Soft, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and quivering, or quaking, in her flesh, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) when she stands up, or rises. (M.)
muromuwrN and muromuwrapN: see maromaArN.
muraAmirN: see maromaArN.

hom.sense: Oamar-u [More, or most, tightly twisted].
[Hence,] fulaAnN Oamar-u EaqodFA mino fulaAnK † Such a one is firmer, and more faithful to his compact, than such a one. (Ṣ.)

More, or most, bitter: fem. mur-aI: of which the dual is mur-ayaAni. (TA.) You say, hecaA Oamar-u mino caA [This is more bitter than that]. (Ṣ.) And xuci AlHalowaI waOaEoTihi Almur-aI [Take thou the sweeter, or sweetest, and give to him the bitterer, or bitterest]. (Ṣ in art. Hlw.) And it is said in a prov., (A,) by a certain Arab woman, (Ṣ,) SugoraAhaA mur-aAhaA ‡ [The youngest of them is the most bitter of them]. (Ṣ, A.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 720; where another reading is given, Xur-aAhaA for muraAh-aA.]
AlOamar-aAni ‡ Poverty and decrepitude: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or decrepitude and disease. (A.)
Also, ‡ Aloes (AlS-abiru) and Alv-uf-aMCu, (A, Ḳ,) i. e., mustard: (TA:) so in a trad. (A, TA.)

You say also, laqiytu minohu AlOamar-iyna, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with the pl. n, (T, Ṣ,) and with kesr to the r, (Ḳ,) and AlOamar-ayoni, (IAạr, M, A, Ḳ,) dual of Oamar-u, (M,) with fet-ḥ to the r, (Ḳ,) and Almur-ayayoni, dual of mur-aI, (M,) or Almur-atayoni↓, (as in copies of the Ḳ,) ‡ I experienced from him, or it, calamities: (Ṣ, A:) or evil, and a grievous, or distressing, thing. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mamar-N A place of muruwr [i. e. passing; passing by;, &c.; or a place of passage: see 1]. (Ṣ.) You say qaEadotu EalaI mamar-ihi [I sat at his place of passing]. (A.)
It is also an inf. n.: see mar-a bihi. (Ṣ.)
mumar-u A rope, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and thread, (Mṣb,) tightly twisted: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) a rope well twisted: (TA:) and anything twisted. (M, TA.) See also mariyrN.
[Hence,] ‡ A man, and a horse, strongly, or firmly, made. (A,* TA.)
mumir-N: see mur-N.
mamoruwrN Overcome by bile; (Ṣ;) a man whose bile is roused. (A.)

baEiydu Almusotamar-i, with fet-ḥ to the second m, Strong in altercation, not weary of labouring or striving. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) AʼObeyd cites the following verse:
wajadotaniI OalowaI baEiyda Almusotamaro
OaHomilu maA Hum-ilotu mino xayorK waXaro
[Thou findest me very contentious, strong in altercation, not weary of labouring or striving, bearing what is imposed on me of good and evil]. (Ṣ, T, A.) IB says, that this rejez is commonly ascribed to ʼAmr Ibn-'Ás, but it is said to be quoted by him from Artáh Ibn-Suheiyeh: Ṣgh says, that it is ascribed to El-ʼAjjáj, but is not his; and to En-Nejáshee El-Hárithee; and Aboo-Moḥammad El-Aarábee says, that it is by Musáwir Ibn-Hind. (TA.)
musotamir-N act. part. n. of 10, q. v.
EaAdapN musotamir-apN A custom constantly obtaining; unvarying. (A, Mgh.)

siHorN musotamir-N [in the Ḳur, liv. 2,] En-chantment going on: or having one continuous course: or continuing in the same manner: or continuing in a regular, uniform, or constant, course: (Mgh:) or passing away, and vain, or ineffectual: or † strong: (Ḳ:) or bitter. (TA.)

fiI yawomi naHosK musotamir-K [in the Ḳur, liv. 19,] In a day of ill fortune that was lasting, or continual: (Zj, Ḳ:) or of which the evil, (Ḳ:) or ill luck, (TA,) was continual; (Ḳ, TA:) or effective, (Ḳ,* TA,) with respect to that which it was ordered and constrained to accomplish: (Ḳ:) or † potent in its evil fortune: or bitter: or in a Wednesday that did not come round again in the month: (Ḳ:) or in the last Wednesday of the month of Safar. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. maruWa AlT-aEaAmu, aor. _u {yamoruOu}, inf. n. maraMCapN, epithet mariIoCN; and mariYa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and maraOa, aor. _a {yamoraOu}; (Ḳ;) and AstmrO↓; (TA;) The food was, or became, wholesome, or approved in its result: (Z:) or easy to swallow, and wholesome, or approved in its result: (Ḳ:) or easy to swallow, not attended by trouble: or quick in digesting. (Z.) It is said in the Keshsháf, on ch. iv., v. 3, of the Ḳur, that haniIoCN and mariIoCN are two epithets from hanaOa AlT-aEaAmu and maraOa, “the food was easy to swallow; not attended by trouble:” or the former epithet signifies “pleasant, or productive of enjoyment, to the eater;” and the latter, “wholesome, or approved in its result:” or the former, food or drink that is “not succeeded by harm, even after its digestion;” and the latter, that which is “quick in digesting.” (TA.) In conjunction with hanaOaniI, one says maraOaniI (hnOnI AlT-aEaAmu wmrOnI), (Fr. Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoraOu}, inf. n. maroCN; (Akh, Ṣ;) and in conjunction with haniYaniI, mariYaniI; (TA [also mentioned in the Ṣ, on the authority of Akh];) and alone, (i. e. not in conjunction with hnOnI or hnYnI,) OamoraOaniI↓, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UimoraMCN, (AZ,) [It (food) was wholesome to me, &c. (see above):] it was light to my stomach, and descended thence well. (TA.) But maraOaniI also occurs in this sense without hanaOaniI. (TA.)
mariYa AlT-aEaAma, and AstmrOhu↓, [He found the food wholesome, &c.] (Ṣ.) [See above.] AstmrO↓ AlT-aEaAma, signifies Ead-ahu mariyoYFA. (MA.)
maraOa, aor. _a {yamoraOu}, He fed; or ate food. (Ḳ.) Ex. maA laka laA tamoraOu What aileth thee, that thou dost not eat? (TA.)
maruWati AlOaroDu, inf. n. maraACapN, The land was, or became salubrious, in its air. (Ḳ.)

maruWa, aor. _u {yamoruOu}, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muruwoCapN, (Ḳ,) epithet mariIoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was, or became, possessed of muruwoCap; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) sometimes written and pronounced muruw-ap; (Ṣ;) i. e., manliness; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) manly perfection; (TA;) consisting in abstinence from things unlawful, or in chastity of manners, and the having some art or trade; (El-Ahnaf;) or in abstaining from doing secretly what one would be ashamed to do openly; (TA;) or in the habit of doing what is approved, and shunning what is held base; (El-Khafájee;) or in preserving the soul from filthy actions, and what disgraces in the estimation of men; or in good manners, and guarding the tongue, and shunning impudence; (TA;) or in a quality of the mind by preserving which a man is made to persevere in good manners and habits: (Mṣb:) [in a word, virtue; or rather manly virtue or moral goodness.]
maraOa Inivit feminam. (Ḳ.)
mariYa He became like a woman, in external appearance, or in talk. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. hecaA yumoriYu AlT-aEaAma [This makes the food wholesome, &c.] (AZ.) (See maruWa.)
5. tmr-O He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, (takal-afa,) manliness, muruwoCap: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to some, he became possessed of that quality. (TA.)
tmr-O bihimo He sought to acquire the character of manliness (muruwoCap) by disparaging them and vituperating them. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

laA yatamar-aOo OaHadukumo biAld-unoyaA (a trad.) [app., Let not any one of you delight himself in the present world]: but accord. to one relation, it is laA yatamaroOaI, from Alr-uWoyapu: [see art. rOI]. (TA.) [See also tahan-aOa.]

maroCN and muroCN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and miroCN↓ (Ḳ) A man, or human being; syn. UinosaAnN: (Ḳ:) or a man as opposed to a child or a woman; syn. rajulN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say maroCN in the nom., maroCFA in the acc., and maroCK in the gen., (Ṣ,) agreeably with analogy. (TA.) And some say muroCN in the nom., maroCFA in the acc., and miroCK in the gen.; doubly declining the word. (TA, and some copies of the Ṣ.)
And miroC↓ is said to be of the dial. of Hudheyl. It is said that no pl. is formed from mrC; but maroWuwna occurs as its pl. in the following words of a trad.; OaHosinuwA OamolaACakumo Oay-uhaA AlmuroWuwna [Amend your manners, O ye men!]; and in the saying of Ru-beh, Oayona yuriydu AlmrWwn [Whither do the men desire to go?]. (TA.) It forms a dual; miroMni: they say humaA miroMni SaAliHaAni [They are two just men] (Ṣ) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) It also forms a dim., muraIoCN, fem. murayoYapN. (Ṣ.)
The fem. of maroCN is maroOapN, A woman: [and a wife:] also written and pronounced marapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mrC is also written with the conjunctive A: you say QmoraON in the nom., QmoraOF in the acc., and QmoraOK in the gen.: also, QmoruWN in the nom., QmoruWFA in the acc., and QmoruWK in the gen.: also, QmoruWN in the nom., QmoraOF in the acc., and QmoriYK in the gen.; doubly declining the word. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [The last three forms are the most common in classical works: but in ordinary parlance, in the present day, the word is generally pronounced with fet-ḥ to the r in each case. The final C is also often written without the A or w or I.] Ks and Fr say, that the word is doubly declined, as to the r and C, because the final C is often omitted. (T, TA.) [When the disjunctive A is substituted for the conjunctive, i. e., when the word is immediately preceded by a quiescence, its vowel is kesr: thus you say AimoraON, &c.; and thus also in the fem. The name of the famous poet AimoraOu Alqayosi [or AimoruOu Alqayosi] is commonly pronounced Imra-el-Ḳeys and Imr-el-Ḳeys.]

The fem. is QmoraOapN, A woman: [and a wife:] but with Al you say AlmaroOapu: AlAimoraOapu [which is authorized by the Ḳ] is also said to be established by usage; but most of the expositors of the Fṣ reject this; and those who allow it to be correct judge it of weak authority: IO mentions also QmoraApN, with soft A after the r. (TA.)

QmoraCN [or QmoruCN] is also used in a fem. sense; (Ṣ;) though this is extr.: ex. Uin-ahaA laQmoraCa Sidoq [Verily she is an excellent woman: see SidoqN]. (TA.) And QmoraOapN is used, in a trad., as signifying a perfect woman: laqado tazaw-ajota QmoraOapF Indeed thou hast married a perfect woman: like as you say fulaAnN rajulN, meaning “Such a one is a perfect man.” (TA.)

Also, AimoraON or QmoruWN, (Ṣ,) or maroCN, (Ḳ,) signifies A wolf: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as Z and others assert, it is tropical in this sense. Yoo says, that the poet means, by QmrW, in the following verse, a wolf:
waOanota QmoruWN taEoduw EalaI kul-i gir-apK
fatuxoTiYu fiyhaA mar-apF watuSiybu
[And thou art a wolf that assaultest on every occasion of carelessness; and sometimes thou missest therein, and (sometimes) thou attainest thine object]. (TA.)

The rel. n. of QmoraCN is maraYiI-N (as in one copy of the Ṣ) or muraYiI-N (as in another copy) and OamariI-N. (Ṣ, and El-Ashmoonee and others.) [For the last, Golius, from a copy of the Ṣ, gives AimoraYiI-N: and in one copy of the Ṣ, I find it written OamoraYiI-N: but I have not met with any confirmation of either of these two forms.] maraYiI-N seems to be formed from maroCN; but is extr.; the analogous form being maroYiI-N. (TA.)
maraON A giving of food on the occasion of building a house, or marrying. (TA.)

mariIoCN The œsophagus, or gullet of a slaughtered camel, or sheep or goat, (Ṣ,) and of a man, (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán,) the canal through which the food and drink pass; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the head of the stomach; (Ḳ;) contiguous, (Ṣ,) or adherent (Ḳ) to the Huloquwm [or windpipe]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) through which the food and drink pass, and by which they enter: (TA;) pl. [of pauc.] OamoriYapN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] muruWN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is also written mariI-N. (TA.)

yaOotiynA fiI mivoli mariIoCi Aln-aEaAmi [It comes to us as it were through the gullet of the ostrich]: a proverbial expression, from a trad., alluding to paucity of food; the ostrich being particularized because of the slenderness of its neck, whence is inferred the narrowness of its gullet. (TA.)
Wholesome, &c. (See maruWa.)
haniyoYFA mariyoYFA: see art. hnO and see 1 in the present art.
gayovN mariIoCN [A rain productive of good result]. (TA.)
kalaON mariIoCN Wholesome herbage. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN mariyoYapN A land salubrious in its air. (Ḳ.)
mariIoCN Manly, &c. (See maruWa.)
maraMCapN: see maruWa.
muruwoCapN and muruw-apN: see maruWa
QmoraON and QmoraOapN, &c.: see maroCN.
mumoriYN act. part. n. of 4, Wholesome food. (Ṣ.) [See 4, and mariYN.]
1. maruta, aor. _u {yamorutu}, inf. n. muruwtapN, It (a tract, or land,) was, or became, what is termed marotN. [See muruwtapN.]
marata, aor. _i {yamoritu}, He rendered smooth. (A, Ḳ.)
marata AlUibila, aor. _i {yamoritu}, He removed the camels from their place. (Ḳ.)
marata, [aor. _i {yamoritu}] inf. n. marotN, He broke [a thing]. (TA.)
marata Alxuboza fiI AlmaACi i. q. marada: (Yaạḳoob:) or it is written mrv. (TA.)

marotN A waterless desert in which is no herbage: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a land in which no herbage grows: or, in which there is neither little [herbage] nor much: (TA:) or a land of which the soil does not become dry, and of which the pasture-grounds, or fields, do not produce herbage: (Ḳ:) or land in which is no herbage; even if it be rained upon: (TA:) as also maruwtN↓; and OaroDN mamoruwtapN: pl. of marotN, OamoraAtN and muruwtN. (Ḳ.)

OaroDN marotN, (TA,) and makaAnN marotN, (Ṣ, TA,) A land, and a place, that is desert, without water and without herbage. (TA.) You say OaroDN marotN and ArD maruwtN↓: but land that has been rained upon in the winter is not termed mrt, because the rain gives hope of its producing herbage. (TA.)
marotN, (Ḳ,) or marotN AlHaAjibi, (Ṣ,) A man having no hair upon his eyebrows. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
marotu Aljasadi Having no hair upon his body. (TA.)
maruwtN: see marotN.
muruwtapN (a subst. Ḳ.) [The condition of a land, or tract, such as is termed marotN]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or, accord. to Ibn-Maạroof, as stated by Golius, it is an inf. n.: if so, its verb is maruta].
xir-iytN mir-iytN: see art. xrt.
maAruwtu [A certain fallen angel,] the companion of haAruwtu: (TA:) a foreign word; or from Almuruwtap; (Ḳ;) or from Almarotu as signifying Alkasoru. (TA.)
maromariytN A calamity; a misfortune. (Ḳ.) Some say, that it is formed from maromariysN, by the substitution of t for s.

hom.sense: 1. marava, (aor. _u {yamoruvu}, inf. n. marovN, Ṣ,) He steeped dates in water, and mashed them (Ṣ, Ḳ) with the hand; (Ṣ;) syn. marasa: (Ṣ, Ḳ;) sometimes maraca is also used in this sense. (Ṣ.)
marava, (aor. _u {yamoruvu}, inf. n. marovN, TA,) He made a thing soft, (Ḳ,) so that it became of such a subsistence that it might be supped, and then supped it. (TA.)

marava, (aor. _u {yamoruvu} and _i {yamorivu}, inf. n. marovN, TA,) He steeped, soaked, or macerated, a thing in water: (Ḳ:) he soaked bread in water; as also maraca. (Sh, Aṣ.) marava He steeped medicine, &c. in water until it became altered. (A.)

marava, [aor. _u {yamoruvu},] He (a child, Ṣ,) mumbled, or bit softly, his finger: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he (a child) bit with his gums: he (a child) bit and sucked a necklace, or string of beads, such as is called saxaAbN. (TA.)
marava, aor. _u {yamoruvu} and _i {yamorivu}, (inf. n. marovN, TA,) He [a child] sucked the kind of shells called cowries. (Ḳ.)
He sucked. (IAạr.)
He (a child) sucked his mother's breast. (IAạr.)
mariva, aor. _a {yamoravu}, (inf. n. maravN, IAạr,) He was mild and forbearing, or clement; and patient in bearing altercation. (Ḳ, TA.)

marava, [aor. _u {yamoruvu},] He beat, or struck, or smote, a man: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to AʼObeyd, mrava bihi AlOaroDa, and mr-v↓, he threw him, or flung him, upon the ground: or, accord. to Fr, the verb is marana. (TA.)

marava Als-axolapa, aor. _u {yamoruvu}, (L,) and mr-vhA↓, He imparted to the lamb, or kid, a foul smell, of sweat, or grease, or the like, so that its mother would not take to it: (Ḳ:) he rendered it foul and greasy with his hand, so that its mother would not suckle it: (Ibn-Jo'eyl El-Kelbee:) he befouled it by stroking it with hands defiled by the smell of flesh-meat or fish, so that its mother would not take to it. (El-Mufaddal Ed-Ḍabbee.)
Also, marava He defiled water, by putting into it his hands foul with flesh-meat, or grease, or the like. (TA, from a trad.)
2. mr-v, inf. n. tamoriyvN, He crumbled, or broke into small pieces, with his fingers. (Ḳ.)
See 1 in two places.

entry.sense: marivN: see mimoravN.
marovapN A single suck, by a child, of its mother's breast. (IAạr.)
mimoravN Patient in bearing altercation: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mild and forbearing, or clement: as also marivN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) pl. of the former, mamaArivu. (Ṣ.)
OaroDN mumar-avapN A land watered by a weak rain, (Ḳ,) and so rendered soft, and dissolved. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. maraja, aor. _u {yamoruju}, inf. n. marojN, He (a beast of carriage) fed in a pasture. (Mṣb.)

maraja, (aor. _u {yamoruju} S,) inf. n. marojN, He sent a beast of carriage to pasture: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or left it [app. to pasture wheresoever it would]: (Ḳṭ:) he pastured it; (TA;) and so Oamoraja↓: (Ḳṭ, Ḳ:) or the latter signifies he left it to go wheresoever it would [app. to pasture]. (TA.)
maraja, inf. n. marojN, ‡ He mixed [a thing with another thing, or two things together]. (Ḳ.)

maraja AlbaHorayoni, [Ḳur., xxv., 55; and lv., 19,] ‡ He hath mixed the two seas, (Zj, Ḳ,) so that they meet together, the sweet and the salt, yet so that the salt does not overpass its bounds and mix itself with the sweet: (Zj:) or He hath sent them forth so that they afterwards meet together: but this is only said by the people of Tihámeh: (Fr:) or, as also Oamoraja↓, (this latter form is used by some, Akh, Ṣ, and is the form used by the grammarians, TA,) He hath let them flow freely, yet so that one does not become mixed with the other: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) He hath made them flow. (IAạr, with reference to the former verb.)
maraja, aor. _u {yamoruju}, † He marred, or spoiled, his affair. (TA.)
mrija, aor. _a {yamoraju}, inf. n. marajN, ‡ It (e. g. a deposit, Ṣ, and a covenant, and religion, TA) became corrupt; impaired; spoiled; marred; or disordered. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
marija, aor. _a {yamoraju}, inf. n. marajN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and maraja; but the former is the more approved; (TA;) It (a ring, on the finger, Ṣ, and an arrow, TA) became unsteady; (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like jarija. (Ṣ.)

marija, aor. _a {yamoraju}, inf. n. marajN, ‡ It (religion, and an affair, Ṣ, and a covenant, TA) became in a confused and disturbed state, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) so that one found it difficult to extricate himself from perplexity therein. (TA.) It (a covenant), was in a confused state, and little observed. (TA.)
marija Aln-aAsu The people became confused. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.

Amrjt She (a camel) ejected her embryo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the seed of the stallion, (M,) in a state consisting of, (Ḳ,) or after its becoming, (Ṣ, M,) what is termed giros [or matter resembling mucus] and blood. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Amrj ‡ He violated a covenant, (Ḳ,) and religion. (TA.)

marojN A pasture, pasturage, pasture-land, or meadow; a place in which beasts pasture; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb, TA;) an ample tract of land abounding with herbage, into which beasts are sent to pasture: (T:) also a wide, open tract of land: (TA:) pl. muruwjN. (Mṣb.)

harojN wamarojN; the latter being written thus, with the r quiescent, only to assimilate it to the former; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and signifying ‡ Confusion, and disturbance, in an affair or the like: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or intricate disorder, discord, trouble, or the like. (L.)
marajN A camel, and camels, (or a beast, or beasts, TA,) pasturing without a pastor. (Ḳ.)

marojaAnN, a coll. gen. n.; n. un. with p {marojaAnapN}; (L;) Small pearls: (AHeyth, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the like thereof: or large pearls: (El-Wáḥidee:) or coral, bus-acN, which is a red gem: or red beads; which is the meaning assigned to the word by Ibn-Mesʼood, and is agreeable with the common acceptation thereof; or, accord. to Et-Tarasoosee (or, as in the TA, Et-Turtooshee, and so correctly accord. to MF) certain red roots that grow up in the sea, like the fingers of the hand: [vulgarly pronounced murojaAn:] the n is said to be an augmentative letter, because there is no Arabic word of the measure faEolaAlN, except such as are reduplicative, like xaloxaAlN: but Az says, I know not whether it be a triliteral-radical word or a quadriliteral: (Mṣb:) IḲṭṭ asserts it to be of the measure faEolaAlN. (TA.)

Also A leguminous plant that grows in the season called Alr-abiyE, (Ḳ,) rising to the height of a cubit, with red twigs, and broad round leaves, very dense, juicy, satisfying thirst, and having the property of making the milk of animals that feed upon it to become abundant: (TA:) n. un. with p {marojaAnapN}. (Ḳ.)
OamorN mariyjN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and maArijN↓, (TA,) ‡ A confused affair, or case: (Zj., Ṣ, Ḳ:) or error: so the former signifies in the Ḳur, l., 5. (TA.)
sar-aAjN mar-aAjN: see sar-aAjN.

maArijN ‡ Mixture, syn. xaloTN: (L:) [as though one of the few inf. ns. of the measure faAEilN, like qaAYimN: but it is said in the L to be a subst., like kaAhilN and gaAribN, and evidently signifies a mixture, or that which is mixed; syn. xiloTN].

maArijN mino naArK, as occurring in the Ḳur., [lv., 14,] ‡ A mixture (xiloTN, L) of fire: (AʼObeyd:) or flame mixed with the black substance of fire: or flame of fire: (TA:) or fire without smoke, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whereof was created El-Jánn, (Ṣ,) i. e., Iblees, the father of the Jinn, or Genii, (Bḍ, Jel,) or the Jinn collectively: (Bḍ:) or fire dwn AlHjAb, [app. meaning below the veil, or that which conceals the lowest heaven, and the angels, from the jinn, or genii, who when they attempt to overhear the conversation of the angels, are smitten by the angels pursuing them with thunderbolts,] of which the thunderbolts consists. (Fr.)
See mariyjN.
mimoraAjN: see mumorijN.
Also, A man who mars, or spoils, his affairs, (Ḳ, TA,) and does not execute them soundly. (TA.)

mumorijN A she-camel ejecting her embryo, or the seed of the stallion, in a state consisting of, or after its becoming, what is termed giros [or matter resembling mucus] and blood. (TA.) A camel that usually does so is termed mimoraAjN↓. (Ḳ.)
1. mariHati Alqirobapu, aor. _a {yamoraHu}, inf. n. maraHaAnN, The water-skin leaked, or let out its water through the punctures made in sewing it. (L.)
mariHa Als-aHaAbu The clouds poured forth rain. (L.)

mariHa, (L,) inf. n. maraHaAnN, (L, Ḳ,) He, or it, became weak. (L, Ḳ.) You say mariHato Eayonuhu His eye became weak. (L.) Also, mariHato Eayonuhu, inf. n. maraHaAnN, His eye flowed much; (L, Ḳ;) and became in a corrupt, or vitiated, or disordered, state; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and became inflamed, syn. haAjat: (Ṣ, L:) or poured forth tears: (L:) or shed many tears. (Sh.)

mariHa, aor. _a {yamoraHu}, inf. n. maraHN, † He exulted; or rejoiced overmuch, or above measure; or he exulted greatly, or excessively; and was exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: (L:) or he exulted; or exulted greatly; or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully; syn. OaXira and baTira: or he was very joyful or glad; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ṣ:) or he was joyful, or glad: (Mṣb:) or it signifies also, he became joyful, or glad, (Ḳ,) and light, (TA,) and the inf. n. in this sense is maraHaAnN: (Ḳ, TA:) and he was brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Ḳ.)

mariHa, aor. _a {yamoraHu}, (inf. n. maraHN, L,) † He was proud and self-conceited: and he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (L, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur, xvii., 39; and xxxi., 17. (L.) [See also a verse cited voce SaAEN.]
2. mr-H Alqirobapa, (inf. n. tamoriyHN, L,) ‡ He filled the water-skin with water in order that the punctures of the stitches might close up; i. q. sar-abahaA. (Ṣ.)
Also, ‡ He rendered the water-skin sweet, when it was new, with Uicoxir or with XiyH The rendering it sweet with loam or clay is termed taXoriybN. (IAạr.)
mr-H AlmazaAdapa ‡ He filled the mzAdp with water, when it was new, in order that the punctures in it, made in sewing, might close up. (T, Ḳ.)
mr-H Aljiloda † He anointed the skin with oil. (Ḳ.)

4. AmrHhu He made him to exult, or rejoice above measure; and to be exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: or made him to exult; or to exult greatly, or excessively; and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (L:) or he made him to be very joyful or glad; and to be very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ṣ:) [&c.: see 1].
AmrHhu It (pasture) made him (a horse) brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)

maraHN, a subst., The leaking of a water-skin, or its letting out its water through the punctures made in sewing it. (L.) You say cahaba maraHu AlmazaAdapi The leaking of the mzAdp has ceased, when the punctures made in sewing it become closed up. (L, A, Ḳ.)

mariHN and mir-iyHN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) Exulting, or rejoicing overmuch, or above measure; and exceedingly brisk, lively, or sprightly: or exulting; or greatly, or excessively, exulting; and behaving insolently, and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (L, Ḳ:*) or very joyful or glad; and very brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ṣ:) [&c.: see 1:] pl. (of the former, L) maroHaI and maraAHaI, and (of the latter, which has no broken pl.,) mir-iyHuwna. (L, Ḳ.)

maroHaI A word that is said to one when he hits the mark in shooting or casting; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) expressing admiration; (Ṣ;) as also maraHay-aA: (Ḳ: [in the CK maraHay-FA, which is wrong]) like as baroHaI is said to one who misses the mark. (Ṣ.)
mazaAdapN mariHapN A mzAdp that leaks, or does not retain its water. (AHan.) [See mariHati Alqirobapu.]

miraAHN, subst. from mariHa, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) Exultation, or joy, above measure; and exceeding briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: or exultation; or great, or excessive, exultation; and insolent and unthankful, or ungrateful behaviour: (L, Ḳ:*) or great joy or gladness; and great briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (Ṣ:) [&c.: see 1].
maruwHN and mimoraAHN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mimoraHN↓. (Ḳ.) A brisk, lively, or sprightly, horse, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) and she-camel. (L.)
maruwHN Wine; so called because of its briskness in the vessel. (ISd, L.) EuqaArN maruwHN Wine that affects the head, and makes the drinker very joyful and brisk. (Ṣ.)

qawosN maruwHN ‡ A bow at the beauty of which the beholders rejoice exceedingly (Ḳ) when they turn it about and examine it: (TA:) or, as though it rejoiced exceedingly, or greatly, at the beautiful manner of its shooting the arrow. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

TaruwHo maruwHo tuEojilu AlZ-aboIa Oano yaruwHo [A bow that sends the arrow far, that makes those who behold and examine it to rejoice exceedingly, that makes the antelope hasten to go]. A saying of the Arabs. (L.)
mir-iyHN: see mariHN.
mimoraHN: see maruwHN.
EayonN mimoraAHN ‡ An eye that sheds copious tears: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an eye that is quick to weep. (TA.) See maruwHN.
timoraAHapN Very brisk or lively or sprightly; or exceedingly so. (IAth, L, from a trad.)

1. maraxa jasadahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoraxu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maroxN; (Ṣ;) and mr-xhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tamoriyxN; (Ṣ;) He anointed his body (Ḳ) with oil (Ṣ, Ḳ), &c. (Ḳ.) And maraxa UidaAwatahu He smeared with clay his UidaAwap [or small vessel of skin, for water,] in order that its odour might become good. (IAạr, TA in art. crH.)
2. mar-axa see 1.
4. Amrx He made dough, or paste, thin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by putting much water to it. (Ṣ.)
5. tmr-x biAld-uhoni He anointed himself with oil. (L.)

maroxN [a coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of tree that quickly emits fire: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is of the kind called EiDaAh, and spreads, and grows high, so that people rest in its shade: it has neither leaves nor thorns, its branches being bare and slender twigs; and it grows in [small water-courses such as are termed] XuEab, and in hard grounds: of it are made the wooden instruments for producing fire which are called zinaAd: the n. un. is with p {maroxapN} (AḤn, L) its shade is thin: (L:) there is no tree that surpasses the mrx in yeilding fire: sometimes these trees are clustered and tangled together, and the wind blowing, and striking one part of them against another, they emit fire, and burn the valley: (Aboo-Ziyád:) [the cynanchum viminale. (Spreng. Hist. rei. herb., p. 252: as mentioned by Freytag.)] It is said in a proverb, fiI kul-i XajarK naAro waQsotamojada Almaroxu waQloEafaAro [In all trees is fire; but the markh and 'afár yield much fire]: (Ṣ:) accord. to AḤn, the meaning is, endeavour to strike fire with gentleness; for that will be sufficient if the zinaAd be marox. (L.) See also EafaArN, and Astmjd. The EfAr is the zanod, which is the upper [piece of the two which compose the zanaAd]; and the marox is the lower. (Ṣ, L.) [See also another proverb at the end of art. dfl.]

Oaroxi yadayoka waQsotaroxi Uin-a Alz-inaAda min m-aroxi [Relax thy hands, and relax thyself, for the wooden instrument for striking fire is of markh]. A saying used with reference to a generous man who requires not to be importuned. (IAạr, TA.)
marixN (Ḳ) and mir-iyxN↓ (L) A man who anoints himself much, (L, Ḳ,) and perfumes himself much. (TA.)
maruwxN Oil, &c., with which the body is anointed. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: mir-iyxN: see marixN.

A long arrow, having four feathers, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with which one shoots to the utmost distance: (Ṣ:) or an arrow which they make for lightness, and which they mostly shoot to the utmost distance [to measure the ground] for the purpose of making horses run when they contend in a race. (Aboo-Ziyád.)
Almir-iyxu, (Ṣ Ḳ,) and mir-iyxN, without Al, which, however, is understood, (IAạr,) [The planet Mars]; one of the stars called Alxun-asu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the fifth heaven, (Ṣ,) also called bahoraAmu.

1. marada, (aor. _u {yamorudu}, inf. n. marodN, Ṣ, L,) He steeped bread, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or corn, (Mṣb,) in water, and mashed it with his hand, so as to soften it: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he soaked bread in water; (M, L;) and so marava, and maraca, with the dotted c; or he softened bread in water, and crumbled it with his fingers. (Aṣ, L.)
maradahu He rubbed it (a thing) in water. (TA.)
maradahu, inf. n. marodN, He crumbled it [namely bread, &c.], or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers; syn. varadahu. (TA [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.])
maradahu, aor. _u {yamorudu}, inf. n. marodN, He made it (a thing) soft. (L.)
maradahu and mr-dhu↓ He made it (a thing) soft and smooth; he polished it. (L.) See also 2.
marada, (inf. n. marodN, Ṣ, L,) He (a child, Ṣ, L) mumbled (marasa) the breast (Ṣ,* L,* Ḳ) of his mother: (Ṣ, L:) or sucked it. (IḲṭṭ.)
marida, aor. _?, He continued to eat mariyd, i. e., dates soaked in milk until rendered soft. (Ḳ.)
marida ‡ It (a branch) was, or became, destitute of leaves. (IAạr, L.)
maridati AlOaroDu, inf. n. maradN, ‡ The land was, or became, destitute of herbage, excepting a small quantity. (TA.)
marida He (a horse) was, or became, without hair upon the fetlock. (IḲṭṭ.)

marida, aor. _a {yamoradu}, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. maradN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and muruwdapN; (L, Ḳ;) and tmr-d↓; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) He (a youth, or young man,) was as yet beardless: (Mṣb:) or had no hair upon his cheeks: (IAạr, L:) or remained to a late period without his beard having grown, (L, Ḳ,) or without the hair of his face having grown forth. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb)

marada aor. _u {yamorudu}, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muruwdN (A, L, Ḳ) and marodN; (IAạr, L;) and maruda, aor. _u {yamorudu}, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. maraAdapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and muruwdapN; (TA, and some copies of the Ḳ;) and tmr-d↓; (A, L;) He exalted himself, or was insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; (IAạr, L;) he was hold, or audacious; (M, L, Ḳ;) and immoderate, inordinate, or exhorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient or rebellious; or exalted himself and was inordinate in infidelity; or was extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing; or was refractory, or averse from obedience: (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he went to such an extreme as thereby to pass from out of the general state [or category] of that species [to which he belonged]. (M, L, Ḳ.)

So in the phrase mrd EalaI AlOamori He was bold or audacious, and immoderate, &c., in the affair: (M, L:) and in like manner, ElI AlX-ar-i, in evil, or mischief: tmr-d↓ EalayonaA He acted immoderately, inordinately, or exorbitantly, &c., towards us, or against us. (L.)
Some explain maruda as syn. with xabuva [signifying He was bad, evil, wicked, malignant, noxious, corrupt, &c.]. (MF.)

tamar-ada↓ maAridN waEaz-a AlOabolaqu ‡ [Márid hath resisted the attempt to take it, and El-Ablak hath proved strong]: a proverb: (Ṣ:) originally said by Ex-Zebbà, the Queen of the Arabs, with reference to two fortresses which she had failed to take. (TA.)
marada, (L,) inf. n. marodN, (L, Ḳ,) He (a sailor) pushed, or propelled, a ship or boat, with a murodiI-. (L, Ḳ.)
He drove vehemently. (L, Ḳ.)
marada EalaI XaIoCK, [aor. _u {yamorudu},] (Ḳ,) inf. n. muruwdN; (Ṣ, L;) and tmr-d↓; (L.) ‡ He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to a thing. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

maraduwA EalaI Aln-ifaAqi [Ḳur., ix., 102,] ‡ They have become accustomed, habituated, or inured, to hypocrisy: (Fr., A, L:) or they have exalted themselves, or become insolent and audacious, in hypocrisy: (IAạr:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is from XajarapN marodaMCu “a tree without leaves;” meaning, † they have become destitute of good. (TA.)
marada EalaI AlkalaAmi ‡ He became accustomed, or habituated, to what was said, so that he cared not for it. (L.)

entry.sense: 2. mr-dhu, inf. n. tamoriydN, ‡ He stripped it (a branch) of its leaves. (Ṣ, A, L.)
‡ He stripped it (a branch) of its peel; as also maradahu. (TA.) See 1.
mr-dhu, (A, L,) inf. n. tamoriydN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He made it (a building) smooth (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and even (L, Ḳ) and tall or long; (A;) and plastered it with mud. (L.)
5: see 1 in five places.
marodN [Coll. gen. n.] Bread crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers, and then moistened with broth; syn. variydN. (T, L.)

What is fresh and juicy of the fruit of the OaraAk: (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) what is ripe thereof is called kabaAvN: (T, L:) or [in the CK, and] what is ripe thereof: (L, Ḳ:) what has become black being called kbAv: (TA in art. brm:) or certain red and large things pertaining thereto: n. un. with p {marodapN}. (AḤn, L.)
maradaI: see maraTaI.
murodiI-N a pole with which a ship, or boat, is pushed, or propelled: (L, Ḳ:) or an oar; syn. mijocaAfN. (IḲṭṭ.)
maraAdN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and mar-aAdN↓ (Ḳ) The neck: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. [of the latter] maraAriydu. (Ḳ.)
maruwdN: see maAridN.

hom.sense: mariydN Bread steeped in water, and mashed with the hand: or soaked in water. (L.)

Dates soaked in milk until they become soft: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or dates thrown into milk to become soft, and then mashed with the hand: (Aṣ, L:) or moistened, and rubbed and pressed with the fingers till soft, in water or in milk; as also mariysN. (Mgh, art. mrs.)
Water with milk. (Ḳ.)
Anything rubbed and pressed with the hand until it becomes flaccid. (Aṣ, L.)
See maAridN.

entry.sense: mar-aAdN: see maraAdN.
mir-iydN: see maAridN.

maAridN [from marada] and mariydN↓ [from maruda] (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mutamar-idN↓ (A, Ḳ) [One who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; an insolent and audacious rebel or unbeliever; see 1;] bold or audacious; (M, L, Ḳ;) and immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient or rebellious;, &c.; see 1; (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and strong: (L:) these epithets are applied to evil beings of mankind and of the jinn, (L,) and to any animal: (M, L:) the first is said to be applied to an evil jinnee of the most powerful class: (Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c.) pl. (of the first, M, L,) maradapN (M, L, Ḳ) and mur-aAdN; (A;) and (of the second, M, L) muradaMCu. (M, L, Ḳ.) mir-iydN↓ signifies the same in an intensive degree. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
maAridN Lofty, high: (L, Ḳ:) applied to a building. (TA.)
maAridN and maruwdN↓ One who often goes and comes, by reason of his briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (L.)

XajarapN marodaMCu ‡ A tree having no leaves upon it: (Ks, A, L, Ḳ:) or, of which the leaves have altogether gone: (AḤn, L:) and in like manner, guSonN Oamoradu ‡ a branch having no leaves upon it: (Ks, Ṣ, L:) or the latter expression is not used. (T, L.)
ramolapN marodaMCu ‡ A sand that is plain (L) and produces no plants: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) pl. maraAdK, as though it were a subst. (M, L.)
OaroDN marodaMCu ‡ An expanse of sands in which nothing grows: pl. maraAdiI [or maraAdiI-u]. (Aṣ, T, L.)

Oamoradu A youth, or young man, as yet beardless: (Mṣb:) or having no hair upon his cheeks: (IAạr, L:) or who has remained to a late period without the hair of his face having grown forth: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or whose mustache has grown forth, but not his beard, (L, Ḳ,) he having attained the usual age at which the beard grows: (L:) pl. murodN: (L:) dim. Oumayoridu. (A.) You do not apply the epithet marodaMCu to a girl [in the sense above explained]. (Ṣ, L.) It is said in a trad., Oaholu Aljan-api jurodN murodN [The people of paradise are without hair upon their bodies, and beardless]. (L.)
marodaMCu A woman having no hair upon her pubes. (M, L, Ḳ.) [In some copies of the Ḳ, for laA Uisoba lahaA, we find lA Ast lhA: and the like is found in copies of the A.]
Oamoradu A horse having no hair upon the fetlock. (Ṣ, L.)
mumar-adN A building made smooth, and tall or long: (A:) or made smooth: (L:) or made tall or long. (AʼObeyd, L, Ḳ.)
jabalN mutamar-idN ‡ [A mountain that opposes obstacles to one's ascent]: pl. jibaAlN mutamar-idaAtN. (A.)
See maAridN.
murodaAsanojN: see marotakN in art. rtk.

marodaquwXN [Marjoram; sweet marjoram; so called in the present day;] i. q. marozanojuwXN [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an arabicized word, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) [thought to be so by J,] from [the Persian] murodaho kuwXo, (Ḳ) meaning “having a dead ear,” (TA,) or “having a soft ear,” [which is given in the Ḳ as one of the significations of the arabicized word,] (AHeyth, TA,) because what is flaccid is as though it were dead: (TA:)
or [so accord. to the Ṣ, TA; but accord. to the Ḳ, and] saffron: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a certain perfume which a woman puts upon her comb, inclining to redness and blackness. (Ḳ.) The vulgar [generally] say barodaquwX. (TA.)

marozanojuwXN, (Ṣ, and so in the Ḳ in art. mrdqX, &c., in some copies of the Ḳ in the present art.,) or marozajuwXN, (so in some copies of the Ḳ in the present art.,) or both, the latter being of the measure faEolaluwlN, like EaDorafuwTN, (TA,) [Marjoram; sweet marjoram; called by the former name in the present day;] i. q. marodaquwXN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an arabicized word, from [the Persian] marozanokuwXo [lit. “mouse-ear”: but see marodaquwX]: in [genuine] Arabic, samosaqN: beneficial for dysury, and colic, and the sting of the scorpion, and pains arising from cold, and melancholy, and inflation, or flatulence, and the disease called laqowap [which distorts one side of the face], and flow of saliva from the mouth, and it is strongly diuretic, and dries up humours of the stomach and bowels. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. marasahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fI AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) aor. _u {yamorusu}, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. marosN, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) He macerated, steeped, or soaked, it, (namely, a quantity of dates, Ṣ, Ḳ, or other things, Ṣ, or medicine, M, A, and bread, M,) in water, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and mashed it with the hand: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so says ISk: (TA:) he rubbed and pressed it, (namely, a quantity of dates,) with the hand, in water, so that it became mashed: (Mṣb:) he moistened it, (namely, bread, or the like,) in water, and rubbed and pressed it with the fingers until it became soft. (Mgh.) marosN also signifies the rubbing and pressing with the hand: and mixing; or moistening with water or the like. (TA.)

marasa UiSobaEahu, aor. _u {yamorusu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. marosN, (TA,) He (a child) mumbled, or bit softly, his finger; i. q. maravahaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of which it is a dial. form; or it is an instance of mispronunciation. (Ṣ.) See also marada.
marasa yadahu biAlminodiyli † He wiped his hand with the napkin. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 5.
marisa: see 3.

marisa AlHabolu, (Ṣ, M,) aor. _a {yamorasu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. mrasN; (Ṣ, M;) or marasa, aor. _u {yamorusu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. marosN; (TA;) The rope fell on one of the two sides of the sheave of the pulley: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or fell between the sheave of the pulley and the bent piece of iron which is on each side thereof and in which is the pin whereon the sheave turns. (M.) And marisati Albakorapu, aor. _a {yamorasu}, inf. n. marasN, The sheave of the pulley had its rope sticking fast between it and the qaEow [or cheek]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. mArs, (M, TA,) inf. n. mumaArasapN and miraAsN, (Ṣ, M,) He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, to prevail, overcome, gain the mastery, or effect an object, syn. of the inf. n. muEaAlajapN: (Ṣ:) or he did so vehemently; as also marisa↓, [aor. _a {yamorasu},] inf. n. marasN: (M, TA:) [and maraAsapN is also, perhaps, an inf. n. of the latter verb, though by rule its verb should be marusa.] You say, faHolN cuw miraAsK A stallion possessing strength: (Ḳ:) or possessing strength, or vehemence, of labour or exertion; (TA;) and fulaAnN cuw miraAsK, and marasK↓, Such a one is a possessor of hardiness and strength, (A,) and rajulN bay-inu Almarasi, (Ṣ, TA,) and AlmaraAsapi, (Ḳ,* TA,) A man bearing evidence of strength: (Ḳ,* TA:) or of strength, or vehemence, of labour or exertion. (Ṣ.)

mArshu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He laboured, exerted himself, strove, struggled, contended, or conflicted, with him, or it, to prevail, overcome, or gain the mastery or possession, or to effect an object: he laboured, or worked, at it, or upon it: syn. EaAlajahu, and zaAwalahu. (Ḳ.) You say, mArs qironahu He strove, contended, or conflicted, with his adversary; syn. EaAlajahu. (A.) And mArs EamalFA He exercised, or practised, diligently, or plied, a work, or an occupation; he laboured. (L, voce EaAlaja.) And mArs AlA-umuwra [He laboured, exerted himself, or exercised himself diligently, in the management, or transaction, of affairs]. (A.) And mArs ZahorFA [He plied, worked, or put to labour, a camel for riding, or carriage]. (L, art. Elj.)
mArs, inf. n. mumaArasapN, also signifies He played, or sported, with another, or others; as, for instance, with women; used in this sense in a trad. (TA.) See also 5, in two places.
4. Amrs AlHabola, (inf. n. UimoraAsN, TA,) He restored the rope to the place [or groove of the sheave] in which it ran. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

Also, He removed the rope from the place in which it ran; (TA;) he made the rope to stick fast between the sheave of the pulley and the qaEow [or cheek]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Thus it bears two contr. significations, on the authority of Yaạḳoob. (Ṣ.)
5. tmr-s It was, or became, strongly twisted and adhering. (M.) See marasapN.
tmr-s bihi He kept to it constantly, or assiduously; he accustomed himself to it; syn. Dariyahu [app. for DariIa bihi]. (M.)

He rubbed, or scratched, himself against it; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as, for instance, a camel against the trunk of a palm-tree, (A,) or any tree, on account of the mange or an itching; (TA;) as also Amtrs↓ bh. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, Albaqarapu tamar-asu biAlX-ajari The cow rubs her horns against the trees to sharpen them. (A. [In my copy of the A, I find here tamorusu; but this is evidently a mistake of the copyist for tamar-asu, or its original form tatamar-asu.])

[Hence, app., † He made use of him.] You say, laA yatamar-asu bihi OaHadN liOan-ahu SulobN laA yusotagal-u minohu XaIoCN † [No one makes any use of him; for he is hard: nothing, meaning no profit, or advantage, is reaped, or obtained from him]. (L.) [See also mutamar-asN.]

‡ He (a camel) ate of it (a tree) time after time. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the signs of the resurrection yatamar-asu Alr-ajulu bidiynihi kamaA yatamar-asu AlbaEiyru biAlX-ajarapi (A, TA *) meaning, ‡ The man will play, or sport, with his religion, [like as the camel eats time after time of the tree; or, accord. to another explanation, like as the camel rubs, or scratches, himself against the tree:] or the meaning is, will strive and contend in dissensions or seditions. (TA.)
‡ He set himself against him to do evil, or mischief. (A, TA.)
‡ I. q. maArasahu; whence the saying, fulaAnN tamar-asa biAln-awaAYibi waAlxuSuwmaAti [app. meaning, ‡ Such a one strove against calamities and contentions, to gain the mastery]. (A.)
‡ He besmeared himself with it; namely, with perfume. (A, TA.)
† He wiped himself with it. (TA.)
See also what next follows {6}.

6. tmArswA [They laboured, strove, struggled, contended or conflicted, one with another, to prevail, overcome, gain the mastery, or effect an object:] they contended together, smiting one another, syn. taDaArabuwA, (A, Ḳ,) fiI AlHarobi in war: (A:) and [in like manner] you say also, tmr-swA↓ fI AlHrb, (Ḳ in art dEk,) or, of two men, tmr-sA fI AlHrb. (Ṣ in that art.)
tamaArasaA AlX-ar-a bayonahumaA [They two laboured, or strove, each with the other, to do evil, or mischief]. (Ṣ, art. kwH.)
8. Amtrs bihi: see 5.
Amtrsti AlOalosunu fiI AlxuSuwmaAti ‡ The tongues persisted in wranglings, or contentions, (Ṣ, M,) and assailed one another. (M, A.)

Amtrst bihi, occurring in a poem of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, is said of wild asses that had drawn near to the hunter as one that would rub himself against a thing: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, of a wild she-ass, and meaning, She began to strive with him to circumvent him and gain the mastery (jElt tkAr-uh wtuEaAlijuhu [as written in the TA; but I doubt not that tkAr-uh is a mistranscription for tukaAyiduhu, which is much like tEAljh in signification; and therefore I have thus rendered it]): or the meaning is, she had his arrow sticking fast in her. (TA.)
marasN: see marasapN, and 3.

hom.sense: marisN A strong man: (TA:) or a man (Ṣ) strong, or vehement, in labour or exertion: (Ṣ, M:) and strong, experienced in affairs, and who has laboured, or exerted himself, in the management, or transaction, thereof: pl. OamoraAsN. (TA.) You say also, Uin-ahu lamarisN HacirN, meaning, Verily he is strong in the waging of wars. (TA.)
humo EalaI marisK waAHidK They are alike in dispositions. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: marasapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or marasN↓, (A,) or both, the latter being sometimes used as a sing., (M,) A rope: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so called because of the strong twisting and adhering (tamar-us) of its strands, one upon another: (TA:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the former, marasN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and pl. pl., (M, Ḳ,) [i. e.] pl. of marasN, (Ṣ, A,*) OamoraAsN. (Ṣ, M, A * Ḳ.)
Also, the former, A dog's rope: pl. as above. (M.)
marosiynN The myrtle-tree; (Xajarapu AlMsi;) also called riyoHaAnu Alqubuwri: of the dial. of Egypt: but perhaps the n is a radical letter. (TA.)
bakorapN maruwsN A sheave of a pulley that is wont to have its rope stick fast between it and the qaEow [or cheek]. (Ṣ,* M,* Ḳ,* TA.)

mariysN Dates macerated, or steeped, or soaked, and mashed with the hand, (A,* Ḳ,) or moistened, and rubbed and pressed with the fingers till soft, (Mgh,) in water or in milk. (A, O, Mgh.) In the copies of the Ḳ, the words fiI AlmaMCi are omitted; and immediately after their place follows OawiAll-abanu [as though meaning, “or it signifies milk].” (TA.) Also, i. q. vriydN, q. v. (Ḳ.)

mariysiy-apN [in the modern Egyptian dial. mariysiI] The south wind, that comes from the direction of mariysN, which, says AḤn, is the lowest part of the country of the Nubians, next to the district of OusowaAn. (M.)
faHolN mar-aAsN A strong stallion: (Ḳ:) or a stallion strong, or vehement in labour or exertion. (M, Ṣgh.)
layolapN mar-aAsapN ‡ A night's journey in which is no remissness or languor; (M;) i. e., (M,) a hard and fatiguing and long night's journey. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)
maArasotaAnN A hospital for the sick: and arabicized word [from the Persian]: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ:) originally biymaArisotaAno: (Yaạḳoob, TA.)
Oamorasu [an imitative sequent and corroborative of Oaxorasu, as is shown in the M, art. mrs, see Oaxorasu.]
mutamar-asN [originally A place where one rubs or scratches himself against a thing. Hence, app., the saying,]

maA bifulaAnK mutamar-asN ‡ [Nothing can be done with, or got from, such a one]: said of him from whom the enemy can obtain no advantage: (A:) or of him who is hardy and strong, so that he who strives with him cannot withstand him, because he has striven against calamities and contentions: (TA:) and of the avaricious man, from whom he who is in want cannot obtain anything. (A, TA.)

1. mariDa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoraDu}, inf. n. maraDN and maroDN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter is a dial. form rarely used, (Mṣb,) He (a man, Ṣ, or an animal [of any kind], Msb) was, or became, [diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; i. e.] in the state termed maraDN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of this term below; (Ḳ;) as also AmrD↓, expl. by SaAra caA maraDK. (Ḳ, TA; but not in the CK.)
[Hence, mariDati AlEayonu ‡ The eye became languid; or languishing; or weak: (see mariyDN:) or, as Golius says, on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, was weak from much, and too much, looking.]
And mariDati All-ayolapu ‡ The night became dark. (Th, O.)
[The verb probably has several other tropical significations agreeable with explanations of maraDN and mariyDN which will be found below.]

hom.sense: 2. mr-Dhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. tamoriyDN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He took care of him in his sickness; (Sb, Ṣ, Mgh;) and treated him medically, to remove his disease; the measure faE-ala in this instance having a privative quality, though its quality is in most instances confirmative: (Sb:) or he took good care of him, namely a sick person: (Ḳ:) or he undertook, or managed, or superintended, the medical treatment of him. (Mṣb.)

mr-D fiI AlOamori, (IDrd, A,) [and mar-aDahu, (O, Ḳ voce DahoyaOa,)] inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ He fell short of doing what he ought to have done, or was remiss, in, or with respect to, the affair: (Ṣ, A:) or he did not exert himself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond what is usual, in it: (IDrd:) or he did it weakly, or feebly, (Ḳ,* TA,) not firmly or soundly: (TA:) as also mArD↓ fiyhi. (TA.) [See also 5.] And mr-D fulaAnN fiI HaAjatiI ‡ Such a one was deficient in activity in accomplishing my want. (TA.) And mr-D fiI kalaAmihi ‡ He was weak in his speech. (IDrd.)

[HakaAhu biSiygapi Alt-amoriyDi, probably a post-classical phrase, signifies † He mentioned it, or related it, in a manner implying that it was doubtful, or was a mere assertion; as when the word qiyla is used.]

entry.sense: 3. mArD fiI AlOamori: see 2.
maAraDotu raOoyiI fiyka ‡ I deceived myself, or endeavoured to deceive myself, respecting thee. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AmrD: see 1.
He had a bane, or murrain, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ,) or a disease, or distemper, (A, TA,) in his beasts, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, A,) or camels. (TA.)

AmrDhu He (God, Ṣ, Mṣb) rendered him mariyD [or diseased,, &c.]. (Sb, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say also, Oakala maA lamo yuwaAfiqohu faOamoraDahu (A, TA) [He ate what did not agree with him, and] it caused him to fall into AlmaraD [or disease,, &c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] UimoraADu AlOjofaAni (Ṣ, voce UisojaAdN) ‡ The lowering of the eyelids [in a languid, or languishing, manner: see mariyDN]. (TḲ, voce UisojaAdN.)
AmrDhu also signifies He found him to be mariyD [or diseased,, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

Also AmrD † He was near to being right in opinion, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) though not altogether right. (L.) In the Ḳ, this signification is wrongly assigned to AmrDhu. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely El-Ukeyshir El-Asadee, praising ʼAbd-el-Melik Ibn-Marwán, (TA.)
walekino taHota caAka AlX-ayobi HazomN
UicaA maA Zan-a OamoraDa Oawo OaSaAbaA
[But beneath that hoariness is good judgment: when he forms an opinion, he is nearly right, or he is right]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, AmrDhu fulaAnN ‡ Such a one was near to attaining the object of his [another's] want. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tmr-D ‡ He was weak, or feeble, in his affair. (A,* Ḳ, TA.) [It seems to be indicated in the A that tmArD↓ also has this signification; like as mArD in nearly the same sense is syn. with mr-D, q. v.: or perhaps tmArD signifies ‡ he feigned, or made a false show of, weakness, or feebleness, in his affair: it is said, in the A, to be used tropically as well as properly.]
6. tmArD He feigned, or made a false show of, maraD [or disease,, &c.] in himself. (Ṣ, A.*)
See also 5.
maroDN: see 1: and see what here next follows, in six places.

maraDN (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maroDN↓: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) see 1: i. q. suqomN [Disease, disorder, distemper, sickness, illness, or malady]; (IDrd, Ṣ;) which is the contr. of SiH-apN; and affects man and the camel [&c.]: (IDrd:) or a certain state foreign to the constitution or temperament, injurious to the intellect; whence it is known that pains and tumours are accidents arising therefrom: or, as IF says, that whereby a man passes beyond the limit of health or soundness or perfection or rectitude, whether it be disease (Eil-ap), or † hypocrisy, or † a falling short of doing what he ought to do in an affair: (Mṣb:)
or a dark and disordered state of the constitution or temperament, after a clear and right state thereof: (O, Ḳ:) or maroDN↓ is † [a disease] of the heart: (Ḳ:) Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says, maraDN and suqomN are said to be in the body and † in religion, like as SiH-apN is said to be in the body and in religion; and maroDN↓ is in the heart, applying to † everything whereby a man quits a state of soundness or perfection or rectitude in religion: (TA:) and Aṣ says, I recited to Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà [the words of the Ḳur, ii. 9, &c.,] fiI quluwbihimo maraDN and he said to me“ maroDN↓, O boy”: (AḤát, IDrd, Mṣb:) and maraDN, or this and maroDN↓ also, signifies † doubt: and † hypocrisy: (Ḳ:) and † weakness of belief: (TA:) and the former, (TA,) or ↓both, (Ḳ,) † languor, or languidness, or weakness: (Ḳ:) and † darkness (IAạr, Ḳ) in the heart: (IAạr:) and † defectiveness; deficiency; or imperfection; (IAạr, Ḳ;) which last is said by IAạr to be the primary signification: (TA:) or maraDN in the body is a languor, or languidness, or weakness, of the limbs, or members: and in the eye, † weakness of sight: and in the heart, † a flagging, or remissness, in respect of the truth: (Ibn-ʼArafeh:) or it properly signifies an accidental affection of the body, which puts it out of the right state proper to it, and necessarily occasions interruption, or infirmity, in its actions: and tropically, ‡ affections of the mind, which interrupt, or mar, its integrity; such as ‡ ignorance; and ‡ evil belief; and ‡ envy; and ‡ malevolence, or malice; and ‡ love of acts of disobedience; for these prevent from the attaining of excellences, or lead to the cessation of true eternal life: (Bḍ, ii. 9:) it is a gen. n.: (IDrd:) and the n. un. is maroDapN↓: (A, TA:) it is one of the inf. ns. which have pls., like XugolN and EaqolN; the pls. of these three being OamoraADN and OaXogaAlN and EuquwlN. (Sb.) fiI qulowbihimo maraDN, in the Ḳur, [ii. 9, &c.,] means † In their hearts is doubt: (AO:) or † doubt and hypocrisy. (TA.) And Al-aciI fiI qalobihi maraDN, in the same, [xxxiii. 32,] † In whose heart is darkness: or † flagging, or remissness, in respect of what is commanded and what is forbidden: or † love of adultery or fornication: (TA:) or hypocrisy. (A.)
mariDN: see mariyDN.
maroDapN [A single disease,, &c.]: see maraDN, near the end of the paragraph.
muraADN A disease [or blight or the like] which affects fruits, and destroys them. (Ḳ.)

mariyDN [Diseased; disordered; distempered; sick; or ill;] in the state termed maraDN (Mṣb, Ḳ) denoting that change of the constitution or temperament which is described in the explanation of the latter word above; (Ḳ;) as also mariDN↓ (Ḳ,) and maAriDN↓, (IB, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the first [and second] being from the verb of which the inf. n. is maraDN, and the third from that of which the inf. n. is maroDN, (Mṣb,) and mamoruwDN↓, and mutamar-iDN↓: (TA:) or, applied to a body, it signifies deficient in strength: (IAạr:) pl. miraADN (A, Ḳ, TA:) and maroDaI (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maraADaI (IDrd, Ḳ) and muraDaMCu; (TA;) or miraADN may be pl. of maAriDN (TA) [or of mariDN]. Accord. to Lḥ, you say, Eudo fulaAnN faUin-ahu mariyDN [Visit thou such a one, for he is sick]: and laA taOokulo hecaA AlT-aEaAma faUin-aka maAriDN↓ Uino Oakalotahu meaning tamoraDu [i. e. Eat not thou this food, for thou wilt be sick if thou eat it]. (TA.)
