[mariyDN has also several tropical significations.] You say also, EayonN mariyDapN ‡ An eye in which is languor, or languidness, or weakness: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. OaEoyanN miraADN, and maroDaI. (A, TA.) And UimoraOapN mariyDapu AlOaloHaAZi and mryDpu Aln-aZari † A woman weak in sight. (IDrd.) And qalobN mariyDN † A heart deficient in religion. (IAạr.) And XamosN mariyDapN ‡ A sun having a feeble light; (A, Ḳ;*) not clear, (Ṣ, TA,) and not beautiful. (TA.) And OaroDN mariyDapN ‡ A land in which are frequent seditions, or factions, or conflicts, or dissensions, (A, TA,) and wars, (A,) and slaughters: (TA:) or † in a weak condition: (Ḳ:) or straitened with its inhabitants: or † in which the wind is still, and the heat intense: or that causes disease; meaning † corrupt in its air. (TA.) And riyHN mariyDapN (A, Ḳ) ‡ A weak wind: (Ḳ:) or ‡ a still wind: or ‡ a wind intensely hot, and blowing feebly. (TA.) And layolapN mariyDapN ‡ A night in which no star shines; (A;) in which the sky is clouded, so that there is no light. (TA.) And raOoIN mariyDN (A, TA) ‡ An opinion deviating from what is right. (TA.)
maAriDN: see mariyDN, in two places.

mumoriDN A man having diseased camels: so in the following trad.: laA yuwridu mumoriDN EalaI muSiH-K [One having diseased camels shall not bring them to water immediately after one whose camels are in a healthy state]: the prohibition being not because of the transition of disease by contagion; but because sometimes disease may befall the healthy beasts, and it may come into the mind of the owner that that is from contagion. (TA.) [See also muSiH-N.]
mimoraADN A man frequently diseased or sick. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mamoruwDN see mariyDN.
mutamar-iDN: see mariyDN.
Also, ‡ A man weak, or feeble, in his affair. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. mariTa, aor. _a {yamoraTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maraTN, (Ṣ, Mgh,) He (a man, Ṣ) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (Ṣ;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears: (Ḳ, TA:) or most of his hair fell off. (Mgh.) [See also mrt and mrd].
maraTa, aor. _u {yamoruTu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. maroTN, (Ḳ,) He plucked out hair (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also mr-T↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tamoriyTN, (TA,) and feathers, and wool, from the body. (TA.)
2: see 1:
and 8.
mr-T Alv-awoba, inf. n. tamoriyTN, He shortened the sleeves of the garment, and made it into a miroT. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. mArThu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mumaAraTapN and miraATN, (TA,) He plucked out his hair, and scratched him with his nails. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. AmrT AlX-aEaru The hair attained to the time at which it should be plucked out; it was time for it to be plucked out. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AmrTt Aln-axolapu † The palm-tree dropped, or let fall, its ripe dates (Jm, Ḳ) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.)
AmrTt Aln-Aqapu waladahaA The she-camel cast her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (IDrd.)

entry.sense: 5. tmr-T AlX-aEaru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) quasi-pass. of mar-aTahu, (TA,) The hair fell off by degrees; became scattered; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also Uim-araTa↓, of the measure UifotaEala, [originally AmtrT,] (Ḳ,) or, [rather,] as in the TṢ, of the measure UinofaEala, [originally UinomaraTa,] quasi-pass. of maraTahu. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, tmr-Tt OawobaAru AlUibili The fur of the camels became scattered. (TA.) And Uim-araTato↓ qucacu Als-ahomi The feathers of the arrow fell off. (TA, from a trad.) And tmr-T Alc-iYobu The hair of the wolf fell off until little thereof remained upon him. (TA.) [See also mariTa.]
7. Uim-araTa [said in the TṢ to be of the measure AnfEl]: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: Uim-araTa [said in the Ḳ to be of the measure AftEl]: see 5, in two places.

entry.sense: miroTN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, of wool, or of xaz- [q. v.], (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or of linen, (TA,) and ‡ of hair-cloth, being tropically applied to one of this last description in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, (MF,) used as an UizaAr, [i. e. a waist-wrapper,] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) in former times, (Ṣ,) and sometimes a woman throws it over her head, (Mgh,) and wraps herself in it: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a green [perhaps meaning gray as is often the case] garment: or any garment that is not sewed: (TA:) [see 2:] pl. muruwTN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
muruTN: see OamoraTu, in two places.
miroTaAwaAni: see murayoTaMCu.
miraATN: see OamoraTu.
mariyTN: see OamoraTu.
muraATapN What falls, of hair, when it is plucked out; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) or when it is combed: (Ḳ,* TA:) or what is plucked out from the arm-pit. (Lḥ.)
murayoTaI The uvula. (Hr, Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: murayoTaMCu; so accord. to Aṣ (Ṣ, TA) and AO; accord. to El-Aḥmar, murayoTaI↓; but Aṣ disputed this with him, and overcame him; (TA;) [dim. of maroTaMCu, fem. of OamoraTu;] only used in the dim. form; (TA;) or it has the form of the dim. of maroTaMCu: (Mgh:) The part between the navel and the pubes: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or between the breast and the pubes: (Lth, Ḳ:) or a thin skin between the navel and the pubes, (IDrd, Ḳ,*) on the right and left, where the hair is plucked out, extending to the groins; (IDrd;) as also murayoTaI↓: (TA:) or a thin skin in the belly: (Mgh:) or [the dual] murayoTaAwaAni signifies the two sides of the pubes of a man, which have no hair upon them: (Mgh, TA;*) or the sing., (accord. to the Ḳ,) or the dual, (accord. to the TA,) two veins (Ḳ, TA) in the soft parts of the belly, (TA,) upon which he who cries out vehemently bears: (Ḳ, TA:) and (the dual, accord. to the TA) the bare part of the lower lip, over which is the sabalap (Ḳ, TA) next the nose: (TA:) and (the dual again, accord. to the TA) the parts on either side of the tuft of hair between the lower lip and the chin; as also miroTaAwaAni↓, with kesr. (Ḳ.)
The arm-pit. (Ḳ.)
A thing with which one ties, binds, or makes fast. (Hr, TA.)

entry.sense: maAriT: see OamoraATu, in two places.

OamoraTu A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; (Ṣ;) or upon his body, and eyebrow, and eye, in consequence of a weakness of this last, and of frequent shedding of tears; (Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, the word XEr is omitted in this explanation;]) or upon his body and breast; when all the hair has gone, he is said to be OamolaTu: (TA:) pl. muroTN and miraTapN; (Ḳ;) the former regular; the latter, extr., and thought by ISd to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) [The fem.] maroTaMCu signifies A woman having no hair upon her pubes and what is next to it. (IDrd.) You say also hiIa maroTaMCu AlHaAjibayoni She has little, or scanty, or thin, hair in the eyebrows: the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable. (TA.) And HaAjibN OamoraT An eyebrow of which most of the hair has fallen off. (Mgh.) See also OaToraTu.
A wolf of which some of the hair has fallen off; (Az, TA;) or whose hair has been plucked out. (Ḳ.)
And hence, as being likened thereto, (Az, TA,) ‡ A thief, or robber; (Aṣ, AA, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also EumoruwTN. (Aṣ, T.)

An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off: (Ṣ:) or an arrow having no feathers; (Ḳ;) as also mariyTN↓ and miraATN↓ (Ḳ) and maAriTN↓ (L, TA) and muruTN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the phrase muruTu AlqicaAci, in a verse [cited voce maSonaEN, wrongly asserted to be] of Lebeed, though we may read muroT, which is pl. of OamoraTu, as this may be correctly applied as an epithet to the sing. because of the pl. which follows it: (Ṣ:) the pl. of mArT↓ is mur-aTu and mawaAriTu; (L, TA;) and the pl. of muruTN↓ is OamoraATN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ḳ, TA) and miraATN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XajarapN maroTaMCu † A tree having no leaves upon it. (TA.)

hom.sense: naxolapN mumoriTN A palm-tree dropping, or letting fall, its ripe dates (Jm, Ḳ) in a juicy, or sappy, state. (Jm.) And mimoraATN↓ One that usually does so. (Jm, Ḳ.)
naAqapN mumoriTN A she-camel casting her fœtus in an imperfect state, with no hair upon it. (Jm.) And mimoraATN↓ One that usually does so. (Jm.) [See mumorijN.]

entry.sense: mimoraATN: see mumoriTN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. maz-a, [sec. pers. mazuzota aor. _u {yamozuzu},] inf. n. mazaAzapN, It had, or acquired, a taste between sweet and sour. (TA; but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is there mentioned.) AZ also mentions, as heard from the Kilábees, the saying, qaco maz-a XaraAbukumo OaqobaHa AlmazaAzapi, and Almuzuwzapi, as meaning, [Your beverage, or wine,] hath become very sour. (TA.)

maz-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yamozuzu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. maz-N, (Ṣ, TA,) [and accord. to one copy of the Ṣ, mazaAzapN, but this I regard as a mistake of a copyist,] He sucked it; i. q. maS-ahu. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. [He sipped:] see 10 in art. dbr.

R. Q. 1. mazomazahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mazomazapN, (Ṣ,) He put him, or it, in motion, or into a state of commotion; or shook him, or it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and moved him, or it, forwards and backwards: (Ṣ, TA:) or he put him, or it, in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion; or shook him, or it, violently: (Mgh, art. tr; and TA:) as, for instance, a drunken man, in order that he might recover from his intoxication. (Ṣ,* TA.) See also tarotarahu.

hom.sense: R. Q. 2. tamazomaza He ate, and drank, what had a taste between sweet and sour. (TA.)

He, or it, was, or became, put in motion, or in a state of commotion, or shaken, (Ḳ, TA,) and moved forwards and backwards: or in violent motion, or into a state of violent commotion, or shaken violently. (TA.)
tamazomaza liloqiyaAmi He raised himself, (Ḳ,) or put himself in motion, (TA,) to stand. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: maz-N: see its fem. maz-apN.

muz-N, applied to beverage, or wine, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a pomegranate, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) Having a taste between sweet and sour: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. with p {muz-apN}. (A.) AZ mentions its signifying Very sour beverage or wine; as heard from the Kilábees. (TA.) You say also xamorapN muz-apN, meaning, Wine, or a wine in which is a taste between sweet and sour; said to be from mixing unripe and ripe dates [in making it]: (TA:) or wine in which is a sour taste, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in which is no goodness. (Ṣ.) See also maz-apN.

hom.sense: qahowapN maz-apN Wine having a pleasant, delicious, or sweet, taste: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) so called because it bites, or burns, the tongue; (Ṣ, TA;) as also muz-N↓, (Ḳ, TA,) which, however, is [not an epithet but] a subst.: (TA:) or the former signifies lcycp AlmqTE [app. meaning having a pleasant sharpness, or acidity]: (so in the L, TA:) J says, that one should not say miz-apN↓, but this form is said to occur in one relation of a verse or El-Aạshà. (TA.) See also muz-N.

Also maz-apN A single suck or sucking. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. laA tuHar-imu Almaz-apu walaA Almz-ataAni [The sucking once will not render marriage unlawful, nor will the two suckings], meaning, in drawing milk from the breast. (Ṣ.) [See a similar saying voce EayofapN.]

entry.sense: miz-apN: see maz-apN.

1. mazaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamozuju}, (L Mṣb,) [not _a, as in the lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] inf. n. mazojN, (Ḳ, &c.,) He mixed, mingled, incorporated, or blended, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing with (bi) water; (Mṣb;) or beverage, or wine, (XaraAb,) with something else. (Ṣ.)
mazaja ‡ He exasperated, or irritated. (Ḳ.) mazajotuhu EalaI SaAHibihi I enraged him, and exasperated him, or irritated him, against his companion. (A.)

hom.sense: 2. mz-j, inf. n. tamoziyjN, He gave. (Ḳ.) Ex. mz-j Als-aAYila He gave the beggar something. (ISh.)
mz-j, inf. n. tamoziyjN, It (an ear of corn, Ḳ, and a grape, TA,) became changed in colour from green to yellow. (T, Ḳ.)
3. mAzjhu, inf. n. mumaAzajapN, It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, intermingled, or became incorporated or blended, with it; as some does with water. (TA.)
mAzjhu, ‡ He contended with him, or disputed with him, for glory, or honour, or glorious or honourable qualities, and the like. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tmAzjA and AmtzjA↓ They two mixed, or mingled, or became mixed or mingled, each with the other. (TA.)
8. Amtzj It was, or became, mixed with (bi) another thing. (TA.) See 6.
XaraAbN mazojN i. q. mamozuwjN↓, Mixed mine, or beverage. (TA.)
See mizojN.
mizoju XaIoCK, and mizaAjuhu↓, What is mixed, or mingled, with a thing; its admixture. (TA.)
mizaAju↓ AlX-araAbi What is mixed with mine, or a beverage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) mizaAju↓ Alxamori kaAfuwrN [see Ḳur, lxxvi., 5,] The odour, not the taste, of the wine is [like] camphor. (TA.)

mizaAju↓ Albadani [The constitution, or temperament, of the body;] the aggregate natural constituents (TabaAYiEu) with which the body is composed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. the four humours of the body; namely, black bile [Als-awodaMCu], yellow bile [AlS-aforaMCu], (Almir-ataAni), phlegm (Albalogamu), and blood (Ald-amu). (TA) Pl. OamozijapN. (Mṣb.) You say, huwa SaHiyHu AlmizaAji↓, and faAsiduhu, He is of sound, and of unsound, constitution, or temperament: meaning the humours of the body. And Oamozijapu Aln-isaMCi muxotalifapN The constitutions, or temperaments, of women are discordant, or various. (A.)

mizojN (Aṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and mazojN↓, (Az, Ṣ, &c.,) or the latter is erroneous, or a word of weak authority, (Ḳ,) Honey: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or honey in the comb; syn. XahodN: (T:) so called because every sweet beverage is mixed with it. (AḤn.)
Also, Water with which wine is mixed. (TA.)
mizaAjN: see mizojN.
mawozajN A boot, (Ḳ,) worn by women: (A:) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the Persian muwzaho: (Ṣ:) pl. mawaAzijapN (because it is a foreign word, Ṣ) and mawaAziju. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maziyjN: see mizojN.
mamozuwjN: see mazojN.
mumaz-ijN: see maz-aAjN.
TaboEu EuTaArida mutamaz-ijN [The nature of the planet Mercury is various]. (A.)

1. mazaHa, aor. _a {yamozaHu}, inf. n. mazoHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and quasi-inf. n. muzaAHN and muzAHapN, (Ḳ,) [the latter like its syn. duEaAbapN,] but Fei says that this last is mazaAHapN, (TA,) [and he mentions it as an inf. n.,] He jested or joked; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) contr. of jad-a [which signifies “he was serious, or in earnest””]: (M:) or he talked or behaved in a free and easy manner, with the view of blandishing and conciliating, without annoying; so that it excludes the meaning of mocking or ridiculing or deriding. (MF.)
3. mAzHhu, inf. n. mizaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mumaAzaHapN, (Ḳ,) He jested, or joked, with him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
6. tamaAzaHaA They two jested, or joked, one with the other. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mazoHapN A jest, or joke; a single act of jesting, or joking. (Mṣb.)
muzaAHN and muzaAHapN, substs., A jesting, or joking. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 1.]
rajulN maz-aAHN A man who is a great jester, or joker. (A.)
1. mazada, &c.: see art. mSd.

mizorN A certain kind of beverage, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or nbyc, (A, Ḳ,) made of curap [a kind of millet]: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) [it is now called in Egypt and Nubia buwzha and buwZh: see De Sacy's “Abdallatif,” pp. 324 and 572; and my “Modern Egyptians,” vol. i. ch. iii.:] and of barley: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or of wheat: (Mgh:) and of [other] grains: (TA:) AʼObeyd mentions that the Ibn-ʼOmar explains the various kinds of nabiyc thus: bitoEN is nbyc of honey: and jiEapN is nbyc of barley: and mizorN, of curap: and sakarN, of dried dates: and xamorN, of grapes: and sukurokapN is the wine of the Abyssinians; Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree says that it is of curap, and it is also called suquroqaEN, app. arabicized from sukurokap, which is Abyssinian: (Ṣ:) mizorN and sukurokahN are the same.
[See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. mas-ahu, (A, Mgh,) first pers. masisotuhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for which they sometimes say misotuhu, rejecting the first s, (Sb,* Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) and transferring the kesreh thereof to the m (Sb,* Ṣ, M,*) contr. to general rule, (Sb, M,) and some do not transfer the kesreh, but leave the m with its fethah, [saying masotuhu,] like Zilotumo and Zalotumo for Zalilotumo, an irregular contraction, (Ṣ,) aor. yamas-uhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and yamosasohu when mejzoom, accord. to rule,] inf. n. mas-N (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and masiysN, (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and mis-iysaI; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) and [mas-ahu,] first pers. masasotuhu; aor. yamus-uhu, (AO, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mas-N; (Mṣb;) the former of which two verbs is the more chaste; (Ṣ, TA;) He touched it, or felt it, [generally the former,] syn. lamasahu, (M, A, Ḳ,) with his hand: (TA: as from the Ḳ [but wanting in a MṢ copy of the Ḳ and in the CK:]) or he put his hand to it without the intervention of anything: (Mṣb:) or mas-N is like lamosN; excepting that the latter is [sometimes] used to signify the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing, even though it be not found; whereas the former is [only] said of that [action] with which is perception by the sense of lms: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [see also lamasahu:] and [in like manner you say,] maAs-a AlX-aIoCu AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. mumaAs-apN and misaAsN, (M, A,*) meaning, the thing met [or touched] the thing with its substance. (M.)

[Hence,] mas-ahaA, (M, A, Mṣb,) first pers. masisotuhaA, aor. yamas-uhaA, (Mṣb,) inf. n. mas-N and masiysN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) ‡ Inivit eam; scil. mulierem; (M, A, Mṣb;) as also maAs-ahaA↓, (M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. mumaAs-apN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and misaAsN: (Mṣb:) the former is used in this sense in several places in the Ḳur, and is said by some to be preferable to the latter: (TA:) and tamaAs-N is also used metonymically for [the coming together, in the sense of] mubaADaEapN, as well as mumaAs-apN. (Ṣ.)
mas-a AlmaMCu Aljasada, inf. n. mas-N, ‡ The water wetted the body. (Mṣb.)
mas-a also signifies ‡ He, or it, struck, or smote; because striking, or smiting, like touching, is with the hand. (TA.) You say, mas-ahu biAls-awoTi ‡ [He struck him with the whip]. (A.)

And it is said of anything annoying or hurtful that befals a man. Thus in the Ḳur, [ii. 74, and iii. 23,] lano tamas-anaA Aln-aAru ‡ [The fire of hell will not smite us; or here it may be rendered touch us]. And [ii. 210,] mas-atohumu AlbaOosaMCu [Distress, or misfortune, smote, or afflicted, or befell, them]. And in other instances; all which are similar to the saying in the same, cuwquwA mas-a saqara. (TA.) [See mas-N below.] You say also, mas-ahu AlmaraDu ‡ [Sickness smote him, or befell him]: and mas-ahu AlEacaAbu ‡ [Punishment befell him]: and mas-ahu Alkibaru ‡ [Old age came upon him]. (A.) And mas-atohu Aljin-u ‡ [lit. The jinn, or genii touched him; meaning, affected him with madness, or insanity]: (TA:) [whence,] mus-a, [in the TA, mus-a bihi, app. meaning, from what immediately precedes, mus-a biAljunuwni, inf. n. mas-N,] He was, or became, [touched with madness, or insanity: or] mad, or insane: (Ḳ:) as though the jinn had touched him. (TA.) And mas-ahu biEacaAbK ‡ He punished him. (TA, from a trad.)

[Hence, app.,] mas-ato Uilayohi AlHaAjapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. [mas-N and] masiysN, (TA,) † [which seems to signify either The want of him, or it, was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing; or the want was difficult of accomplishment, or distressing, to him]. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [In both these lexicons, the meaning is left to be inferred only from the fact that this phrase immediately follows the explanation of HaAjapN maAs-apN, q. v.])

[mas-a is also said of what is good, as well as of what is evil; as in the following instance:] mas-atohu mawaAs-u Alxayori waAlX-ar-i ‡ [The haps of good fortune, and of evil,] happened to him, or betided him. (TA.)
[As touching implies proximity,] mas-ato bika raHimu fulaAnK signifies ‡ The relationship of such a one is near to you. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
And as mas-a originally signifies “he touched or felt with the hand,” it is used metaphorically as meaning ‡ He took a thing; as, for instance, (in a trad.,) water from a miyDaOap. (TA.)
mas-a is made doubly trans. by means of the prep. bi prefixed to the second objective complement. (Mṣb.) See 4, in two places.

entry.sense: 3: see 1, in two places: and see laA masaAsi.
4. Ums-hu AlX-aIoCa He made him, or caused him, to touch the thing: (Ṣ,* IJ, M, A:*) he enabled him to touch it. (Mgh.)

Oamas-a Aljasada maMCF, and mas-a↓ Aljasada bimaMCK, ‡ He wetted the body with water; or caused water to wet the body. (Mṣb.) And Oamas-a wajohahu AlT-iyba ‡ He smeared his face with the perfume. (Mgh.) And Oamas-atohu EaAriDayohaA, and mas-atohu↓ biEaAriDayohaA, ‡ She smeared the sides of her cheeks with it; namely, perfume. (Mgh.)
Oamas-ahu XakowaI ‡ He made a complaint to him. (M, TA.)
6. tmAs-A They (two bodies) touched each other; were, or became, in contact. (M, A,* Ḳ,*)
Hence, (Ḳ,) ‡ They two came together in the way of mubaADaEap: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:*) in this sense the verb is used in the Ḳur, lviii. 4 and 5. (Ṣ, TA.) See also mas-ahaA.
mas-N: see 1.

It is used to denote [the first sensible effect of] anything annoying or hurtful that befalls a man. (TA.) Thus in the Ḳur, [liv. 48,] (TA,) cuwquwA mas-a saqara ‡ Taste ye the first effect upon you of the fire of hell: (Ḳ, TA:) or the stroke thereof: (Jel:) or the heat and pain thereof. (Bḍ.) In like manner you say, (Ḳ,) wajada mas-a AlHum-aI (M, Ḳ) ‡ He felt the commencement, or first touch, [or access,] of fever, before its taking him forcibly, and becoming apparent. (M, L.) And lamo yajido mas-FA mina Aln-aSabi ‡ He did not feel the first sensation of fatigue. (TA, from a trad.) [And hence,] bihi mas-N mina Aljunuwni ‡ [In him is a touch, or stroke, of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession]: (Ṣ, TA:) and mas-N, alone, signifies madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession: (M, A,* Mgh, Ḳ:) as in the Ḳur, ii. 276: (TA:) and you say bihi mas-N in him is madness,, &c.: (A,* Mgh:) for they assert that the devil touches one and his intellect in consequence becomes confused. (Mgh.)

You say also, huwa Hasanu Almas-i fiI maAlihi ‡ He has the impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, or sheep, or goats: and raOayotu lahu mas-FA fiI maAlihi ‡ I saw him to have an impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels,, &c.: like as you say UiSobaEFA. (A, TA.)

laA masaAsi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like qaTaAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because altered from the inf. n. mas-N, (Ṣ,) signifies [properly There shall be no touching: or] touch not thou: (Ḳ:) or touch not thou me: (M:) and some read thus in the Ḳur, [xx. 97:] (M, Ḳ:) it is a saying of the Arabs: (Ṣ:) and sometimes one says masaAsi [alone], in the sense of an imperative, [affirmatively,] like daraAki and nazaAli: (Ḳ:) but laA misaAsa↓, in the Ḳur, [ubi supra,] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) accord. to the reading of others, (M,) signifies There shall be no mutual touching: (M:) or I will not touch nor will I be touched. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
laA misaAsa: see laA masaAsi.

masuwsN ‡ Water that is reached by the hands; or taken with the extended hands: (M, Ḳ,* TA:) in the Ḳ, naAlatohu is put by mistake for tanaAwalatohu [which is the reading in the M]: (TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of a pass. part. n.: (M:) or, [in the Ḳ and,] ‡ wholesome water, (A, TA,) that removes thirst, or the heat of thirst, as soon as it touches it: (M, A,* Ḳ,* TA:) accord. to which explanation, it has the signification of an act. part. n.: (M:) and † anything that cures thirst, or the heat of thirst: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or, [in the Ḳ, and,] † water between sweet and salt: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, [in the Ḳ and,] † sweet and clear water: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) and † salt, or bitter and thick and undrinkable, water, that burns everything by its saltness. (M.) You say also riyqapN masuwsN ‡ Some saliva that takes away thirst. (IAạr, M.) And kalaON masuwsN † Herbage that has a fattening and beneficial effect upon the animals that pasture on it. (AḤn, M.)
Also, i. q. faAdozahorN [The bezoar-stone]: (Ḳ:) or tiroyaAqN [an antidote against poison]: (M:) or both these words by which it is explained mean the same thing. (TA.)
mas-aAsapN: see maAs-ahN.
HaAjapN maAs-apN † A want difficult of accomplishment; or pressing; syn. muhimopN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
raHimN maAs-apN ‡ Near relationship; (Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ;) as also mas-aAsapN↓. (TA.)
[Also, as a subst., sing. of mawaAs-N, of which an ex. has been given above, (see 1,) signifying Haps of good fortune, and of evil.]
mamosuwsN A man in whom is a touch, or stroke, (mas-N,) of madness, insanity, or diabolical possession: (Ṣ, TA:) or mad, insane, or possessed by a devil. (AA, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. masaOa AlT-ariyqa He went along the middle of the road; (Ḳ;) or the hard and elevated part (maton) of the road. (TA.)
masaOa He was slow, or tardy. (Ḳ.)
masaOa Haq-ahu He delayed giving him his due. (Ḳ, TA.)
masaOa Alqidora He stilled, or allayed, the boiling of the pot. (Ḳ.)
masaOahu biAlqawoli He soothed, or softened, him by words. (Ḳ.)
masaOa He beguiled, or deceived. (Ḳ.)
masaOa EalaI XaIoCK, (Ḳ,) inf. n. masoCN, (TA,) He became accustomed, or inured to a thing. (Ḳ.)
masaOa bayonahumo and AmsO↓, He excited discord between them. (Ḳ, TA.)
masaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamosaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. masoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and musuwCN, (Ḳ,) He was hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one said, or did to him. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
5. tms-O It (a garment) rent, or became ragged and worn out. (IB, Ḳ.)
masoCN The middle of a road. (Ḳ.) [See 1, and see misoHN.]

maAsiYN Hard, or impudent, and rude; not caring for what one says or does to him. (AZ, Ṣ.) Perhaps maAsK is from this: (see art. msI:) or perhaps it is formed by transposition from maAYisN: see art. mys. (AM.)

hom.sense: 1. masaHa XayoYFA, aor. _a {yamosaHu}, inf. n. masoHN; and ms-Hhu↓, inf. n tamosiyHN; He wiped a thing that was wet or dirty, with his hand, or passed his hand over it to remove the wet or dirt that was upon it: (L:) masoHN and tamosiyHN and tamas-uHN↓ signifying the passing the hand over a thing that is flowing [with water or the like], or dirtied, soiled, or polluted, to remove the fluid or dirt, or soil or pollution; (L, Ḳ;) as when one wipes his head with his hand to remove water; and his forehead, to remove sweat. (L.) [It often signifies He stroked a thing with his hand; as, for instance, the Black Stone of the Kaabeh; see below.]
masaHa raOosahu mina AlmaMCi; and jabiynahu Alr-aXaHi; He wiped his head with his hand to remove the water that was upon it; and his forehead to remove the sweat. (L.)

masaHa biraOosihi (Ṣ) He wiped with his hand, or passed his hand closely over, his head, or a part thereof, without making any water to flow upon it: so in the Ḳur, v. 8; where it is said, faQgosiluwA wujuwhakumo waOayodiyakumo UilaI QlomaraAfiqi waQmosaHuwA biruWuwsikumo waOarojulakumo UilaI QlokaEobayoni: here Oarojulakumo is in the acc. case as an adjunct to Aydykm; [i.e., as a third objective complement to the verb AgslwA; not as an adjunct to rWwskm;] but some read Oarojulikumo, putting it in the gen. case because of its proximity to rWwskm; (Jel;) [in like manner as xaribK is put in the gen. case in the phrase hecaA juHoru Dab-K xaribK, an ex. given by many of the grammarians, showing that this is allowable in prose,] notwithstanding that it is said, by Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ the grammarian, that the putting a noun in the gen. case because of its proximity to a preceding noun in that case is not allowable except in poetry, when necessity requires it: (L:) the head, which is wiped, is mentioned between the arms and the feet, which are washed, to show the order which is to be observed in the purification. (Jel.) But masaHa signifies both he wiped with the hand, and also he washed: so says IAth: (L:) and AZ and IḲt say the like: (Mṣb:) you say masaHotu yadaI-a bAlmaMCi, meaning I washed my hands with water. (AZ, Mṣb.)
masaHa XayoYFA biAlmaMCi He wiped a thing with his hand wetted with water; passed his hand, wetted with water, over a thing. (Mṣb.)
masaHa Albayot He compassed the House [of God, i.e. the Kaabeh: because he who does so passes his hand over the corner in which is the Black Stone]. (L.)
masaHa Qll-ehu Eanoka maA bika May God remove that which is in thee! (L;) or, wash and cleanse thee from thy sins! (TA, art. mSH.) A prayer for a sick person. (L, from a trad.)
masaHahu He anointed him or it with oil. (A.)
musiHa biAlkarami, inf. n. masoHN, ‡ He was characterized by somewhat, or by some sign or mark, of nobility. (L.) [See masoHapN.]
masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, He combed and dressed hair; syn. maXaTa. (Ḳ.)
masoHu All-uHiIa [The stroking of the beards] was a sign of reconciliation. (Ṣ, O, in art. Eq: see Eaqu biAls-ahomi.)

masaHahu, or masaHahu biAlmaEoruwfi, i. e. bAlmErwf mina Alqawoli, (L,) inf. n. masoHN; (L, Ḳ;) and ms-Hhu↓, (L,) inf. n. tamosiyHN; (L, Ḳ;) He spoke to him good words, deceiving, or beguiling, him therein, (L, Ḳ,) and giving him nothing. (L.)
fulaAnN yamosaHu raOosa zayodK ‡ Such a one beguiles, or deceives, Zeyd. (A.) [See also 3.]
masaHa, inf. n. masoHN and tamosaAHN He lied; uttered what was false. (Ḳ.)
masaHa fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. musuwHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:*) as also maSaHa. (TA.)
masaHahumo ‡ He passed lightly by them, or brushed by them, without remaining by them. (L.)

masiHa, [aor. _a {yamosaHu},] inf. n. masaHN, The inner sides of his (a man's, Ṣ) thighs rubbed together, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or he had the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment. (L, Ḳ.)

masaHa AlUibila, inf. n. masoHN ‡ He made the camels to journey all the day long: and he made the backs of the camels to be wounded by the saddles, and emaciated them; as also mas-aHahaA↓, inf. n. tamosiyHN: (Ḳ:) and in the latter sense you say masaHa Aln-aAqapa, and ms-HhA↓. (TA.)
masaHati AlUibilu yawomahaA ‡ The camels journeyed all the day. (Ṣ.) masaHati AlUibilu AlOaroDa yawomahaA daOobFA ‡ The camels journeyed all the day laboriously. (TA.)
masaHa, (Ṣ,) inf. n. masoHN (Ḳ) and misaAHapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) ‡ He measured land. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

masaHa, inf. n. masoHN, ‡ He cut, or severed: and he struck, or smote: (Ḳ:) he severed the neck, and the arm. (TA.) masaHa Eunuqahu and biEunuqihin, aor. _a {yamosaHu}, inf. n. masoHN, He smote his neck: or, as some say, severed it, or cut it through. Agreeably with both these significations masoHFA is rendered in the Ḳur, xxxviii. 32: some say that what is here meant is the wiping with the hand wetted with water: accord. to IAth, Solomon is here said to have smitten the necks and hock-tendons of the horses. (L.) [See art. Tfq.] masaHahu biAls-ayofi He smote him with the sword: (L:) and he cut him with the sword: (Ṣ, L:) or masaHahu signifies he struck him gently with a staff, or stick, and with a sword. (TA in art. dhn.)
See 8.
Also masaHahumo He slew them. (L.)
masaHahu, (inf. n. masoHN, Ḳ,) He (God) created him blessed, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) and goodly: (AHeyth:)
and, contr., created him accursed, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) and foul, or ugly. (AHeyth.)
masaHa, (Ṣ,) inf. n. masoHN, (Ḳ,) ‡ Inivit feminam. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in four places.
3. mAsHhu ‡ He took him by the hand; applied the palm of his hand to the palm of the other's hand. (TA.)
‡ He made a compact, or covenant, with him. (TA.)

maAsaHaA ‡ They used blandishing, soothing, or wheedling, words, one to the other, deceiving thereby; (Ḳ;) their hearts not being sincere. (TA.) You say gaDiba famaAsaHotuhu Hat-aI laAna ‡ He was angry, and I coaxed, or wheedled, him until he became gentle, or mild. (TA.) [See also 1.]
5. tms-H biAlmaMCi He washed himself with water. (A, Z.)
tms-H ‡ He performed the ablution called AlwuDuwoC. (IAth.)
tms-H biAlOaroDi (Ṣ, L) ‡ He performed the action termed Alt-ayam-um: or he made his forehead to touch the ground in prostration, without anything intervening. (L.)

fulaAnN yutamas-aHu bivawobihi ‡ Such a one has his garment passed over men's persons as a means of their advancing themselves in the favour of God: (L:) [i.e., he is a holy man, from the touch of whose garment a blessing is derived: see St. Matthew's Gospel, ix., 20 and 21]. fulaAnN yutamas-aHu bihi ‡ Such a one is a person by means of whom one looks for a blessing (butabar-aku bihi,) by reason of his excellence, (Ḳ,) and his devotion; (TA;) as though one advanced himself in the favour of God by approaching him. (L.) [See also an ex. voce rukonN.]

fulaAnN yatamas-aHu ‡ Such a one has nothing with him, or in his possession; as though he wiped his arms with his hands: (Ḳ:) [for it is a custom of the Arabs to do thus as an indication of having nothing.]
tms-H He wiped himself, mino XaIoCK to remove a thing, and biXaIoCK, with a thing. (L.) [See also 1.]

6. tamaAsaHaA ‡ They acted in a friendly or sincere manner, one to the other; syn. taSaAdaqaA: or they made a contract, or bargain, one with the other, and each struck the palm of the other's hand with the palm of his own hand [to confirm it], (Ḳ,) and swore to the other. (TA.)
tamaAsaHuwA ‡ They took one another by the hand. (TA.)

masoHN i. q. balaAsN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i.e., A garment of thick, or coarse, hair-cloth: so in the T: and a piece of such stuff as is spread in a house or tent: (TA:) a blAs such as is worn by monks: (Mgh:) a kisaMC of hair-cloth: (L:) an old and worn-out garment: (Kull:) pl. OamosaAHN and musuwHN; (Ṣ;) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter a pl. of mult. (L.)
misoHN The main part, and middle, of a road; syn. jaAd-apN: (Ḳ:) pl. OamosaAHN (TA) and musuwHN. (Ḳ.)
masaHN, a subst., Paucity of flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or smallness of the buttocks, and their sticking together; or paucity of flesh in the thighs; syn. rasaHN. (L.)

EalaI fulaAnK masoHapN mino jamaAlK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or misoHapN↓, (L,) ‡ Upon such a one there appears somewhat of beauty; (L, Ḳ;) or, some sign, or mark, or trait, of beauty: (L:) and msHpu karamK, some sign, or mark, trait, or indication, of nobility; and the like: a mode of expression said, by Sh, to be used only in praise; so that you do not say Ealayohi msHpu quboHK: (L:) but you say also bihi msHpN mino huzaAlK in him is somewhat, or some sign, or mark, of leanness; (L, Ḳ;) which is a phrase of the Arabs mentioned by Az. (L.)
masoHapN in the cheek of a horse: see SifaAHN.
misoHapN: see masoHapN.

hom.sense: masiyHN Anointed: wiped over with some such thing as oil. (Ḳ.)
A king. (El-ʼEynee.)

AlmasiyHu [The Messiah, the Christ, the Anointed,] Jesus, on whom be peace! (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [correctly] an arabicized word, [from the Hebrew,] originally maXiyHaA, with X: (T, Mṣb:) but the learned differ as to this word, whether it be Arabic or arabicized: F relates, in the Ḳ, his having mentioned, in his Expos. of the Mesháriḳ el-Anwár, fifty opinions respecting the derivation of it; and in another work he has made the number fifty-six. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or AlmasiyHu Alkac-aAbu, (Ṣ,) or Almis-iyHu↓, (Ḳ,) [The Messiah, or Christ, surnamed the Great Liar; the False Christ; Antichrist; also called] EdDejjál, Ald-aj-aAlu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is not allowable, however, to apply to him the appellation AlmasiyHu without restriction; wherefore one says AlmasiyHu Ald-aj-aAlu [or Alkac-aAbu]; (TA;) [unless in a case like the following, in which] a poet says
UicaA AlmasiyHu yaqotulu AlmasiyHa
[When the true Messiah shall slay the false Messiah] (Mṣb.) [Many opinions respecting the derivation of the appellation thus applied are also mentioned by various authors.]
masiyHN Sweat: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because it is wiped off (yumosaHu) when it pours forth. (T.)
masiyHN ‡ A dirhem [or silver coin] of which the impression is obliterated; syn. OaTolasu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) having no impression. (Mṣb.)
masiyHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and masiyHapN↓ (TA) A piece of silver. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
masiyHN. ‡ i. q. mamosuwHu Alwajohi, (Ḳ,) i.e., A man having one side of his face plain, without eye or eyebrow: said to apply in this sense to Ed-Dejjál, among others. (IF, L.)
One-eyed. (Az.) [See also OamosaHu.]

masiyHN A rough napkin, or kerchief, with which one wipes himself: (L, Ḳ:) so called because the face is wiped with it, or because it retains the dirt. (TA.) [A dusting-cloth, or dish-clout, or the like, is now called mimosaHapN↓.]
masiyHN Beautiful in the face. (TA.)
masiyHN One who journeys or goes about much for the sake of devotion, or as a devotee; as also mis-iyHN↓ (Ḳ,) and OamosaHu↓, (TA,) the fem. of which is masoHaMCu. (Ḳ, TA.) See mas-aAHN.
masiyHN Erring greatly. (TA.)
masiyHN A great liar; one who lies much; as also maAsiHN↓ and mimosaHN↓ (Ḳ) and timosaHN↓ (Lḥ, Ḳ) and OamosaHu↓, (TA,) the fem. of which last is masoHaMCu. (Ḳ, TA.) See maAsiHN.
masiyHN Very veracious; syn. Sid-iyqN: (Ḳ, L, TA: in the CK SadiyqN:) a meaning unknown to many of the lexicologists, and probably obsolete in their time. (L.)
masiyHN Created blessed, and goodly; (L;) created (mamosuwHN) with blessing, or prosperity: (Ḳ:)
and, contr., created accursed, and foul, or ugly; (L;) created with unfortunateness. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: misaAHapN ‡ Mensuration of land. (Mṣb.) [See also 1.]
See also takosiyrN.

hom.sense: masiyHapN i. q. cuWaAbapN, [a portion, or lock, of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back; or the hair of the fore part of the head; the hair over the forehead; or the part whence that hair grows; or a plait of hair hanging down;, &c.]: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or hair that is left without its being dressed with oil or anything else: or that part of a man's head that is between the ear and the eyebrow, rising to the part below that where the sutures of the scull unite: or that part of the side of the hair upon which a man puts his hand, next to his ear: or the hair of each side of the head: pl. masaAYiHu: or msAYH signifies the place which a man wipes with his hand: or, accord. to Aṣ, the hair: or, accord. to Sh, the hair which one wipes with his hand, upon his cheek and his head. (L.)
See masiyHN.
masiyHapN A bow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an excellent bow: (L.) pl. masaAYHu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mas-aAHN ‡ A measurer of land; (TA;) as also masiyHN↓. (L.)
mis-iyHN and Almis-iyHu: see masiyHN.

bihi maAsiHN He (a camel) has a fretting of the edge of the callosity upon his breast, produced by his elbow, without making it bleed: if he make it bleed, you say bihi HaAz-N: (Ṣ, L:) and he has a chafing of his arm-pit produced by his elbow, but not violent, by reason of the disease called DaAgiT. (L.)
See masiyHN.
maAsiHN and masiyHN↓ A great slayer; one who slays much, or many. (Az, L.)
maAsiHapN A woman who combs and dresses hair; syn. maAXiTapN. (Ṣ.)
OamosaHu A flat place, with small pebbles, and without plants, or herbage. (Ṣ.)

masoHaMCu A plain tract of land, with small pebbles, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and without plants, or herbage: (Ṣ:) [ex.] mararotu bixariyqK mina AlOaroDi biyona masoHaAwayoni [I passed by a depressed tract of land containing herbage between two plain tracts containing small pebbles and without herbage]: (Fr, Ṣ:) or a piece of flat ground, bare, abounding with pebbles, containing no trees nor herbage, rugged, somewhat hard, like a flat place in which camels, &c. are confined, or in which dates are dried, not what is termed quf-, nor what is termed saholap: (ISh:) pl. masaAHK and masaAHI [i. e. masaAHaI or masaAHiI-u]; pl. forms proper to substs.; as it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.)
Also masoHMCu Red land. (Ḳ.)

masoHaMCu A woman having little flesh in her posteriors and thighs; or foul, ugly, or unseemly; syn. rasoHaMCu. (Ṣ.) [In the Ḳ., AlOaroDu Alr-asoHaMCu, given as an explanation of AlmasoHaMCu, is an evident mistake for AlmaroOapu Alr-asoHaMCu, as observed by Freytag.]

OamosaHu, or OamosaHu Alqadami, A man having a flat sole to his foot, without any hollow: (L:) fem. masoHaMCu: (L, Ḳ:) and masiyHN↓, or masiyHu↓ Alqadamayoni, signifies the same: and also having smooth and soft feet, without fissures or chaps, so that they repel water when it falls upon them. (L.)
Also masoHaMCu, (Ḳ,) or msHMCu Alv-adoIi, (L,) A woman whose breast has no bulk. (L, Ḳ.)

Also masoHaMCu A one-eyed woman: [see also masiyHN:] and such as is termed bixoqaMCu, whose eye is not mulaw-azap: so in [most of] the copies of the Ḳ., but in some, bil-aworap: (TA:) [the meaning seems to be whose eye has no crystalline humour].
OamosaHu A man having little flesh in his posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks sticking together; syn. ArsH: fem. masoHaMCu: pl. musoHN. (L.)

OamosaHa A man (Ṣ) having the inner sides of his thighs rubbing together (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) so as to become sore and chapped: (L:) or having the inner side of his knee inflamed by the roughness of his garment: (L, Ḳ:) fem. masoHaMCu, and pl. musoHN. (L.)

gaArapN masoHaMCu ‡ A hostile attack, or incursion, by a troop of horse, in which the attacking party passes lightly by the party attacked, or brushes by them, without remaining by them. (L, from a trad.)
See masiyHN.
OamosaH [app. used as a subst., and therefore with, or without, tenween,] A flat tract of land: pl. OamaAsiHu. (TA.)
A smooth desert; or smooth waterless desert. (Lth.)
OumosuwHN Any long piece of wood in a ship: (Ḳ:) pl. OamaAsiyHN. (TA.)
mimosaHN and mimosaHapN: see masiyHN.
mamosuwHu AlOaloyatayoni Having the buttocks cleaving to the bone, and small. (L.)
mamosuwHN A eunuch whose testicles have been extirpated. (TA.)
EaDudN mamosuwHapN An arm, from the shoulder to the elbow, having little flesh. (TA.)
mamosuwHu A thing foul, or ugly, and unfortunate, and changed from its proper form, or make. (TA.) [See art. msx.]
timosaHN A dissembler; a deceiver; (Ḳ;) one who blandishes, soothes, or wheedles, one with his words, and deceives him. (TA.)

timosaHN An audacious, or insolent, and wicked, or corrupt, man: (L, Ḳ:) or a great liar, who, if asked, will not tell thee truly whence he comes; who lies to thee even as to the place whence he comes. (L.) [See also masiyHN.]
See timosaAHN.

timosaAHN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and timosaHN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter app. a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) [The crocodile]; a well-known aquatic animal, (Ṣ,) a creature like the tortoise, of great size, found in the Nile of Egypt and in the river Mihrán, (Ḳ,) which is the river of Es-Sind; (TA;) or [rather] resembling the waral about five cubits long, and less; that seizes men and oxen, and dives into the water with them and devours them: pl. of the former tamaAsiyHN, and of the latter tamaAsiHu. (Mṣb.)

1. masaxahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamosaxu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. masoxN, (Ṣ,) He transformed him, or metamorphosed him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. masaxahu Qll-ehu qirodFA God transformed him into an ape. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See Ḳur, xxxvi. 67.]

masaxa XiEorFA He took and transformed poetry; accord. to the most common usage, by the substitution of what is synonymous with the original, wholly or partly; but sometimes by altering the meanings. (M, F.) See 1 (last sentence) in art. slx.
masaxa AlkaAtibu The writer corrupted what he wrote by changing the diacritical points and altering the meaning. (Mṣb.)
masaxa Aln-aAqapa, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamosaxu}, inf. n. masoxN, (L,) ‡ He rendered the she-camel lean, and wounded her back, by fatigue and use: (AʼObeyd, L, Ḳ:) as also masaHa. (L.)

masuxa, [aor. _u {yamosuxu},] inf. n. masaAxapN † It (flesh-meat, and fruit,) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid: it (food) had no salt nor colour nor taste: and, sometimes, it was between sweet and bitter. (L.)
masaxa TaEomahu † It caused its taste to depart; took away its taste. (Ṣ.)
4. Amsx It (a humour) became dissolved. (L, Ḳ.)

7. Uim-asaxati AlEaDudu, [or Uinomasaxat, the original form,] The arm, between the shoulder and the elbow, became lean. (L.) UinomisaAxu HamaApi Alfarasi Lankness of [the muscle of the thigh (sAq) called] the HmAp of the horse (Ṣ, Ḳ) is disliked. (Ṣ.) [In some copies of the Ṣ, this is omitted.]

masoxN and masiyxN↓, (L, Ḳ,) [the former originally an inf. n., and therefore used as sing. and dual and pl. without alteration, though musuwxN is used as a pl. by late writers, (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., ii. 273,)] the latter of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (L,) Transformed, or metamorphosed, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape. (L, Ḳ.) Ex. AljaAn-u masoxu Aljin-i The Jánn, which are slender serpents, are the transformed of the Jinn, or Genii; like as certain persons of the Children of Israel were transformed into apes. [See Ḳur, ii. 61.] (L, from a trad.)
Also, ↓the latter, Deformed; rendered ugly in make, or form. (Ḳ.) Hence, some say, the appellation of Almasiyxu↓ Ald-aj-aAlu [more commonly AlmasiyHu Ald-j-An, q. v.]. (TA.)
Also, the same, ‡ A man having no beauty. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And † Weak and stupid: (Ḳ:) also an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

And † Flesh-meat, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and fruit, (L, Ḳ,) that has no taste; tasteless; insipid: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, applied to food, that has no salt nor colour nor taste: and sometimes, that is between sweet and bitter. (L.) El-Ash'ar Er-Rakabán, of the tribe of Asad, a Jáhilee, says, addressing a man named Ridwán, (L,)
masiyxN maliyxN kalaHomi AlHuwaA
ri laA Oanota HulowN walaA Oanota mur-N
[Tasteless, insipid, like the flesh of a new-born camel, thou art not sweet nor art thou bitter]. (Ṣ, L.)
masaxN Leanness of the arm, between the shoulder and the elbow. (L.)
masiyxN: see masoxN.

maAsixiI-N A bow-maker. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) AḤn says, that maAsixapu, a man of the tribe of Azd, of Es-Saráh, is asserted to have been a bowmaker: and Ibn-El-Kelbee says, that he was the first of the Arabs who made bows; that the people of Es-Saráh who made bows and arrows were numerous, because of the abundance of trees in their district, and hence every bowmaker in after times received the above appel-lation. (L.)

maAsixiy-apN (L, Ḳ) and maAsixiy-aAtN (Ṣ, L) Bows: so called in relation to the abovementioned bow-maker, Másikhah of the tribe of Azd: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) Másikhah was his surname, and his name was Nubeysheh the son of El-Hárith, one of the sons of Naṣr the son of Azd. (TA.)
huwa Oamasaxu mino laHomi AlHuwaAri [He, or it, is more tasteless, or insipid, than the flesh of the newborn camel]: i.e., he, or it, has no taste. A proverb. (Ṣ.)
mamosuwxN A horse, having little flesh in the rump, or buttocks: and mamosuwxapN AlEajuzi A woman having little flesh in her posteriors: (Ḳ:) but the more approved pronunciation is with H. (TA.)
1. masada, aor. _u {yamosudu}, (Ṣ, M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) He twisted a rope: (M, L, Ḳ:) or he twisted it well. (ISk, Ṣ, L.)

masada, aor. _u {yamosudu}, (M, L,) inf. n. masodN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) He pursued a journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey; syn. OadoOaba Als-ayora, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) by night: (Ṣ, M, L:) or he journeyed on continually, whether by night or by day: (M, L:) because the so journeying renders an animal lean, or lank. (Lth, L.)

masada, aor. _u {yamosudu} [inf. n. masodN,] ‡ It (leguminous herbage, A, or continued travel, Lth) rendered an animal lean, lank, light of flesh, slender, or lank in the belly. (Lth, A, L.) El-'Abdee says, describing a she-camel, and likening her to a wild bull,
yamosuduhu Alqaforu walayolN sadiI
The bare and waterless desert renders him lean,, &c., and dewy night. (L.)
musida, inf. n. masodN, ‡ It (the belly) was, or became, soft, of small dimensions, even, and without any ugliness. (M, L.)

The following expression of Ru-beh,
yamosudu OaEolaI laHomihi wayaOorimuhu
means ‡ It (the milk of camels) strengthens the upper parts of his flesh, (referring to a pastor, not to an ass, as J says, IB, L,) and renders it, firm. (L.)
Hasanapu Almasodi, applied to a damsel, ‡ i. q. mamosuwdapN, q. v. (Ṣ, L.)

masadN The fibres that grow at the roots of the branches of the palm-tree; syn. liyfN: (Ṣ, A, L:) you say HabolN mino masadK a rope, or halter, of those fibres: (Ṣ, A:) also, masadN alone signifies a rope of those fibres: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) or, of those of the [kind of palm-tree called] muqol: (Zj, L, Ḳ:) or, of the leaves of the palm-tree: or, of the soft hair of the camel: (Ṣ, M, L: [see an ex. voce zaAhiqN:]) or, of other hair: or, of wool: or, of hides: (M, L:) or, of camels' hides: (Ṣ, L:) or, of plants: or, of the bark of a tree: (L:) or, of any thing: (M, L, Ḳ:) or a plaited rope, firmly twisted, (M, L, Ḳ,) of any of the materials above mentioned: (M, L:) applied to a rope, it is for mamosuwdN; and is thus similar to nafoDN, meaning mA nufiDa: (L:) pl. OamosaAdN and misaAdN. (M, L, Ḳ.) HabolN mino masadK in the Ḳur, cxi., last verse, is said to mean A chain seventy cubits in length, whereby the woman upon whose neck it is to be put shall be led into hell, (Zj, T, M, L,) firmly twisted of iron; as though it were a rope of iron strongly twisted. (L.)
masadN mugaArN ‡ A back compact like a rope strongly twisted. (M, L.)
masadN An iron axis of a pulley. (M, L, Ḳ.)
misaAdN, a dial. form of misoOabN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) i. e., A skin for clarified butter: and one for honey: (Ṣ, M, L:) a black skin for wine, &c. (AA, L.)
saAqN masodaMCu ‡ An even, and a goodly, or beautiful, shank. (M, L.)

mamosuwdN ‡ A man of well-turned, compact, and slender, make; syn. majoduwlu Alxaloqi; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) i. e., light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature; syn. mamoXuwqN; as though twisted; (TA:) a belly soft, of small dimensions, even, and having in it no ugliness. (M, L.) mamosuwdapN, applied to a damsel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the same as the masc. applied to a man; (L, Ḳ;) slender; or light of flesh; or tall and slender; or of goodly stature: (L, M:) and, applied to a woman, compact in make; of well-knit frame. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. maX-a, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _u {yamoXuXu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. maX-N, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He wiped his hand with a thing, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ), or with a rough thing, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) and with a napkin, (A,) to cleanse it, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and to remove its greasiness. (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muDah-abN.] You say also, maX-a Oucunahu, and biOucunihi, He wiped his ear. (TA.) And OumoXuXo muxaATaka Wipe thou away the mucus of thy nose. (TA.)
‡ He wiped an arrow, and a bow-string, with his garment, to make it soft. (A, TA.*)

maX-a, (Lth, A, Mgh,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He sucked, (Lth, A, Mgh,) a bone, (A,) or the heads, or extremites, of bones, (Mgh, Ḳ,) [i. e.] what are termed muXaAX, they being chewed; (Lth;) as also tmX-Xhu↓, (Lth, A, Ḳ,) and AmtX-hu↓, and maXomaXahu↓, of which last the inf. n. is maXomaXapN: (TA:) and (TA) tmX-X↓ AlEaZoma he ate the muXaAX [q. v.] of the bone: or he sucked the whole of it; or extracted its marrow; syn. tamak-akahu: (Ṣ, TA:) and mX-Xhu↓, (TḲ,) inf. n. tamoXiyXN, (Ḳ,) he extracted its marrow; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AmtX-hu↓. (TA.)

huwa yamuX-u maAla fulaAnK, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He takes the property of such a one, thing after thing; (A, Ḳ, TA;) as also yamuX-u mino maAlihi: (TA:) or the latter, (accord. to one copy of the Ṣ,) or yamotaX-u↓ mn mAlh, (accord. to other copies of the Ṣ, and the TA,) he obtains of his property. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
4. AmX-, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UimoXaAXN, (TA,) It (a bone) had in it what might be sucked, or extracted; i. e., (TA,) had in it marrow. (Ḳ, TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
8. AmtX-: see 1, in five places.
Also, ‡ He performed the purification termed UisotanojaMC (IAạr, A, Ḳ) with a piece of stone or a lump of dry clay or loam. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. maXomaXa: see 1.

muXaAXN The heads of bones, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) that are soft, (Ṣ,) that may be chewed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or that are sucked: (Mgh:) or soft bones: (A:) or the heads of bones such as the knees and elbows and shoulder-bones: (AʼObeyd:) and the bone within a horn: (Mgh:) sing. [or rather n. un.] with p {muXaAXapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is also said to signify the prominent part of the shoulder-bone. (TA.) rajulN haX-u AlmuXaAXi rixowu Almagomazi ‡ [lit. A man soft, or fragile, in the heads of the bones, flabby where he is felt or pressed,] denotes dispraise. (TA.)

‡ The soul, or spirit; syn. nafosN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say fulaAnN Tay-ibu AlmuXaAXi ‡ Such a one is generous in soul, or spirit. (Ṣ, A.*) nahiXu AlmuXaAXi, applied by Aboo-Dhu-eyb to a horse, means ‡ Light, or quick, in spirit, or in the bones, or in the legs. (Ṣ, TA.)
‡ Natural disposition. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, fulaAnN lay-inu AlmuXaAXi ‡ Such a one is good in natural disposition; one who abstains from coveting. (TA.)

‡ Origin. (Ḳ, Ibn-ʼAbbád.) So in the saying Anh lkrym AlmuXaAXi ‡ Verily he is of generous origin: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) or this means ‡ verily he is a lord, or chief. (A, TA.) [And similar to this is the saying] huwa fiI muXaAXapi↓ qawomihi ‡ He is among the best of his people. (A,* TA.)

† Light, sharp, or quick, and who does much service in journeying and at home: (Ḳ:) or † light in spirit: or † one who is a light burden (xafiyfu AlmaWuwnapi) to him who consorts with him: or † sharp or quick in motions: and, as some say, xafiyfu AlmaXaAXi means † one who does much service in journeying and at home: so accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
maXuwXN A napkin, (Ṣ, A,) or rough napkin, (TA,) or thing with which to wipe the hand. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 1, first signification.
muXaAXapN: see muXaAXN, in two places.

miXomiXN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the dial. of El-Basrah, (TA,) and maXomaXN↓, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the dial. of El-Koofeh, (TA,) [The apricot;] a certain thing that is eaten; (Ṣ;) a well-known fruit; (Ḳ;) called in Persian zarodN Aluw [or zarodo Mluw]; (TA.) than which few things are found more productive of cold, or coolness, to the stomach, and befouling, and weakening: (Ḳ:) some, (Ḳ,) namely, the people of Syria, (TA,) apply this appellation to the Uij-aAS [which with others signifies the plum; but with them, the pear]: (Ḳ:) so says Lth: and some of the people of Syria pronounce it [muXomusN,] with damm. (TA.)
muXotN [The fist; the hand clinched: a Persian word arabicized]. (Mgh, in art. nXr.) [See an ex. voce taw-N, where it has a redundant n affixed to it.]
1. maXaja, aor. _u {yamoXuju}, inf. n. maXojN, He mixed, or confused, syn. xalaTa, (Ḳ,) one thing with (bi) another. (TḲ.)
maXaja bayonahumaA He made a confusion, or disturbance, (xalaTa,) between them two. (Ṣ.)
miXojN and maXajN and maXijN: see maXiyjN.

maXiyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maXaja↓ (Ḳ) and like ktf in its two dial. forms, (fiI lugatayohi, Ḳ accord. to the TA,)
i. e., maXijN↓ and miXojN↓, or like katifN in a dial. of little authority, (fiI lugay-apK, CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ.) [See maXoyuwHaMCu, in art. Xyj.] A thing mixed, or confused: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or any two things mixed together: or any two colours mixed together: or what is a mixture of red and white: (TA:) pl. (of all the above forms, TA) OamoXaAjN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nuTofapN OamoXaAjN, occurring in the Ḳur, lxxvi. 2, [A drop consisting of] mixtures; meaning the sperma genitale, because it is a mixture of various kinds: (ISk:) or [a drop consisting of] mixtures of sperma genitale and blood: (Zj:) or [a drop consisting of] the sperma genitale of the man mixed with that of the woman and with her blood. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also OamoXaAjN What collect together in the navel. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. maXaTa AlX-aEara, aor. _u {yamoXuTu} and _i {yamoXiTu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. maXoTN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He combed the hair; loosed and separated it with the comb; or combed and dressed it; syn. raj-alahu, (M, Ḳ,*) or sar-aHahu: (Mṣb:) and mX-Thu↓ signifies he did so much. (Mṣb.) You say also maXaTati AlmaAXiTapu AlmaroOapa, aor. _u {yamoXuTu}, inf. n. as above, [The mAXTp combed, or combed and dressed, the woman's hair.] (Ṣ, TA.)
Hence, (TA,) daAYimu AlmaXoTi is applied to ‡ A blandisher, or coaxer. (Ḳ, TA.)
maXoTN also signifies The act of mixing. (Fr, Ḳ.) You say, maXaTa bayona AlmaMCi waAll-abani [He mixed together the water and the milk]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
8. AmtXT He combed, or combed and dressed, his hair: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) [and in like manner,] you say of a woman, AmtXTt. (Ṣ, TA.)
maXoTN: see what next follows.

muXoTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and miXoTN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the latter disapproved by IDrd, (TA,) and maXoTN↓, (Ḳ,) and accord. to some with each of the three vowels to the X, but this requires consideration [in other cases than those here following], (MF,) and muXuTN↓ (Ks, Ḳ) and muXuT-N↓ (AHeyth, Ḳ) and maXiTN↓ (Ḳ) and mimoXaTN↓, (IB, Ḳ,) of all which the first is the most chaste, (TA,) A comb: pl. OamoXaATN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and miXaATN. (IB, Ḳ.)
muXoTN mina AlHadiydi A curry comb (miHas-apN): so called by a poet because it has teeth like the muXoT. (TA, art. nmS.)

Also muXoTN ‡ [An upright loom;] a loom with which one weaves, set upright: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. OamoXaATN. (TA.) You say Daraba Aln-aAsiju bimiXoTihi and OamoXaATihi ‡ [app. meaning The weaver wove with his upright loom and his upright looms]. (TA.)

‡ [The metatarsal bones;] the sulaAmayaAt of the upper part of the foot; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. the slender bones spread upon the foot, exclusive of the toes; [also called, more particularly, or perhaps only called, muXoTu Alqadami or muXoTu Alr-ijoli:] pl. OamoXaATN. (TA.) You say, Ainkasara muXoTu qadamihi ‡ [His metatarsal bones broke]. (TA.) And qaAmuwA EalaI OamoXaATi Oarojulihimo ‡ [They stood upon their metatarsal bones]. (TA.)
muXoTu Alkatifi † The wide bone of the scapula: (Ṣ:) or a wide bone thereof: (Ḳ:) or the wide flesh thereof: (T, TA:)
muXoTN also signifies † A certain mark made with a hot iron upon camels, (Ḳ,) in the form of a comb, (Sb, TA,) upon the body, and the neck, and the thigh. (Aboo-ʼAlee, TA.)
miXoTN: see muXoTN.
maXiTN: see muXoTN.
muXuTN: see muXoTN.
muXuT-N: see muXoTN.
miXoTapN A mode, or manner, of combing, or of combing and dressing the hair. (Ṣ,* TA.)
lim-apN maXiyTN A lock of hair descending below the lobe of the ear combed, or combed and dressed; i. q. mamoXuwTapN↓. (Ṣ, TA.)
muXaATapN What falls, of hair, on the occasion of combing, or combing and dressing it. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
miXaATapN The art, or occupation, of the maAXiTap. (Ḳ.)
maX-aATN A comb-maker. (TA.)
See also maAXiTapN, in two places.

maAXiTapN [A female comber, or comber and dresser, of the hair;] (Ṣ;) a female who combs the hair, or combs and dresses it, well; (Ḳ;) and [in like manner] maX-aATapN↓ a girl who performs well the art of combing, or combing and dressing, the hair. (TA.) And one of the post-classical writers has used in his poetry the epithet maX-aATN↓ [applied in like manner to a man or boy]. (TA.)
OamoXaTu: see mamoXuwTN.
mimoXaTN: see muXoTN.
mamoXuwTN, fem. with p {mamoXuwTapN}: see maXiyTN.
baEiyrN mamoXuwTN. † A camel marked with the mark termed muXoT; (Ḳ;) as also OamoXaTu↓. (TA.)

1. maS-ahu, (A, Mṣb,) first pers. maSiSotu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yamaS-u; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and first pers. maSaSotu, aor. yamuS-u; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) but the former is the more chaste; (T, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. maS-N; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) [He sucked it; or sucked it in; or sipped it, i. e.] he drank it (namely water, A, or a thing, Ṣ, M,) with a minute draught, (XurobFA raqiyqFA: so in a copy of the A, and in the CK,) or with a gentle draught: (XurobFA rafiyqFA: so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA:) or he took it (namely a small quantity of a fluid) by drawing in the breath: and whether Xariba may be used to denote this, as it is in the Ḳ, requires consideration: (MF:) or i. q. raXafahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. rXf:) or i. q. taraX-afahu: (M:) raXofN signifies the “taking” water “with the lips;” and is more than maS-N: (Mṣb, art. rXf:) and AmtS-hu↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so tmS-Shu↓: (M, A:) or the last signifies he did so leisurely. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, AmtS-↓ Alr-um-aAna, i. e. maS-ahu [He sucked the pomegranate]; and so of other things. (TA.) And maS-a AljaAriyapa He sucked the damsel's saliva from her mouth. (IAạr, in L, art. mSd.) And maS-a mina Ald-unoyaA ‡ He obtained a little of worldly goods. (TA.)
4. AmS-hu [He made him to suck: or he gave him to suck]. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say OamoSaSotuhu AlmaMCa (A) or AlX-aIoCa (Ṣ) [I made him to suck, or I gave him to suck, the water, or the thing].
‡ He said to him yaA maS-aAnu, q. v. (Ṣ,* A, TA.) You say, huwa yumiS-uhu wayubaZ-iruhu. (Ḳ, art. bZr, which see in the present work.)
5: see 1, in which two explanations of it are given.
8: see 1. in two places.

R. Q. 1. maSomaSa, (Ṣ, A,) or maSomaSa faAhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. maSomaSapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [He rinsed his mouth with water; he agitated water in his mouth;] syn. maDomaDa: (M:) or he did so with the extremity of his tongue, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or with the fore parts of his mouth; (A;) whereas the latter signifies he did so with his mouth altogether; (Ṣ, M, A;) the difference between maSomaSapN and maDomaDapN being similar to that between qaboSapN and qaboDapN: (Ṣ, M:) the former is mentioned in a trad. as being done after drinking milk; but not after eating dates. (Ṣ.) You say also, maSomaSa AlUinaMCa He washed the vessel; (ISk, Ṣ, M;) as also maDomaDahu: (ISk, Yaạḳoob, M:) or he washed out, or rinsed, the vessel; he put water into the vessel, and shook it, to wash it; (Aṣ, TA;) he poured water into the vessel, and then shook it, without washing it with his hand, and then poured it out. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)
And maSomaSa Alv-awoba He washed [or rinsed] the garment, or piece of cloth. (M, TA.)
muS-apN: see what next follows.

muSaASN What is sucked from, or of, a thing; (M, TA;) as also muSaASapN↓. (M, A, TA.) You say, TaAbato muSaASatuhu fiI famiI What was sucked from it, or of it, was good, or sweet, or pleasant, in my mouth. (A.)

[And hence,] The pure, or choice, part of anything; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also muSaAmiSN↓: (Ḳ:) and (Ṣ) the purest, or choicest, (Ṣ, M,) of a thing; as also muSaASapN↓ and muSaAmiSN↓. (M.) And muS-apu↓ AlmaAli signifies the same as muSaASuhu, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. The pure, or choice part of property, or of the property. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN muSaASu qawomihi, (Ṣ, M,) and muSaASatuhu↓, (M,) Such a one is the purest in race, or lineage, of his people: and in like manner you say of two, and of more, and of a female. (Ṣ, M.) And huwa mino muSaASi qawomihi [He is of the purest, or choicest, of his people]. (A.)

Also, The origin, source, or place of origination, of a thing. (M, TA.) You say, huwa kariymu AlmuSaASi He is generous, or noble, in respect of origin. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, muSaASu Alqawomi signifies The original source of the people: and the most excellent of their middle class. (TA.)

maSuwSN A certain kind of food, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of flesh-meat, cooked, and steeped in vinegar; (Ḳ;) or, as some say, steeped in vinegar, and then cooked: (TA:) or of the flesh of birds particularly: (Ḳ:) pronounced by the vulgar with damm to the m: (Ṣ:) but what is said in the Nh implies that it is with damm; for it is there said, “and it may be with fet-ḥ to the m.” (TA.)
muSaASapN: see muSaASN, in four places.
maSuwSapN: see mamoSuwSapN.
maS-aASN: see what next follows.
maS-aAnN A cupper; because he sucks; (M, TA;) and so maS-aASN↓: (Ḳ, voce Haj-aAmN, which is its syn.:) fem. of the former with p {maS-aAnapN}. (M.)

A man who sucks his ewes or she-goats; by reason of his meanness, or ungenerousness: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e. who sucks from their udders with his mouth; lest the sound of the milking should be heard; as also, maAS-u↓; (TA;) and so maloHaAnu and mak-aAnu. (AʼObeyd, TA. [But in the TA it is written maS-aAnu, without tenween; and so in two copies of the Ṣ.])

yaA maS-aAnu, [said to a man,] and yaA maS-aAnapu, to a female, denote vituperation, meaning ‡ O sucker (maAS- Ṣ, Ḳ) of such a thing, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the baZor [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,) of thy mother: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or the meaning is O sucker (raADiE) of the ewes or she-goats: (Ḳ:) ISk says, (TA,) you should not say yaA maAS-aAnu↓: (Ṣ, TA:) but Ibn-ʼAbbád says, (TA,) one says wayoliI EalaI maAS-aAni boni maAS-aAnK, and maAS-aAnapa boni maAS-aAnapa↓, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning [Alas for me, on account of] the mean, or ungenerous, the son of the mean, or ungenerous! (TA.)
muS-aAnN, with damm, The sugar-cane; [because it is sucked.] (IKh, IB.)
muSaAmSN: see muSaASN, in four places.
maAS-N, act. part. n. of 1: see maS-aAnN, in two places.
maAS-aAnu and maAS-aAnapu: see maS-aAnN.

mamoSuwSN ‡ A slender pastern; (Ḳ, TA;) as though it were sucked. (TA.) And mamoSuwSapN (M, A) and maSuwSapN (AZ, ISk, Ḳ) ‡ A woman emaciated (AZ, ISk, M, A, Ḳ) by reason of a disease infecting her; (AZ, ISk, M;) as though she were sucked. (M, TA.)
1. maSata, [_u,] inf. n. maSotN (TA,) Inivit puellam: (Ḳ:) dial. form of mSada. (TA.)
maSata Aln-aAqapa He laid hold upon the womb of the camel, and put in his hand, and extracted the water [i. e. the semen injected into it]. (M, Ḳ.) [See also masaTa.]
maSata AlmiEaI He squeezed out what was in the intestine, or gut, with his fingers. (TA.)
maSata It (herbage) purged cattle; or relaxed them in the bowels. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ.)
maSata He squeezed an ulcer, so as to express the matter. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ)
maSata He sucked saliva. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ.)
1. maSaHa, aor. _a {yamoSaHu}, inf. n. muSuwHN (and maSoHN, TA), He, or it, (a thing, Ṣ,) went away; passed away; departed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It finished; came to an end; ceased. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (a plant) became faded in its blossoms. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a blossom) faded; or lost its colour. (AḤn.)
maSaHa, (inf. n. muSuwHN, TA,) It (the shade) became short. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (an udder) ceased to have milk. (TA.)
It (the milk of a camel) ceased; passed away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maSiHa, aor. _a {yamoSaHu}, It (shade) became deficient and thin. So accord. to the Ḳ; but in other lexicons, the verb, with reference to shade, is maSaHa. (TA.)
maSaHa, inf. n. muSuwHN, It (a writing) became obliterated, or nearly so. (TA.)
It (a dwelling) became obliterated; or its vestiges became effaced. (TA.)
maSaHa bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OamoSaHahu↓, (IB,) He took away, carried off, or went away with, it; or caused it to go, go away, or pass away. (Ṣ, IB, Ḳ.)
maSaHa fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. maSoHN, He set forth journeying through the land, or earth: as also masaHa. (ISd.)
4: see 1.
OamoSaHu Deficient and thin shade. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. maSaxa, aor. _a {yamoSaxu}, (L,) inf. n. maSoxN; and AmtSx↓ and tmS-x↓; (L, Ḳ;) He pulled away a thing (L, Ḳ) from the inside of another thing, (L,) and took it: (Ḳ:) and maSaxa and AmtSx↓ he pulled away an OumoSuwxap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, or of that called naSiI-, (Ṣ, L,) from within another AmSwxp thereof, (L,) and took it: (Ṣ, L:) and tmS-x↓ he pulled out the white pith called AmSwxp of the barodiI-. (AḤn, L.)
maSaxa, inf. n. maSoxN, a dial form of masaxa, q. v. (L, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 4. AmSx It (a plant of the kind called vumaAm) put forth its OamaASiyx [pl. of OumoSuwxap, q. v.] (Ḳ.)
5: see 1 in two places.
7. Uim-aSaxa, inf. n. Uim-iSaAxN, It (a child) became disunited from its mother; (Ḳ;) i. e., from the belly of its mother. (L, TA.)
8. AmtSx, It (a thing) became disunited from (Eano) another thing. (TA.)
See 1 in two places.
maSuwxapN A ewe or she-goat whose udder is flaccid at the base; (T, Ḳ;) as though it were disunited (AmtSxt, i. e. AnfSlt,) from the belly. (T, L.)

muS-aAxN A certain plant having coats (quXuwr) like the onion; (Ḳ;) of which Az says, I have seen, in the desert, a plant called muS-aAxN and Yud-aMCN having coats (qXwr), one above another; whenever one peels off one OumoSuwxp (or coat) there appears another; and its coats (qXwr) are an excellent fuel: the people of Haráh (hrAp) call it dlyzAc. (L.)

OumoSuwxapN A sheath or coat, of a plant, enveloping, or surrounding, another sheath or coat, and the latter another, and so on: (T, L:) a xawSap of the kind of plant called vumaAm, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of that called naSiI-; (Ṣ;) what is plucked from the nSI-, like a rod; (AḤn;) [i. e., a sheath of the vmAm or the nSI-;] there is a species of the vmAm having no leaves properly so called, its leaves being sheaths (OanaAbiyb) set one into another, each sheath (Ounobuwbap) of which is called AmSwxp, and when it is pulled away it comes forth from the inside of another, as though it were a stopper taken out from a vessel in which collyrium (kuHol) is kept: (Lth:) pl. OumoSuwxN and OamaASiyxu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former is a lexicological pl., [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which AmSwxp is the n. un.,] and the latter is the proper pl. (TA.)
Also, The white pith of the barodiI-. (AḤn.)

hom.sense: 1. maSadahaA, aor. _u {yamoSudu}, (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) He sucked her breast (Lth, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) in a certain manner. (Ṣ, M, L.) You say, qab-alahaA famaSadahaA He kissed her and sucked her breast. (Lth, L.)

maSadahaA, (IAạr, L,) inf. n. maSodN; (IAạr, L, Ḳ;) He sucked her (a damsel's) saliva from her mouth; like maS-ahaA, and raXafahaA, and raf-ahaA: (IAạr, L:) and maSada he sucked (IAạr, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) saliva. (IAạr, Ṣ, L.)
maSadahaA, (Ṣ, M, L,) aor. _u {yamoSudu}, (M,) inf. n. maSodN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) Inivit eam, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) quodam modo; (M;) scil, ancillam suam. (L); as also mazadahaA, inf. n. mazodN. (M.)
maSada, inf. n. maSodN, He brought under; subdued; rendered submissive; syn. cal-ala. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maSodN Thunder. (L, Ḳ.)
maSodN Rain: (L:) and with p {maSodapN}, a shower of rain; a rain: you say, maA OaSaAbatonaA AlEaAma maSodapN, (and mazodapN, TA,) Not a rain has fallen on us this year. (M, L, Ḳ.)

maSodN Intenseness of cold; (Kr, M, L, Ḳ;) as also maSadN↓: (Ḳ:) or, simply, cold; (Er-Riyáshee, L;) as also maSodapN↓. (Ṣ, M.) And, contr., Intenseness of heat: (Kr, M, L, Ḳ:) and maSodapN↓, simply, heat. (AZ, L.) You say, maA wajadonaA lahaA AlEaAma maSodapF, (and mazodapF, ISk, Ṣ, M, L,) We have not found it (the earth, AZ,) to have, this year, cold (AZ, Ṣ, M, L) nor heat: (AZ, L:) or, intenseness of cold nor intenseness of heat. (Kr, M, L.)

maSodN and maSadN↓ and maSaAdN↓ A high (M, Ḳ) and red (M) hill, or mountain, such as is called haDobapN: (M, Ḳ:) or the last, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and the others also, (M,) the upper part, or top, of a mountain: (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and the last, a place of refuge: and applied to a man: (A:) pl. of the last, OamoSidapN and muSodaAnN. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Az holds the m in mSAd to be augmentative, and the pls. to have been formed on the supposition of its being radical. (L.) See also art. Syd.
maSadN: see maSodN.
maSodapN: see maSodN.
maSaAdN: see maSodN.
2. mS-rhu He made it (namely a town) a miSor, i. e. a limit, or boundary, between two things. (IAạr.)

maS-aruwA AlmakaAna, inf. n. tamoSiyrN, They made the place, or appointed it to be, a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M,* Ḳ.) It is said of ʼOmar, maS-ara AlOamoSaAra, (TA,) which is a phrase like mad-ana Almuduna, (Ṣ,) [and signifying He appointed the cities, or towns called OamoSaAr: or] mS-r AlAmSAr signifies he built the [cities, or towns, called] AmSAr: (A:) among which AmSAr were El-Basrah and El-Koofeh. (A, TA.)
5. tmS-r It (a place) became a miSor [meaning a city, or town, such as is thus called]. (M, Ḳ.)

miSorN A partition, barrier, or thing intervening, between two things: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) as also maASirN↓: (Ḳ:) and (Ṣ) or limit, or boundary, between two lands: (M, Ḳ:) pl. muSuwrN. (Ṣ, M.) The people of Egypt, (Ṣ,) or of Hejer, (M,) or of both, (TA,) write in their contracts, (Ṣ, M,*) UiXotaraI fulaAnN Ald-aAra bimuSuwrihaA Such a one bought the house with its limits, or boundaries. (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ.*)

Hence, A great town; syn. baladN EaZiymN; (Bḍ, ii. 58;). a kuwrap [here meaning city, or provincial city]: (M, Ḳ:) or a kuwrap (Lth, IF, Mṣb) in which the [ordinances of God which are termed] Huduwd are executed, and (Lth, TA) in which the [spoil or tribute termed] faIoC and the [alms termed] SadaqaAt are divided (Lth, IF, Mṣb) without consulting the Khaleefeh; such is its signification in the language of the Arabs: (Lth, TA:) or that [town] whereof the greatest of its mosques will not hold, or contain, its inhabitants: (KT:) it is masc. and perfectly decl., and fem. and imperfectly decl.: (Mṣb:) [but this remark seems properly to relate to the word when used as the name of the metropolis of Egypt, and of Egypt itself, agreeably with what is said in the Ṣ, M, and Ḳ:] pl. OamoSaArN. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb.) The dual, AlmiSoraAni, is applied to El-Koofeh and El-Basrah. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)

maSiyrN A gut, an intestine, or a bowel, into which the food passes from the stomach; syn. miEFI: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or specially, as some say, of a bird, and of an animal which has a soft foot, or xuf-, [as the camel,] and of such as have a cloven hoof: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OamoSirapN (M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] muSoraAnN, and pl. pl. maSaAriynu: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the last accord. to Sb; (M;) but some say that it is not established; (A;) and Lth says, that it is a mistake; but Az says, that it is pl. of muSoraAnN, and that the Arabs have given it this form of pl. imagining the m to be a radical letter; (TA;) and some say, that maSiyrN is of the measure mafoEilN, [originally maSoyirN,] derived from SaAr Uilayohi AlT-aEaAmu [“the food passed to it”], and they say muSoraAnN in like manner as they say musolaAnN as pl. of masiylu AlmaMCi, likening mafoEilN to faEiylN: (Ṣ, TA:) miSoraAnN also is a dial. form of muSoraAnN. (Fr, Ṣgh, TA.) [See also maSaAr-, in art. Sr.]
muSoraAnu AlfaArapi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or muSoraAnu AlfaOori, (Mgh, Ḳ,) ‡ A bad kind of dates. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
maASirN: see miSorN; and see maOoSirN, in art. ASr.

hom.sense: 1. maD-a, (A,) or maDiDa, like fariHa, (Ḳ) [but maDiDa, being contr. to rule, is probably a mistranscription, and its being said to be like fariHa may be only to indicate the form of the sec. pers., &c.,] sec. pers. maDiDota, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yamaD-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. maDaDN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDiyDN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and maDaADapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He suffered, or experienced, pain; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) mina AlX-aIoCi from the thing; (Mṣb;) or mina AlmuSiybapi from the calamity, or misfortune; (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ,* TA;) and mina AlkalaAmi from the speech. (A, TA.) And maDiDotu liloOamori I experienced distress from the affair, or event. (TA.)
maD-ahu: see 4, throughout.

entry.sense:
4. AmD-hu, (AO, Th, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UimoDaADN; (Ṣ;) and maD-ahu↓ (AO and the other authorities mentioned above, IDrd, A,) aor. _u {yamoDuDu}, (M, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. maD-N (IDrd, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDiyDN; (M, A, Ḳ;) but the latter form of the verb was not known to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) and is said by Th, (Ṣ,) and by Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà, (IDrd,) to be obsolete; (IDrd, Ṣ;) or the former is of the dial. of Temeem; (AO;) It (a wound, Th, Ṣ, Mṣb, and disquietude of mind, Mṣb) pained him: (Th, Ṣ, Mṣb:) it (disquietude of mind, and grief,) burned him, and distressed him: (M, TA:) it (a thing) affected, or distressed, his heart with grief; (A, Ḳ;) and both are said also of pain, and of disquietude of mind, and of a man beating another. (A.)
You say also, AlkuHolu yumiD-u AlEayona; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and yamuD-uhaA↓, (A, Ḳ,) and yamaD-uhaA↓; (Ḳ;) The collyrium pains the eye: (A, Ḳ:) or burns it: (Ṣ:) or pains and burns it: (TA:) or stings it by its pungency. (Mṣb.) And maD-a Alxal-u faAhu↓ The vinegar burned his mouth. (IDrd, Ḳ.) And OamaD-aniI hecaA Alqawolu This saying distressed me. (TA.) And AmD-hu jiloduhu fadalakahu His skin itched [and he therefore rubbed it]. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. maDomaDa, (Ḳ,) or maDomaDa AlmaMCa fiI fiyhi, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. maDomaDapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and miDomaADN and maDomaADN, (Ḳ,) this last is said by Aṣ to be allowable, (TA,) [He rinsed his mouth with water;] he agitated water (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) round about (Mṣb) in his mouth; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) lilowuDuwoCi for the wDwC, q. v.; (Ḳ;) as also tamaDomaDa↓ llwDwC, (Ḳ,) or fiI wuDuwoYihi in his wDwC, (Ṣ,) or tmDmD↓ biAlomaMCi. (Mṣb, TA.) [See also maSomaSa.]

maDomaDa, (Aṣ, Lḥ,) inf. n. maDomaDapN, (Ḳ,) also signifies He agitated a vessel [so as to rinse it, or wash it out, with water]: (Aṣ:) or he washed a vessel, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) or other thing; (Ḳ;) so, [for instance,] a garment, or piece of cloth; as also maSomaSahu [q. v.] (Lḥ.)

[Hence,] maA maDomaDotu EayoniI binawomK (Ṣ, A, L) ‡ I did not sleep. (Ṣ, L.) And maA maDomaDato EayoniI binawomK, (L,) or maA tamaDomaDato↓, (A,) ‡ My eye did not sleep. (L.) [The inf. n.] miDomaADN also signifies ‡ The state of sleeping. (TA.) And maDomaDa ‡ He slept a long sleep. (TA.) And maDomaDa Aln-uEaAsu fiI Eayonihi ‡ Drowsiness crept in his eye; (TA;) and [so] tamaDomaDa↓ Aln-uEaAsu fiI Eayonihi, (Ṣ, TA,) or Aln-awomu sleep. (A.) And tamaDomaDati↓ AlEayonu biAln-uEaAsi ‡ [The eye became infused with drowsiness]. (TA.)

maDomaDapN also signifies, accord. to El-Fárábee, The making, or uttering, of a sound; or the sound itself; (Sawot;) of the serpent, &c.: or, as some say, its (a serpent's) making motions with the tongue [so as to produce a sound]. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1, in five places.

maD-N, applied to collyrium, (L, Ḳ,) and to the style, or bodkin, with which it is applied to the eyes, (Ṣ, O,) an inf. n. used as an epithet; (O;) Paining; (Ḳ;) or burning; (O, L;) or hot. (Ṣ.) You say, kaHalahu kuHolFA maD-FA He applied to his eyes burning [or paining] collyrium. (L.) And kaHalahu bimulomuwlK maD-K He applied collyrium to his eyes with a hot, (Ṣ,) or burning, (O,) [or paining,] style. (Ṣ, O.)
rajulN maD-u AlD-arobi A man who beats, or strikes, painfully. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

UimoraOapN maD-apN A woman who does not bear, or endure, what displeases her, or grieves her; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as though it pained her, or burned her: (IAạr:) or whom a small word pains: or whom a small thing hurts, or annoys. (T, TA.) [It occurs coupled with baD-apN, to which it should not be regarded as merely an imitative sequent.]
maD-apN: see maD-N:
and what next follows.
maDaDN The pain of a calamity or misfortune. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 1.]
Sour milk; (Ḳ;) [so called because it bites the tongue;] and so maD-apN↓, (Ḳ,) and baD-apN, of the milk of camels. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
maDaADN The state of being burned. (TA.)
muDaADN A pain which affects a man in the eye, &c., from a thing that burns: so in the O, on the authority of IAạr; but in the TṢ it is miDomaADN↓. (TA.)
Water that is intolerable by reason of saltness. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
maDiyDN The burning of collyrium [&c.: see maD-ahu, explained with OamaD-ahu]: (L:) and miDomaADN↓ [in like manner] signifies a burning. (Ḳ.)
maD-aADN Burning: [or rather, burning much:] applied by El-ʼAjjáj as an epithet to travel. (TA.)
miDomaADN: see muDaADN:
and maDiyDN.

1. maDaHa EiroDahu, aor. _a {yamoDaHu}; (inf. n. maDoHN; TA;) and OamoDaHahu↓, (inf. n. UimoDaAHN; TA;) He disgraced, or dishonoured, him; blasted his reputation; (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ;) imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault, or the like. (TA.)
4: see 1.

1. maDara, aor. _u {yamoDuru}; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and maDira, aor. _a {yamoDaru}; (A, Ḳ;) and maDura, aor. _u {yamoDuru}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. muDuwrN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the first, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and maDorN, [also of the first,] and maDarN, [of the second;] (Ḳ;) It (milk, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, and [so in the A, but in the Ḳ or,] beverage of the kind called nabiyc, A, Ḳ) was, or became, sour, or acid: (Mṣb:) or sour, or acid, biting the tongue: (A:) or such as to bite the tongue; (Ṣ, TA;) before becoming raAYib: (TA:) or sour, or acid, and white. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. mD-rhu, inf. n. tamoDiyrN, He referred his lineage, or origin, to muDar [Mudar, the ancestor of most of the Arabs who trace up their genealogy to Ismá'eel, or Ishmael]: (Ḳ:) or he made him to be of the race of muDar by referring his lineage, or origin, to them. (A.)

It is said, of the race of muDar, in a trad., mD-rhA Qll-eh fiI Aln-aAri, meaning, May God make them to be in the fire [of hell]; the verb being derived from their name: (TA:) or may God collect them together [therein]; like as one says jan-ada Aljunuwda: (Z, TA:) or destroy them; (Ḳ;) from the saying cahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA, in the first of the senses explained below: (TA:) J says, [in the Ṣ,] that its origin seems to be from muDuwru All-abani, meaning “the biting of the tongue by milk,” and that it is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or intensiveness. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tmD-r He asserted himself to be related, or to belong, to the race of muDar. (A, Ḳ.) See 2.

He entered into a league (taEaS-aba, A: in the copies of the Ḳ, tagaD-aba; but the former, with the two unpointed letters, is the right reading: TA:) with, (A,) or for, (Ḳ,) the race of muDar. (A, Ḳ.)
He affected to be like, or imitated, or assimilated himself to, the race of muDar. (Ṣ, TA.)

cahaba damuhu xiDorFA miDorFA, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and xaDirFA maDirFA↓, (Ḳ,) His blood went unrevenged, or unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or so as to occasion no inconvenience or trouble (haniyoYFA mariyoYFA) to the slayer: (A:) mDrA is an imitative sequent: Ks mentions also biDorFA, with b. (Ṣ.)
