You say also, xucohu xiDorFA miDorFA, (Ḳ, TA,) and xaDirFA maDirFA↓, (Ṣgh, TA, and so in the CK,) Take thou it in a fresh, or juicy, state. (Ḳ.) See also art. xDr.

hom.sense: maDirN: see maADirN.
xaDirFA maDirFA: see miDorFA, in two places.

entry.sense: muDaAru All-abani, (TṢ,) or muDaArapu All-abani↓, (Ḳ,) What flows from milk (TṢ, Ḳ) when it becomes sour, or acid, and clear. (TṢ.)
maDiyrN: see maADirN.
muDaArapN: see muDaAru All-abani.

maDiyrapN A kind of cooked food made of [sour] milk that bites the tongue: (Ṣ:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk such as is termed maDiyr, and sometimes mixed with fresh milk: (Ḳ:) or a small quantity of broth, or gravy, cooked with milk and other things: (TA:) or, as made by the Arabs, flesh-meat cooked with pure milk that bites the tongue, until the flesh-meat is thoroughly done, and the milk has become thick; and sometimes they mix fresh milk with milk that has been collected in a skin; and in this case it is the best that can be. (AM, TA.)

maADirN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDiyrN↓ (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDirN↓, (IAạr, Ḳ,) the last thought by ISd to be a kind of relative or possessive epithet, because the verb is maDara, (TA,) [but it seems that he was unacquainted with, or that he disallowed, the form maDira, of which it is the regular part. n.,]
Milk that is sour, or acid, (A, Mṣb,) biting the tongue: (A:) or such as bites the tongue, (Ṣ, TA,) before becoming raAYib: (TA:) or that has become sour, or acid, and white. (Ḳ.)
maDoraHN and maDoraHiI-N: see art. DrH.

1. maT-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoTuTu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. maT-N, (TA,) He drew it; pulled it; strained it; extended it by drawing or pulling; stretched it; stretched it out; extended it; lengthened it; i. q. mad-ahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) maT-N and maTowN and mad-N are all one [in meaning]. (Az, TA.) You say, maT-a Ald-alowa, (Ḳ,) or maT-a biAld-alowi, (Lḥ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Lḥ,) He drew, or pulled, the bucket. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) And maT- HaAjibayohi He extended, or stretched, his eyebrows (Ṣ, TA) in speaking. (TA.) This last phrase also signifies ‡ He behaved proudly; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so maT-a xad-ahu; (Ḳ, TA;) syn. takab-ara [for which in the CK we find takab-urFA]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, maT-a OaSaAbiEahu He extended his fingers, (Ḳ, TA,) as though (TA) talking, or addressing, with them. (Ḳ, TA.) And maT-a AlHuruwfa [He lengthened the letters]; for mad-ahaA. (Aṣ, in TA, in remarks on the letter T.) And maT-a xaT-ahu, and xaTowahu, He extended, and made wide, his handwriting, and his stepping: and maT-a [alone], aor. and inf. n. as above, [xaTowahu being understood,] he made his stepping wide. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., of Saạd, laA tamuT-uwA bMmiyna Ye shall not lengthen [the word] Mmiynu [amen: yet this is done by most, if not by all, of the Muslims in the present day]. (TA.)
2. tamoTiyTN, [inf. n. of mT-T, and app. originally meaning The act of lengthening the tongue overmuch:] ‡ the act of reviling. (Ḳ, TA.)

5. tmT-T He stretched himself: he walked with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, and stretching out his arms; syn. tamad-ada; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tamaT-aI; like taZan-ayotu from AlZ-an-u; tmT-T being the original form. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur, [lxxv. 33,] vum-a cahaba UilaI Oaholihi yatamaT-aI Then he went to his family walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; syn. yatabaxotaru; (Fr, Bḍ, Jel, TA;) from AlmaT-u, because he who so walks extends his steps, so that it is originally yatamaT-aTu; (Bḍ;) or from AlmaTaA, signifying “the back,” because he who so walks twists his back. (Fr, Bḍ.)

It (water, Aṣ, TA, and thick sour milk, TA) roped, or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts; it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy. (Aṣ, TA.) [See also R, Q, 2.]
tmT-T fiI AlkalaAmi He varied (law-ana) in speech. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. maTomaTa fiI kalaAmihi He extended, and lengthened, his speech: (IDrd:) or maTomaTa signifies he flagged in his handwriting, or in his speech. (IAạr, Az, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. tamaTomaTa It (water) became thick. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [See also 5.]
muTuTN [a pl., of which the sing. is probably maTiyTN↓, like as the sing. of its syn. mududN is madiydN,] Tall, or long; applied to any animals. (IAạr.)
maTaATN Thick and sour camels' milk; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) such as is termed qaAriS; so called because it ropes, or is ropy. (TA.)
muTaATN: see what next follows.
miTaATN Extended; [meaning long;] as also muTaATN↓, and maTaAYiTN↓; applied as an epithet to what is termed SalFA [app. here meaning the “middle of the back”]; (Ḳ;) and to a camel. (TA.)
maTiyTN: see muTuTN.

maTiyTapN thick water, (Ṣ,) or turbid and thick water, (Ḳ, TA,) remaining (TA) in the bottom of a watering-trough: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or slime; or strong, or thick, slime: or, accord. to Aṣ, water in which is ropy mud: pl. maTaAYiTu: which, as pl. of the same sing., also signifies places hollowed by the feet of beasts of carriage, in the ground, in which slime, or strong or thick slime, collects. (TA.)
muTayoTaI: see what next follows.
maTiyTaMCu: see what next follows.

muTayoTaMCu, a dim. n. which has no undiminished form, (Z, in the Fáïk,) The act of walking with an elegant, and a proud, and self-conceited, gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: and the act of stretching out the arms in walking: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also muTayoTaI↓, (Aṣ, Kr, Ḳ,) in both these senses, (Aṣ, TA,) and maTiyTaMCu↓. (Ḳ.) You say, maXaI AlmuTayoTaMCa [He walked in either of the manners above described]. (Ṣ, TA.)
muTaAYiTN: see miTaATu.
1. maTaOa, aor. _a {yamoTaOu}, Inivit feminam. (Ibn-El-Faraj, Ḳ.)
maTovN: see art. Tv.

hom.sense: 1. maTarati Als-amaMCu, aor. _u {yamoTuru}, inf. n. maTarN, [The sky, or, as it sometimes means, the rain,] rained; as also OamoTarat↓: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb:) but the former is said to relate to that which is sent in mercy, and the latter to that which is sent in punishment. (Mṣb.) See also what follows.

[Both are also trans. You say,] maTaratohumu Als-amaMCu, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoTuru}, (TA,) inf. n. maTorN and maTarN; (Ḳ:) and OamoTaratohum↓, (A, TA,) which latter is the worse form, [as will be seen below,] The sky rained upon them. (A, Ḳ, TA.) And muTironaA We were rained upon; we had rain. (Ṣ. TA,)

You say also, maTarahumo xayorN, and Xar-N, ‡ [Good, and evil, poured upon them; or betided them]. (A.) And maTaraniI bixayorK ‡ He did good to me. (Ḳ.) And maA maTaraniI bixayorK ‡ [He did not any good to me]. (A.) And maA muTira minohu xayorFA, [in the CK, incorrectly, xayorN,] and bixayorK, ‡ Good did not betide him from him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.) But OamoTarahumu Qll-ehu↓ is only said in relation to punishment: (Ḳ, TA:) as in the saying in the Ḳur, [xxvi. 173, and xxvii. 59,] waOamoTaronaA↓ Ealayohimo maTarFA fasaMCa maTaru Qlomunocariyna ‡ [And we rained upon them a rain, and evil was the rain of the warned people]: and again in the Ḳur, [xv. 74,] waOamoTaronaA↓ Ealayohimo HijaArapF mino sij-iylK ‡ [And we rained upon them stones of baked clay]: the stones being regarded as rain because of their descent from the sky: some, however, hold that maTara and OamaTara↓ are the same in meaning. (TA.)

mar-a Alfarasu yamoTuru, inf. n. maTorN (Ṣ, A) and muTuwrN↓; (Ṣ;) and yatamaT-aru↓; (Ṣ, A;) ‡ The horse passed, or went, running vehemently, like the pouring of rain: (A:) or went quickly; or hastened; (Ṣ;) as also maTara Alfarasu, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. ns.: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies the horse was quick in his passing, or going, and in his running; and so tmT-r↓. (TA.) You say also, tamaT-ara↓ bihi farasuhu (A, TA) ‡ His horse ran, and hastened, or went quickly, with him. (TA.) And maTarati AlT-ayoru, and tmT-rt↓, ‡ The birds hastened, or were quick, in their descent. (Ḳ.) And tmT-rt↓ Alxayolu ‡ The horses came, (Ḳ, TA,) and went, quickly, (TA,) outstripping one another. (Ḳ, TA.)

cahaba AlbaEiyru famaA OadoriI mano maTara bihi (Ṣ, Ḳ *) ‡ [The camel has gone away, and I know not who has gone with it, or] has taken it: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, cahaba vawobiI Alx ‡ my garment has gone,, &c. (TA.)
4: see 1, in four places.
AmTr Qll-ehu Als-amaMCa God made the sky to rain. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
AmTr AlmakaAna He found the place rained upon. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
OamoTaronaA We were in rain. (TA.)

kal-amotuhu faOamoTara, (Mubtekir El-Kilábee, A, Ḳ,*) and UistmTra↓, (Mubtekir, A,) ‡ I spoke to him, and he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground, (OaToraq, Mubtekir, A, Ḳ, [which also signifies he was silent, not speaking, but accord. to the TA, (see 10,) should not be so rendered here,]) and his forehead sweated. (A, Ḳ.)
5. tmT-r He exposed himself to the rain: (A, Ḳ:) or he went out to the rain and its cold. (Ḳ.)
See also 10, in two places.
See also 1, in five places.

entry.sense: 10. AstmTr He asked, or begged, or prayed, for rain; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also tmT-r↓. (TA.) You say xarajuwA yasotamoTiruwna Qll-eha, and yatamaT-aruwnahu↓, [They went forth praying to God for rain.] (A, TA.)
[Hence,] AstmTrhu ‡ He sought, desired, or demanded, his beneficence, or bounty; (A, TA;) he asked him to give like rain. (Ṣ.)
[And hence, perhaps,] AstmTr lils-iyaATi † He endured patiently the whips [as though he desired that the stripes should fall like rain upon him]. (TA.)

And AstmTr † He was silent; he did not speak [when spoken to, as though he desired that words should pour upon him like rain]: in the Ḳ, this meaning is assigned to OamoTara, which should not be used in this sense: see also musotamoTirN; and see 4. (TA.)
AlmaAlu yasotamoTiru ‡ [The camels, or sheep,, &c.,] go out to the rain. (A.) See also 5.
AstmTr ‡ He (a man) sough shelter from the rain. (TA.)
AstmTr vawobahu He (a man) put on his garment in the rain. (Ibn-Buzurj.)
maTarN Rain: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) pl. OamoTaArN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See maTorapN: and see also ZahorN, p. 1929, a.
maTirN: see maATirN:
and see also mamoTuwrN.

hom.sense: maTorapN [A rain; a shower of rain]. (A; and Ṣ, Ḳ, voce magorapN, &c.) You say maTorapN mubaArakapN [A blessed rain.] (A.) See maTarN.
See also maTarapN.

entry.sense: maTarapN, (Fr, Ṣgh, Ḳ, also mentioned in the L, on the authority of IAạr, and in such a manner as implies that it may be also maTorapN↓, TA,) A [skin of the kind called] qirobap: (Ḳ, &c.:) applied in the present day to an UidaAwap and the like: (TA:) [I have found it now applied to a large bottle of leather, and of wood: pl. OamoTaArN.]
maTirapN: see EaTirN.
maToraAnN [sometimes pronounced miToraAnN, and muToraAnN, A metropolitan]: see jaAvaliyqN.
maTiyrN: see mamoTuwrN:
and maATirN.
maT-aArN ‡ A horse that runs vehemently. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: samaMCN maATirapN, (A, Mṣb,) and mumoTirapN↓, (A,) A raining sky. (A, Mṣb.) See also mimoTaArN.
yawomN maATirN, (A, Ḳ,) and mumoTirN↓, (Ḳ,) and maTiyr↓, (A,) and maTirN↓, (Ḳ,) which last is a possessive epithet, (TA,) ‡ A day of rain. (A, Ḳ.)
See also mutamaT-irN.

entry.sense: mamoTarN: see what next follows.

mimoTarN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mamoTarN↓ and mimoTarapN↓ (Ḳ) What is worn in rain, to protect one; (Ṣ;) a garment of wool, (Ḳ,) worn in rain, (TA,) by which to protect one's self from the rain; (Ḳ;) from Lḥ. (TA.)
mumoTirN and mumoTirapN: see maATirN.
mimoTarapN: see mimoTarN.
samaMCN mimoTaArN A sky pouring down abundance of rain. (A.) See also maATirN.

mamoTuwrN ‡ A place, (Ḳ,) and a valley, (A,) rained upon, or watered by rain; as also maTiyrN↓; (A, Ḳ, TA;) and maTirN↓, as in a verse cited voce xaTowapN: and so maTiyrN↓ and maTiyrapN↓ applied to a land (OaroDN). (TA.)

hom.sense: xaraja mutamaT-irFA He went forth into the gardens and fields after rain. (A.)

TaAYirN mutamaT-irN ‡ A bird hastening, or going quickly, (Ṣ, TA,) in its descent; (TA;) [as also maATirN↓, of which the pl., muT-arN, occurs in the following ex.:] Ru-beh says,
waAlT-ayoru tahowiI fiI Als-amaMCi muT-arFA
[And the birds descend in the sky, hastening]. (TA.) mutamaT-irN is also applied to a horseman, as signifying hastening, or going quickly. (Ṣ.)
musotamoTarN ‡ A man [from whom beneficence, or bounty, is sought, or desired: and hence,] naturally disposed to beneficence, or bounty. (IAạr, TA.)
‡ A place that is open and uncovered. (A, Ḳ.)
musotamoTirN [Asking, begging, or praying, for rain.]

[Hence,] ‡ Seeking, desiring, or demanding, beneficence, or bounty, (Lth, Ḳ,) from a man. (Lth.) You say, maA OanaA mino HaAjatiI Einodaka bimusotamoTirK ‡ I am not covetous of obtaining from thee the object of my want. (IAạr.)
‡ A place needing rain. (A, Ḳ.)
‡ Silent; not speaking [when spoken to, as though desiring that words should pour upon him like rain]. (Ḳ.)
[One] on whom rain has fallen. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maZ-N The pomegranate-tree: (Ḳ:) or the wild pomegranate, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M,) or the wild pomegranate-tree: (Lth, M, Ḳ:) or a sort of pomegranate (IDrd) that grows in the mountains of the saraAp, not producing fruit, but only blossoms, (IDrd, Ḳ,) and these in abundance: (IDrd *) in its blossoms is honey, (Ḳ,) in abundance, (TA,) and they are sucked: (Ḳ:) it produces blossoms, but does not form fruit, and the bees eat them, and yield good honey therefrom: AḤn says, it grows in the mountains, and produces many blossoms, but does not mature its produce, (laA yurab-iI,) but its blossoms have much honey: (M:) it has fire-wood of the best quality, the most excellent thereof in yielding fire, and it is made to flame like candles: Es-Sukkaree says, it is the wild pomegranate, which bees eat, and it produces only leaves, having no pomegranates: the n. un. is with p {maZ-apN}. (TA.)

Also, i. q. damu AlOaxawayoni, which is the same as damu AlgazaAli, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) called in the present day AlqaATiru Almak-iI-u (TA) [and qaToru mak-apa, i. e. the red, resinous, inspissated juice which we call dragon's blood.]
Also, The expressed juice of the roots of the OaroTaI, (Ḳ, TA,) which are red, the tree itself being green, and which, when camels eat them, cause their lips to become red. (TA.)
[Forskal, in his Flora, page ciii., mentions The dianthera trisulca as called in El-Yemen mD or mZ.]
1. maEata, aor. _a {yamoEatu}, (inf. n. maEotN, TA,) He rubbed (Ḳ) a skin, or hide. (TA.)
1. maEaja, aor. _a {yamoEaju}, inf. n. maEojN, He, or it, (a horse, and the wind, Ṣ, and a torrent, TA,) went quickly, or swiftly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See art. Emj.
mar-a yamoEaju He (a horse) went at an easy pace: (Ṣ:) and in like manner maEajato she (a camel) went at an easy pace. (Th.)
maEajati Alr-iyHu, aor. _a {yamoEaju}, inf. n. maEojN, The wind blew gently. (IAth.)
Alr-iyHu tamoEaju fiI Aln-abaAti The wind turns over the herbage to the right and left. (IAth.)
maEaja fI sayorihi He inclined, in his course in every direction, by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.)

maEaja, aor. _a {yamoEaju}, inf. n. maEojN, He affected various modes in running: he (a horse) pressed against one of the branches of the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness: see maE-aAjN]. (TA.)

maEaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa Oum-ihi, (aor. _a {yamoEaju}, inf. n. maEojN, TA,) The young weaned camel struck its head against its mother's udder, and inverted (as in the Ṣ, or opened, as in the Ḳ) its mouth around it, in order to suck: (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also magaja. (TA, arts. mEj and mgj.)
farasN maEuwjN A swift horse. (Ṣ.) riyHN maEuwjN A wind swift in its course. (TA.)

farasN maEuwjN, and mimEajN↓, A horse that often affects various modes in running: that often presses against one of the branches of the bit, and then against the other, now on the right and now on the left; [inclining in his run now to the right and now to the left, by reason of his sprightliness]. (TA.) [In like manner,] HimaArN maE-aAjN↓ An ass that inclines in his run to the right and left by reason of his sprightliness. (TA.)
maE-aAjN and mimoEajN: see maEuwjN.

hom.sense: 1. maEadahu, aor. _a {yamoEadu}, (inf. n. maEodN; L,) and AmtEdhu↓; He snatched it unawares; seized it hastily when its owner was unawares: (L, Ḳ:) or he seized it and took it away; snatched it away; took it away quickly by force. (L.)

Also, ↓both verbs, He drew, or pulled, it: (L:) or drew, or pulled, it quickly. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) Ex. maEada Ald-alowa, and maEada bihaA, and AmtEdhA↓, He drew up, or pulled up, the bucket: or drew, or pulled, it out, or forth, from the well. And maEada Alr-umoHa and AmtEdhu↓, He pulled forth the spear from the place where it was stuck in the ground. And AmtEd↓ sayofahu He drew forth his sword from its scabbard. (L.)
maEada bihi, aor. _a {yamoEadu}, inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, He took it (a thing) away; carried it off; went away with it. (Ḳ.)
Hence, maEada bixuSoyayohi He removed his testicles; (L, TA;) or he pulled them; as also maEada humaA. (Lḥ, L, TA.)
maEadahu He took it (namely, flesh,) with his fore-teeth. (Ḳ.)
maEadahu He plucked it out; namely, hair; as also magadahu. (L.)

muEida, (L, Ḳ,) and maEida, aor. _a {yamoEadu}, inf. n. maEodN and maEadN, (IḲṭṭ,) He (a man, L,) had a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he did not find his food wholesome: (L, Ḳ:) or his stomach pained him. (Ibn-T reef.)
maEadahu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his maEidap, or stomach. (L, Ḳ.)
maEada fiI AlOaroDi, (aor. _a {yamoEadu}, inf. n. maEodN and muEuwdN, L,) He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1 in five places.

R. Q. 2. tamaEodada He assumed the garb, dress, habit, or external appearance, of the sons of Ma'add: mentioned also in art. Ed [which see for other explanations not repeated here]: (Ḳ:) he endured with patience their mode of life in travel and in a fixed residence: (Lth, L:) and he subjected himself to a hard, or difficult life: said to be not derived from any other word. (L.)
tamaEodada He became numbered among the sons of Ma'add. (L.)
It (a people or party) removed from Ma'add to El-Yemen, and then returned. (Lth, L.)
‡ He became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and fat: (Lḥ, TA:) ‡ he (a boy) became big, bulky, gross, or coarse, and hard, and lost the freshness and tenderness of youth. (A.)
† He (an emaciated man) began to become fat. (Ḳ.)
He † (a sick man) became convalescent. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: nazoEN maEodN A quick pulling up, or out, of the bucket from a well: (IAạr, Ṣ,* L:) or a strong pulling up, or out; as though the bucket were pulled up from the bottom of the well: or a pulling up, or out, by means of the pulley, (L,) [and therefore quick].
maEodN Bigness; bulkiness; grossness; coarseness. (Ḳ.)
Big; bulky; gross; coarse; (ISd, L, Ḳ,) and strong: (ISd:) applied to a thing. (ISd, L.)
A quick, or swift, camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Fresh, and soft, or tender; applied to a leguminous plant; (L, Ḳ;) fresh and juicy; applied to the same, (Ṣ,) and to fruit. (L, Ḳ.)
ruTabapN maEodapN, and mutamaE-idapN↓, A fresh and juicy ripe date. (L, Ḳ.)
In the phrase busorN vaEodN maEodN, mEd signifies Fresh and soft or tender: (Ṣ, L:) or it is a mere imitative sequent, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) not used alone. (Ṣ, L.) See art. vEd.

entry.sense: maEodapN, miEodapN, miEidapN: see maEidapN.

maEidapN and miEodapN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maEodapN and miEidapN; (TA;) the first of which is the original form; (Mṣb, TA;) the second and third being contractions; and the fourth, as well as the others, mentioned by Expositors of the Fṣ.; (TA;) The stomach of a human being; the place in which is the food before it descends into the lower intesstines, or guts; (L, Ḳ;) in a man, what the kariX is in every ruminating animal; (Ṣ, L;) or in animals that have cloven hoofs, and such as have feet like those of the camel: (M, L, Ḳ:) accord. to ISd, from maEodN, applied to a thing, signifying “strong, and big, bulky, gross, or coarse:” (TA:) pl. maEidN (L, Ḳ) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which maEidapN is the n. un.,] and miEadN: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the latter as though formed from miEodapN. (L.)

maEad-N The side (L, Ḳ) of a man, &c.: (L:) or, in a horse, the part of each side between the lower portion of the shoulder-blade and the extremity of the ribs, consisting of thick and compact flesh behind the shoulder-blade; the protuberance whereof is approved, because, when that part is narrow, it compresses the heart: (L:) or, in a horse, the part between the head of each shoulder-blade and the hinder extremity of the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone: (L, Ḳ:) and the flesh that is beneath the shoulderblade, (L, Ḳ,) or a little below it; which is the best of the flesh of the side: (L:) and the place of the horseman's heel: (L, Ḳ:) or the part of a beast of carriage which is the place of the rider's leg: (Lḥ, L:) and the belly: (Aboo-ʼAlee, L, Ḳ:) also, a vein in the part of a horse called manosij. (L, Ḳ.) See also art. Ed.
maAEidN: see what follows.
mimoEadN (L, Ḳ) and maAEid↓ (L) A wolf that runs quickly. (L, Ḳ.)
mamoEuwdN A man having a diseased, or disordered, stomach, so that he does not find his food wholesome: (L:) having a bad stomach. (A.)
mutamaE-idapN: see maEodN.

1. maEira, [aor. _a {yamoEaru}, inf. n. maEarN,] said of a man, (Ṣ,) and of the head, and of the tail, (TA,) His or its hair fell off; (Ṣ, TA;) as also tmE-r↓, said of the head: (TA:) and the former said of the head, its hair became little, or scanty. (TA:) and maEirato, said of the forelock, (Aln-aASiyap, Ḳ,) or of that of a horse, (TA,) it lost all its hair: (Ḳ:) and maEira, said of a solid hoof, it lost the hair that hung down upon it from the fore part of the pastern. (TA.)

maEira, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoEaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maEarN, (Ṣ, TA,) said of hair, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and of plumage, and the like, (Ḳ,) It fell off; (Ṣ, A;) as also tmE-r↓, said of hair: (Ṣ, A:) or it became little, or scanty; as also OamoEara↓: (Ḳ:) and, said of a finger-nail, or toe-nail, ‡ it came out, or fell out, (A, Ḳ,) in consequence of something befalling it, or hurting it. (Ḳ.) See maEar-apN in art. Er.

[Hence,] maEira, (TA,) or maEira mino maAlihi, (A,) ‡ He became poor; (A, TA;) as also OamoEara↓, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. UimoEaArN; (TA;) or the latter, he became poor, and his travelling-provisions failed or became exhausted; as also mE-r↓, inf. n. tamoEiyrN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] OamoEarati↓ AlOaroDu ‡ The land became destitute of herbage: or its herbage became little, or scanty: (Ḳ:) contr. of OamoraEat. (IḲṭṭ.)
2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in the three places.

OamoEaronaA ‡ We came upon a land destitute of herbage: (A, TA:) or we found dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility: (TA:) and AmEr Alqawomu the people became afflicted with dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility. (TA.)
AmErt AlmawaAXiI AlOaroDa ‡ The beasts pastured upon the land, (i. e., its trees or herbs, TA,) and left no pasturage in it. (TṢ, L, Ḳ.)
AmErhu † He despoiled him of his property, (Ḳ, TA,) and reduced him to poverty. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.

maEirN A man, (Ṣ,) and a head, (A,) whose hair is falling off, or has fallen off; (Ṣ, A;) as also OamoEaru↓ and mutamaE-irN↓: (A:) or having little hair; (TA;) as also OamoEaru↓: (Ṣ:) and the first and second, a camel's foot (xuf-) of which the hair (both XaEar and wabar) has gone: and maEoraMCu↓, a forelock (naASiyap, Ḳ, or that of a horse, TA,) of which all the hair has gone. (Ḳ.)
Hair, and plumage, and the like, little in quantity, or scanty; as also OamoEaru↓: and the latter, hair falling off. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] ‡ A man who is niggardly, or avaricious, having little beneficence; (Ḳ;) unpropitious, mean, and hard, or difficult. (TA.)
† A man having little flesh. (TA.)

qaAEN maEirN, and OaroDN maEirapN, ‡ A plain, and land, destitute of herbage: (A:) or the latter, accord. to Yaạḳoob, land having little herbage: and makaAnN OamoEaru↓ a place having little herbage. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: OamoEaru: fem. maEoraMCu: see maEirN, throughout.
Also, of a solid hoof, † The hair that hangs down upon it (Ḳ, TA) from the fore part of the pastern: because it has a disposition to fall off. (TA.)

entry.sense: mutamaE-irN: see maEirN.

hom.sense: 1. maEiza AlX-aIoCu, [and maEizati AlOaroDu, accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the Ṣ,] aor. _a {yamoEazu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. maEazN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TḲ,) The thing [and the ground] was, or became, hard. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TḲ.)
maEiza said of a man: see 4.
maEazotu AlmiEozaI waDaOanotu AlD-aOona, aor. _a {yamoEazu}, I set apart the goats from the sheep. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AmEz He, (a man, A,) or it, (a people, Ṣ,) became abundant in goats; his or its, goats became abundant, or numerous; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also, maEiza↓, aor. _a {yamoEazu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maEazN. (TḲ.)

maEozN, and maEazN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) gen. ns., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [or rather quasi-pl. ns., signifying Goats;] the kind of ganam opposed to DaOonN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) the kind of Eanam that have hair; (Mṣb, TA;) the DOon being those that have wool; (TA;) as also miEozFI↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to Sb, (Ṣ,) with tenween, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) when indeterminate, (Mṣb,) and perfectly decl., (Ṣ,) the A [which is written I] being a letter of quasicoördination, not a characteristic of the fem. gender, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) for the word is quasi-coördinate to dirohamN, of the measure fiEolalN; for the A of quasi-coördination follows the same rules as a letter belonging to the word itself, as is shown by their saying muEayozK↓ and OurayoTK [originally muEayoziIN and OurayoTiIN] as the dim. forms of miEozFI and OaroTFI with tenween, the letter next after the I of diminution being with kesr, like as they say durayohimN; for if the A were to denote the fem. gender they would not change it into I [in muEayoziIN, the original form of muEayozK,] like as they do not change it in the dims. of HubolaI and OaxoraI [which are HubayolaI and OuxayozaI]: (Ṣ:) it is sometimes made fem., [by being written or pronounced miEozaApN,] and sometimes it is made imperfectly decl. [and therefore without tenween]: (Ḳ:) Fr says, that it is [itself] fem., but that some make it masc. [and therefore with tenween]: but AʼObeyd says, that most of the Arabs pronounce ciforaI without tenween, while some of them pronounce it with tenween, whereas all of them pronounce miEozFI with tenween: (Ṣ:) IAạr says, that it is perfectly decl. when likened to the measure mifoEalN, and imperfectly decl. when held to accord. with the measure fiEolaI: (TA:) accord. to Aboo-ʼAmr, Ibn-El-ʼAlà, it is from maEazN, [inf. n. of maEiza,] and in like manner ciforaI is from cafarN: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) maEiyzN↓ also signifies the same as maEozN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or is pl. of maEozN, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] like as EabiydN is of EabodN; (Mṣb;) and OumoEuwzN↓ also is syn. with maEozN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and so are miEaAzN↓ (Ḳ) and miEozaMCN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) [respecting OumoEuwzN, see also below:] maEozN [as well as its syns. mentioned above, like all quasi-pl. ns., is sometimes masc., but generally] is fem.: (Mṣb:) a male is called maAEizN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so a female; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or a female is called maAEizapN↓ (Ṣ, A, TA) [and maEozapN↓ (M, voce XaroqaMCu)] and miEozaAp↓; (TA;) and XaApN [or rather XaApN mina AlmaEozi] is also used as a sing., (Mṣb,) and is applied to a male and to a female: (Mṣb, art. Xwh:) [see also ZaboIN:] OamoEuzN is a pl. [of pauc.] of maEozN, like as OaEobudN is of EabodN: (Mṣb:) the pl. of maAEizN↓, (Ḳ,) or of maAEizapN, (Ṣ,) is mawaAEizu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and miEaAzN↓ and OumoEuwzN↓ are said to be quasi-pl. ns. (TA.) The goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun; but the goats of the cold countries, and of the people of the fertile regions, have abundant hair, and of this the Akrád [or Kurds] fabricate their tents. (T in art. bnI.) See also tadomuriI-N in art. dmr; and see DaAYinN in art. DOn.
maEozapN: see its syn. maEozN.
miEozFI: see its syn. maEozN.
miEozaMCN: see its syn. maEozN.
miEozaApN a fem. sing. of maEozN, q. v. (TA.)
miEaAzN: see its syn. maEozN.
maEiyzN: see its syn. maEozN.
muEayozK dim. of miEozNI, syn. of maEozN, q. v. (Sb, Ṣ.)
maE-aAzN A possessor, or master, of miEozFI [or goats]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maAEizN and maAEizapN sings. of maEozN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
The former also signifies Goats' skin. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OamoEazu, and its fem. maEozaMCu, applied respectively to a place (makaAnN) and to land or ground (OaroDN), ‡ Hard, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and abounding with pebbles: (Ṣ:) or both, [used as substs.,] rugged and stony ground: (A:) or a place abounding with pebbles, and hard: or the latter, small pebbles: (AʼObeyd, TA:) thus AʼObeyd explains a sing. as having a pl. signification: (TA:) or the latter, a desert, (SaHoraMC) in which is elevation and ruggedness, consisting of soil, or clay, and pebbles, mixed together, but hard ground, rough to the tread: (ISh, TA:) pl. muEozN, (Ḳ,) [a pl. of each as an epithet, or of each used as a subst.,] because imagined to have the character of an epithet; (TA;) and OamaAEizu, [a pl. of the former,] because the character of a subst. predominates in it; and maEozaAwaAtN, a pl. of the latter. (TA.)
OumoEuwzN: see its syn. maEozN.

It also signifies, (Ḳ,) or is said to signify, (Ṣ,) A herd of gazelles, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in number from thirty to forty; (Ṣ, TA;) or from thirty upwards: or a number of buckgazelles collected together: (TA:) or a number of OawoEaAl [or mountain-goats] collected together: (A, Ḳ:) or of AwEAl such as are termed vayaAtil: (Az, TA:) pl. OamaAEiyzu and OamaAEizu. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. maEiTa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoEaTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maEaTN, (Ṣ,) He (a man) was, or became, without hair upon his body: (Ṣ:) and in like manner you say of a man's skin: (TA:) and of a wolf, meaning his hair fell off by degrees, or part after part: but you should not say maEiTa XaEaruhu: (Ṣ:) [but see 5:] or, said of a wolf, it signifies he was, or became, mischievous, malignant, or foul; syn. xabuva: or his hair became scanty, or little, (Ḳ,) and tmE-T↓ said of a wolf, his hair fell off: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and Uim-aEaTa↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure UifotaEala, or [rather] UinofaEala, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) said of a rope, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ,) it became worn smooth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 5.
maEaTa, aor. _a {yamoEaTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. maEoTN, (TA,) He plucked out hair [or wool] (Ḳ, TA,) from the head of a sheep or goat. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tmE-T It (hair, Ṣ, Mṣb, [in the TA, Alrjl is inadvertently put for AlXEr, and copied in the TḲ, with the addition of XErh in the explanation,]) fell off by degrees, or part after part, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) upon the ground, (TA,) by reason of disease, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or the like; (Ṣ;) as also AmtET↓, (Ṣ,) and Uim-aEaTa↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure UifotaEala, (Ḳ,) or [rather] of the measure UinofaEala [originally UinomaEaTa]: (Ṣ:) and [accord. to some, but see 1, above,] maEiTa↓, aor. _a {yamoEaTu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. maEaTN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) it (hair) fell off. (Mgh, Mṣb.) You say also, tamaE-aTato OawobaAruhu His fur became scattered. (Ḳ, TA)
See also 1.
7. Uim-aEaTa, [said in the Ṣ, and in one place in a copy of the Ḳ, to be of the measure UinofaEala]: see 1:
and 5.
8. AmtET and Uim-aEaTa [which latter is said in one place in the copies of the Ḳ, to be of the measure UifotaEala]: see 5:
and for the latter, see also 1.
maEiTN: see OamoEaTu.
Oabuw muEoTapa The wolf: (Ḳ:) a gen. proper name thereof; similar to cuWaAlapu and OusaAmapu and vuEaAlapu. (TA.)

OamoEaTu, applied to a man, Having no hair upon his body; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or whose hair has fallen off; fem. maEoTaMCu: (Mṣb:) [and pl. muEoTN:] and, applied to a wolf, whose hair has fallen off by degrees, or part after part: (Ṣ:) or, thus applied, mischievous, malignant, or foul: [see 1:] or whose hair has become scanty, or little: as also maEiTN↓: (Ḳ:) and maEoTaMCu, applied to a she-wolf, has the former of the last two significations: and, applied to a ewe, it signifies whose wool has fallen off. (TA.)
liS-N OamoEaTu ‡ A mischievous, malignant or foul, or wolf-like, thief, or robber; (Ṣ,* L;) likened to the wolf termed AmET: pl. muEoTN. (Ṣ, L.)

OamoEaTu applied to sand, (Ḳ,) and maEoTaMCu applied to a tract or collection of sand (ramolapN), (TA,) and to land (OaroDN), (Ḳ,) and muEoTN applied to sands (rimaAlN), (Ḳ,) also signify ‡ Destitute of herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also OamoEaTu [app. applied to sand or the like], Extended upon the face of the earth or ground. (TA.)
And AlmaEoTaMCu, (IAạr, Ḳ,) as a subst., (IAạr,) The pudendum; syn. Als-awoCapu. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

1. magava, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yamoguvu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. magovN, (Ḳ,) He steeped, soaked, or macerated, a thing in water, and rubbed it with the fingers; he steeped it in water, and mashed it with the hand; (TA;) he steeped, and mashed with the hand, medicine in water; syn. marava. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
magava AlmaTaru AlkalaOa inf. n. magovN, The rain fell upon the herbage, and rendered it yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid it prostrate. (TA.)
magava, [aor. _u {yamoguvu},] He submerged, or immersed, him, or it, in water. (Ḳ.)
mugiva He was affected by a fever. (TA.)
magavatohu AlHum-aI The fever attacked him; or pained him. (TA.)
magavuwhu, [aor. _u {yamoguvu},] (Ṣ,) inf. n. magavN, (Ḳ,) They beat him lightly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) as though they shook him about (kaOan-ahumo talotaluwhu). (Ṣ.)
magava EiroDahu, (inf. n. magovN, Ḳ,) He defamed him; disgraced him; dishonoured him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) aspersed him by reviling. (TA.)
magavahumo biXar-K He did evil to them. (TA.)
3. maAgavaA, inf. n. migaAvN and mumaAgavapN, They clashed, and contended, each against the other; syn. HaAk-aA waxaASamaA. (Ḳ.)
magovN Evil, as a subst. (Ḳ.)
Conflict, (Ḳ,) and engagement of brave men in war, in the field of battle. (TA.)
A struggling in wrestling. (TA.) See magivN.
Play; syn. EabavN. (Ḳ.) One of the additions of F. (TA.)
magivN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or magovN↓, (L,) and mumaAgivN↓, (L,) A strong wrestler. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, the latter, A man pertinacious in altercation. (TA.)
magivN and magiyvN↓ An evil, a wicked, or malignant, man: after the manner of a rel. n. [denoting habitual state or action, and the like]. (TA.)
mugaAvN The lightest, or slightest, of the diseases incident to camels. (El-Hejeree.)

Also, A certain tree, two carats' weight (qiyraATaAni) of the root of which is an emetic and laxative: (Ḳ:) or, as in one copy [of the Ḳ], a certain plant, in the root of which is a poisonous quality (smyp [i. e., sum-iy-ap]); the drinking of a grain of it [in water] causes looseness of the bowels, and vomiting, in an excessive degree. (TA.) But these properties [says SM] are strange, and not mentioned by the physicians. Ibn-El-Kutbee says, in [the book entitled] maA laA yasaEu AlT-abiyba jaholuhu, mgAv is [the name of] roots which are imported, of a hot and moist temperament, in one of the last measures of the second degree, (fI AwAxr AlvAnyp,) [the degrees of heat and cold and dryness and moistness being four,] the best of which are the white and soft, inclining to yellow: it is fattening, strengthening to the limbs or members, of use in cases of fracture and contusion, applied in a bandage, and drunk; also for the gout (niqoris), and spasmodic contraction (taXan-uj); and softens hardness of the joints; and improves the voice, and clears the throat and lungs; and excites to sexual intercourse. Some say, that it is [the name of] the roots of the wild pomegranate; but this assertion is not of established authority. Others say, that it is a kind of suwranojaAn; and this is not improbable. The hakeem [Dáood] says, in the Tedhkireh, mgAv is [the name of] a certain plant in El-Kerej (Alkrj) and the parts adjacent; roots extending deep into the earth, and thick, with a rind inclining to black and red, which, when peeled off, discloses a substance, between white and yellow: the best thereof is the heavy, sweet-scented, in taste inclining to sweet, with a slight bitterness. It is said to have rough, or coarse, and wide, leaves, like those of the radish; and a white flower; and seeds resembling the grains of the sumonap, and called qlql: hence it has been imagined to be the pomegranate: and it is said to be a species of swrnjAn: its strength, or virtue, lasts about seven years: and there is a kind of it brought from 'Abbádán, and towards Syria, weak in operation; and it is this which is used in Egypt. (TA.) [M. Rouyer, in the Descr. de l'Egypte, tome 11 of the sec. ed., p. 452, describes it as follows: a root of a whitish colour, mucilaginous, fleshy, or pulpous, and of an aromatic odour: it is nutritive and aphrodisiac: it is taken in the simple substance; and they make of it a sherbet, which should be drunk hot: this root comes from the Indies.]
magiyvN and mamoguwvN↓ Herbage laid prostrate by rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) herbage that is rained upon, and rendered yellow, and bad-tasted, and laid prostrate by the rain. (TA.)
See magivN.
mamoguwvN Affected by a fever. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See magiyvN.
mumaAgivN: see magivN.
1. magaja AlfaSiylu DaroEa Oum-ihi: see mEj.

hom.sense: 1. magada, aor. _a {yamogadu}, (inf. n. magodN, Ṣ, L,) He (a child, and a lamb or kid, Ṣ, L, and a young camel, L, Ḳ) sucked his mother: he (a young camel) struck his mother in her udder with his head, and sucked her: and he (a lamb or kid) took the teat of his mother in his mouth to suck; (L;) as also maEaca, with the unpointed E and the pointed c. (IḲṭṭ.)

magada He sucked, or sucked in, a thing: (Ḳ:) he sucked, or sucked in, the inside of Sarabap, i. e., [a piece of] the gum of the TaloH; for there is sometimes in the inner part thereof what resembles glue and the honey of dates or bees. (Ṣ, L.) See also magodN, below.
magada, aor. _a {yamogadu}, inf. n. magodN; (L, Ḳ;) and magida, aor. _a {yamogadu}, (L,) inf. n. magadN; (L, Ḳ;) He, (L,) or it, (the body, Ḳ,) became full and fat. (L, Ḳ.)

magadahu, (aor. _a {yamogadu}, inf. n. magodN, Ṣ, L.) It (a pleasant, or an ample, and easy, life) nourished him: (AZ, IAạr, Ṣ, L:) or it (a life, or manner of living) nourished him, and rendered him in a state of amplitude and ease. (Ḳ.)
magada He (a man, L) and it (a plant, L, Ḳ, or other thing, Ḳ, or anything, L) became tall. (Aboo-Málik, L, Ḳ.)

magada fiI EayoXK naAEimK, (aor. _a {yamogadu}, inf. n. magodN, Ṣ, L,) a phrase mentioned by Fr, (Ṣ,) He (a man) lived, and enjoyed abundant comforts, or luxury, in a pleasant, or an ample and easy, state of life. (Ḳ.)
magadahu It (youth) caused him still to flourish, or to be in the flower of age. (En-Naḍr, L.)
magada He became in the full prime of youth. (L.)
magada, aor. _a {yamogadu}, inf. n. magoda, He plucked out hair: (L:) as also maEada. (L, art. mEd.)
magada mawoDiEa Algur-api He plucked out the hair in the place of the blaze, or white mark on the forehead or face, of a horse, in order that it might become gray. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. Amgdt She (a woman) suckled her child; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and a she camel, &c., her young one. (Ṣ, L.)
Amgd, (inf. n. UimogaAdN, L,) He (a man, Ṣ, L,) drank much, or abundantly: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or he drank long. (AḤn, L.)

hom.sense: magodN The flower, or flourishing period, of youth. (En-Naḍr, L.)
Soft; tender; delicate: pleasant; easy and ample: syn. naAEimN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) applied to the period of youth: (Ṣ, L:) and to life, or a manner of living. (L.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or magodu Aljisomi, (L,) Soft and plump: applied to a camel: (L, Ḳ:) or (so in the L; in the Ḳ, and) big, or bulky; (L, Ḳ;) as also maEodN; (L;) and tall: (Ḳ:) applied to anything. (L.)

magodN, applied to the gur-ap, or blaze, on the forehead or face of a horse; app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; Having the hair plucked out in order that it may become gray: (L:) the term magodN is used with relation to the blaze of a horse when it appears as though it were swollen; for the hair is plucked out in order that it may grow white: (Ṣ, L:) and with relation to the forelock, when it is as though burnt. (L.)

magodN (L, Ḳ) and magadN↓ (L) The fruit of the [tree called] tanoDub: or (so in the L; but in the Ḳ, and) the [plant called] luf-aAH [q. v.]: (L, Ḳ:) or the wild lf-AH: (L:) or, both words, (so in the L; but in the Ḳ, and) the [plant called] baAcinojaAn: (L, Ḳ:) or a plant resembling the nAcnjAn, growing at the roots of the EiDah: (L:) and the former word, a fruit resembling the cucumber, (Aboo-Saʼeed, L, Ḳ,) which is eaten: (Aboo-Saʼeed, L:) or a kind of tree that twines about other trees, more slender than the vine, having long, thin, and soft, leaves, and producing a fruit like that of the banana, but thinner in the peel and more juicy, which is sweet, and is not peeled [to be eaten], with pips like those of the apple; people share this fruit among themselves, taking it by turns, alighting where it grows, and eating it; it appears first green; then becomes yellow; and then, at last, green [again, or probably red; for I think that yxDr-, in the L, from which this is taken, is a mistake for yHmr-]: the word is a coll. gen. n.: [and] the n. un. is with p {magodapN}: (AḤn, L:) ISd says, I have not heard magadapN; but magadN↓ may be a quasi-pl. n. of magodapN; like as HalaqN is of HaloqapN, and falakN of falokapN. (L.)
magodN i. q. SarabapN, meaning as explained above, at 1: (Ṣ, L,) also, the gum of the lote-tree, sidor: (Aboo-Saʼeed, L:) or, of the lok-tree of the desert. (Ṣ, L.)

entry.sense: magadN: see magodN.
2. mg-rhu He dyed it (namely a garment or piece of cloth) with magorap. (A.)

magarN and mugorapN↓ (Ḳ, TA) A colour inclining to red: (TA:) or a colour not pure red, (Ḳ, TA,) nor inclining to yellow; its redness being like the colour of magorap↓: (TA:) or i. q. XuqorapN [i. e., in a man, ruddiness of complexion combined with fairness, and in a horse, a sorrel colour,] with duskiness, or dinginess. (Ḳ.) See also Oamogaru.
magorapN [Red ochre, called in the present day mugorap;] red earth, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with which one dyes [and paints]; (TA;) well known; (A;) as also magarapN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mugorapN: see magarN.
magarapN: see magorapN.

Oamogaru i. q. OaXoqaru, (A, Mṣb,) applied to a man [and signifying Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness], (A,) and to a horse [and signifying of a sorrel colour]: (A, Mṣb:) or red in the hair and skin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the colour of magorap: (Ṣ:) and having redness in the face, with clear whiteness: (Ḳ:) or white, or white in face: as also OaHomaru: applied to a man: (TA:) and, applied to a horse, of a colour inclining to OaXoqar [or sorrel]; i. e. having his XuqorapN [or sorrel colour] tinged over with duskiness, or dinginess: (Ṣ:) and applied to a camel, of the colour of magorap: (Ḳ:) and so applied to a horse: or a horse not of a pure red colour, nor of a colour inclining to yellow, but of a red colour, like the colour of magorap, and having the mane and forelock and ears like the [red] colour termed Suhobap, without any whiteness: (TA:) [see also magarN:] the fem. is magoraMCu: and the dim. Oamayogiru. (TA.)
mamogarapN Land whence magorap comes forth, or is procured. (TA.)
mumag-arN A garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) dyed with magorap. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. [magaSahu, inf. n. magoSN, He pierced him with a spear or the like: for] magoSN is syn. with TaEonN; as also magosN. (TA.)

[Hence, perhaps,] mugiSa, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [of which magoSN, which see below, is app. the inf. n.] and magiSa, (A, Mṣb, [in a copy of the former of which, instead of the former verb, I find maguSa, but this is probably a mistranscription,]) inf. n. magaSN; (Mṣb;) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb,) had what is termed magoSN as explained below; (ISk, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also mugisa and magisa: (IḲooṭ, Mṣb:) and maEiSa: (TA:) [it is most commonly with g and S; but Z says, that] the original word is with s, from magasahu signifying TaEanahu. (A.)

entry.sense: 5. tmg-S baToniI, and tamag-aSaniI, My belly pained me; as also tmg-s, with s. (TA.) [In the CK, we find tmg-S baTonahu, explained by OawojaEahu, as though signifying It pained his belly: but baTonahu is doubtless a mistake for baTonuhu. In MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, I do not find this verb.]
And [hence,] tamag-aSaniI AlX-aIoCu † The thing hurt me: and in like manner, tamag-aSotu minohu † [I was hurt by it]. (TA.)

magoSN (ISk, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and magaSN; (IDr, A, Ḳ;) but the former is the chaste word; (A;) or the latter, accord. to ISk, is vulgar, (Ṣ,) and Az pronounces him right in saying so, (Mṣb,) and Yaạḳoob disallows the latter word. wherefore the author of the Ḳ is wrong in imputing error, in this matter, [if error it be,] to J; (TA;) [Colic; or] pain in the belly, (A, Ḳ,) and griping (taqoTiyEN) in the bowels; (A;) or griping (tqTyE) in the bowels, and pain [therein]; (Ṣ;) or pain in the bowels, and contortion [therein]; (Mṣb;) as also magosN. (Yaạḳoob, TA.)
mamoguwSN A man (Ṣ, Mṣb) having what is termed magoSN as explained above. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

magonaTiysN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or magoniyTisN, (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and magoniyTiysN (CK) and magonaATiysN (Ḳ)
[The magnet;] a certain stone that attracts iron: arabicized [from the Greek μαγνῆτις]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Mentioned in Ṣ, L, Ḳ, in art. gTs; but, as observed in the TA, it should have a separate place.]

maAqiYN and muwqiYN The posterior, or, as some say, anterior, part of the eye: (Ḳ:) or the inner angle of the eye, next the nose. (Ḳ, &c., art. mOq.) Mentioned by most of the lexicographers in art. mOq, q. v. (TA.)

1. maqatahu, (aor. _u {yamoqutu}, Msb,) inf. n. maqotN (and, accord. to the Ḳ, maqaAtapN; but this is the inf. n. of maquta, q. v.; TA) He hated him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also mq-th↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tamoqiytN; (TA;) [but this has, probably, an intensive signification;] or he hated him on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he hated him with the most violent hatred, (Zj, M, Er-Rághib, Mṣb,) on account of a foul action. (Mṣb.)

maquta UilaI Aln-aAsi, aor. _u {yamoqutu}, inf. n. maqaAtapN, He was hateful, or an object of hatred, to men, on account of a foul action that he had committed: (Lth:) or he was hateful, or an object of hatred, in the utmost degree, (M, Mṣb,) on account of a foul action. (Mṣb.)
2: see 1.
3. maAqatahu He hated him [or hated him in the utmost degree] reciprocally, on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.)
maAqatuwA [They bore hatred, one to another.] (TA, art. bht.)
4. maA Oamoqatahu EinodiI How hated, or hateful, or odious, is he to me! (Sb, Ḳ.)
maA OamoqataniI lahu How I hate him! (Sb, Ḳ.)
5. tmq-t Uilayohi He showed, or manifested, hatred [or the utmost hatred] to him: contr. of tHb-b Uilayohi. (A.)
6. tmAqtwA They hated one another, [or hated one another in the utmost degree,] on account of some foul, or evil, affair. (A.)

nikaAHu Almaqoti The marrying the wife of one's father after him; (Ḳ;) that is, after his having divorced her or died: (TA:) this was done in the time of paganism, (Ṣ,) and was then thus called; maqotN signifying the “most violent hatred:” it is forbidden in the Ḳur, iv. 26. (Zj.)
maqotiI-F A man who has contracted the kind of marriage termed nkAH Almqt: (ISd, Ḳ:) or the son of such a man. (Zj, Ḳ.)

maqiytN and mamoquwtN↓ Hated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former signifies hateful, and the latter hated: (MF:) [or hateful, and hated, on account of his having committed a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned by Lth: or hateful, and hated, in the utmost degree, on account of a foul action: in this sense mqyt is mentioned in the Mṣb.]
mamoquwtN: see maqiytN.

maqadiI-N A certain kind of beverage, prepared from honey, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) which the Khaleefehs of the sons of Umeyyeh used to drink: (L:) so called in relation to a town in Syria, (Ṣ, L,) called maqadN; or in relation to a town in Syria in the province of El-Urdunn: (L:) or this is a mistake; for the name of the town is with teshdeed [maqad-N]: IB says, that the orthography of the word as best known to the lexicologists is maqadiI-N, without teshdeed; but that AʼObeyd and others write it with teshdeed; and that IAmb cites in confirmation of its being thus a verse of ʼAmr Ibn-Maadeekerib, at the end of which occurs the expression Xagaluwhu Eano Xarobi Almaqad-i; without I; [app. for maqad-iI;] adding, that it is thus called in relation to maqad-N, a town of Damascus, in the mountain overlooking El-Ghór: (L:) AʼObeyd says, I hold it to be correctly maqad-iI-N; and I heard Rejà Ibn-Selemeh explain this as signifying “wine diminished to half its quantity by boiling;” as though it were divided (qud-a) in halves: (Sh, L:) IB adds, that Aboo-t-Teyyib the lexicologist says, that the word in question is with d without teshdeed; from maqadN; and is only written with teshdeed by poetic licence: and in confirmation of this assertion, IB cites verses in which the name of the town and that of the beverage are written without teshdeed. (L.)
vawobN maqadiI-N A certain well-known kind of cloth, or garment: (L, TA:) you say viyaAbN maqadiy-apN. (Ḳ. [In the CK, erroneously, maqad-iy-apN.])

hom.sense: 1. maqira, aor. _a {yamoqaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. maqarN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It was, or became, bitter; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Amqr↓, (ISk, IḲṭṭ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UimoqaArN: (Mṣb:) or sour, or acid: (Ḳ:) and Amqr↓, said of milk, (AZ, A, Ḳ,) it became almost bitter, by reason of its quality of biting the tongue: (A:) or lost its [proper] flavour (AZ, Ḳ) by becoming intensely sour or acid. (AZ, TA.)

maqara Eunuqaha, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoquru}, inf. n. maqorN, (ISk, Ṣ,) He bruised his neck: (Ṣ, A:) or beat it with a staff or stick, so as to break the bone in pieces, leaving the skin whole. (A, Ḳ.)
And hence, (A,) maqara Als-amakapa AlmaAliHapa He macerated the salt fish in vinegar; (A, Ḳ;) as also Amqr↓. (Ḳ.) And in like manner you say of anything that you macerate. (TA.)
4: see 1, in three places.
Oamoqarotu lifulaAnK XaraAbFA I made beverage bitter to, or for, such a one. (IDrd.)

entry.sense: maqorN: see maqirN, in three places.

maqirN Bitter; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also maqorN↓ (TA) and mumoqirN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and yamoquwrN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or sour; acid; as also mumoqirN↓: (Ḳ:) which last also signifies intensely sour or acid; (AZ, Aboo-Málik, Ṣ;*) applied to milk: (the same, and Ḳ:) or sour, or acid, milk. (Mṣb.)

Aloes; syn. SabirN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also maqorN↓: (Ṣ:) or a certain thing resembling it: (IḲt, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or poison: as also maqorN↓; (Ḳ;) which is said by some to be a form used by poetic license: (TA:) or, accord. to AA, a certain bitter kind of tree: and accord. to AḤn, a certain plant, which grows in leaves without branches. (TA.) [See SaqirN.]
mumoqirN: see maqirN, in two places.

samakN mamoquwrN Fish macerated in vinegar and salt, so as to become a cold sauce or fluid seasoning: (Az, TA:) or sour, or acid, fish: (IAạr, TA:) or fish bruised (yumoqaru) in water and salt: you should not say manoquwrN. (Ṣ.)
yamoquwrN: see maqirN.
maAqiTN The freedman of a freedman: (Ḳ:) or the slave of a slave of a freedman: whence the Arabs say, in reviling, fulaAnN saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (Ṣ.) See art. sqT.
muq-aATN [which is its pl.] like suq-aATN and luq-aATN, signifies, accord. to IAạr, The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, or mankind, or of people. (TA in art. xXr.)
makoCN The hole of a fox, or of a hare, or rabbit: or, accord. to Th, the hole of the kind of lizard called Dab-. (L.)

1. makata, [aor. _u {yamokutu},] He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (Ḳ:) like makada: accord. to some, a word mispronounced: accord. to others for makava; the v being changed into t. (TA.)
10. Uisotamokatati Albavorapu The pustule became filled with pus, or matter. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

1. makava, aor. _u {yamokuvu}; and makuva, aor. _u {yamokuvu}; inf. n. makovN [with which mukovN and mikvN (see below) are syn.] and mik-iyvaI (Ṣ, Ḳ) [like xiS-iySaI, q. v.,] and mik-iyvaMCu [like xiS-iySaMCu] and makavN and mukuwvN and mukovaAnN (Ḳ) and makaAvN and makaAvapN [which last is the inf. n. of makuva]; (TA;) He tarried; tarried and waited, or expected; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) was patient, and tarried, and waited, or expected: or he tarried, stayed, or stopped, expecting: loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation; fiI makaAnK in a place. (TA.) [In like manner,] tmk-v↓ He loitered; tarried; stayed; waited; paused in expectation. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
mukovN and mikovN↓, substs., from makava or makuva, A tarrying; tarrying and waiting, or expecting;, &c. (Ṣ, A.)
mikovN: see mukovN.
makiyvN Grave: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) who does not hasten in his affair: pl. mukavaMCu and makiyvuwna. (TA.)
makiyvu AlkalaAmi ‡ Slow of speech. (Ibn-Abi-l- Hadeed.)
Also makiyvN A man remaining; staying; abiding; remaining fixed, or stationary. (TA.)
saAra Alr-ajulu mutamak-ivFA The man journeyed, or proceeded, loitering; syn. mutalaw-imFA. (Ṣ.)
1. makada, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamokudu}, (L,) inf. n. mukuwdN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and makodN, (Ḳ,) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) bimakaAnK in a place; (Ṣ, L;) as also makata. (TA.)
maAkidN Water (L) lasting, or continuing, (L, Ḳ,) unceasingly. (Ḳ.)

naAqapN maAkidapN A she-camel abounding with milk; as also makodaMCu↓: (Ḳ:) or constantly, or always, abounding with milk; (L;) as also makodaMCu↓ (Ṣ, L;) and makuwdN↓: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) like nakodaMCu: (Ṣ, L:) pl. of makuwdN, mukodN, (Ḳ,) or mukudN, and makaAYidu. (L.)

biYorN maAkidapN, and makuwdN↓ A well having a constant, or unceasing, supply of water: (L:) and rakiy-apN maAkidapN a well whereof the water remains without diminution [to which is added EalaI qaroni wAHidK laA yatagay-aru waAlqaronu qaronu AlqaAmapi, app. meaning, of the measure of one qaron, not changing; by qrn being meant the structure of stone which supports the wood whereto the pulley is suspended, and which is described as being of the proportion of a man]. (Ṣ, L.)
wud-N maAkidN ‡ Unceasing love or affection. (L.)
makuwdN: see maAkidN.
makodaMCu: see maAkidN.

1. makara, aor. _u {yamokuru}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. makorN; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Amkr↓; (Mṣb;) He practised deceit, guile, or circumvention; or he practised deceit, guile, or circumvention, desiring to do to another a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded; syn. xadaEa; (Mṣb;) and of the inf. n. xadiyEapN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) he practised an evasion or elusion, a shift, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a machination, a trick, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient; he plotted; or he exercised art, craft, cunning, or skill, in the management or ordering of affairs, with excel-lent consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will; syn. of the inf. n. UiHotiyaAlN: (Ṣ, TA:) or to this explanation, conveyed by AHtyAl as the syn. of the inf. n., should be added secretly, or privately: (Lth, TA:) makorN is praised or dispraised according to the nature of its object. (El-Basáir.) [For further explanation, see what follows.]

It is trans. by means of bi: and also, accord. to Z, by itself: (MF:) [but I know not any instance of its being trans. by itself: except as meaning he plotted a thing: see makora Als-ay-iY in the Ḳur, xxxv. 41, cited voce say-iYN:] you say makara bihi, (Ṣ, A, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning, He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; or he deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him, and desired to do him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded:, &c.: (Ṣ, A, TA:) syn. kaAdahu: or it differs [somewhat] from kAdh, accord. to Aboo-Hilál El-'Askeree: (TA:) some say, that mkr bh signifies as above with the addition of feigning the contrary of his real intentions; which kAdh does not imply: or this latter signifies “he did him harm,” or “mischief;” and the former, he did him harm, or mischief, clandestinely. (MF, voce kAd.) See art. xdE.
makara also signifies He managed with thought, or consideration, or acted with policy, and practised stratagem, in war. (TA.)

makara Qll-ehu and Oamokara↓ are syn., (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb,) signifying, ‡ God recompensed, or requited, for makor [or the practising deceit,, &c.]: (Lth,* Mṣb, TA:*) or makoru Qll-ehi signifies God's granting a man respite or delay, and enabling him to accomplish his worldly aims [so as to bring upon himself the punishment due to his evil actions]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, God's causing his trials to befall his enemies, exclusively of his friends: or his taking men by little and little, so that they do not reckon upon it, bestowing upon them renewed favours for acts of obedience which are imagined to be accepted whereas they are rejected. (TA.)
3. mAkrhu He practised with him mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention;, &c.; (A,* TA;) syn. xaAdaEahu. (TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
6. tmAkrwA They practised mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention;, &c. (A,* TA.)
makuwrN: see maAkirN.
mak-aArN: see maAkirN.

maAkirN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mak-aArN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and makuwrN↓ (Ḳ) epithets from makara: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [the first signifying Practising deceit, guile, or circumvention;, &c.: and the second and third, practising the same much, or frequently; deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; a trickster, or crafty knave.]

1. makasa, aor. _i {yamokisu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. makosN, (Sh, A, Ḳ,) He diminished, or deducted from, a thing; (Sh,* A,* Ḳ,* TḲ;) syn. of the inf. n. taqoSN. (Sh, A, Ḳ.) Thus Sh explains makos in the saying of Jábir Ibn-Jinnee Et-Taghlibee:
OafiI kul-i OasowaAqi AlEiraAqi UitaAwapN
wafiI kul-i maA baAEa QmoruWN makosu dirohami
[Is there bribing in every one of the markets of El-'Irák, and in the case of everything that a man has sold the deducting of a dirhem?]. (TA.) [Hence,] you say, makasa fiI AlbayoEi, aor. and inf. n. as above; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and mAks↓, inf. n. mumaAkasapN and mikaAsN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) both signify He diminished, or deducted from, the price in the selling, or buying: (Mṣb:) or both signify he desired, or demanded, a diminution of, or deduction from, the price in selling or buying: (Mgh, TA,*) or the former signifies he collected property in selling or buying: (Ḳ: [but from what I find in the other lexicons, I think it probable that an early copyist has perverted the text of the Ḳ here by making a transposition; writing makasa fiI AlbayoEi yamokisu makosFA jabaI maAlFA wAalmakosu Aln-aqoSu waAlZ-ulomu for makasa yamokisu makosFA jabaI maAlFA waAlmakosu fI AlbayoEi Aln-aqoSu waAlZ-ulomu: in the TḲ we find jnI mAlA, which is certainly a mistake:])
or makosN signifies the diminishing (UinotiqaAS) of the price of a commodity: (M, TA:) and mikaAsN↓, the acting with mutual niggardliness in bargaining; or, accord. to EshShereeshee, the vying in acuteness between a seller and buyer, the former demanding a price and the latter offering less, time after time, until they agree to a reduced price. (Ḥar, p. 586.) You say also, mukisa, meaning, He (a man) suffered a diminution, or deduction, in selling or buying and the like. (TA.)

[Hence, perhaps, or the reverse may be the case,] He wronged a man; treated him, or used him, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically. (A,* Ḳ,* TḲ. [In the first and second, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned.])

[Hence, also, app.,] He (the mak-aAs, Mgh, Mṣb) collected a tax; syn. jabaI; [particularly, the tax termed makos:] (Ṣ,* M, Mgh,* Mṣb [in the first and third of which, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is mentioned:]) or he collected property. (A.) Hence the saying, (Mgh,) in a trad., (Ṣ,) laA yadojulu SaAHibu makosK Aljan-apa (Ṣ, Mgh) [The taker of the tax termed mks will not enter paradise]; meaning, the EaX-aAr. (TA.)
3. mAks fiI AlbayoEi: see 1.

mAkshu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mumaAkasapN [and mikaAsN], (TA,) He acted with him in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner; syn. XaAH-ahu: (Ḳ: but in some copies, XaAkasahu. TA,) or mAkshu fI AlbayoEi signifies he contended with him [by bidding against him or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.) [See, in art. kys, voce kaAsa, an ex. from a trad., accord. to one reading thereof.]

6. tmAksA They acted in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner, each with the other, in bargaining: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or tmAkswA fiI AlbayoEi they contended, one with another, [by outbidding or otherwise] in the sale. (MA.)

makosN, an inf. n., (see 1,) used as a subst., (Mgh, Mṣb,) Money that used to be taken from the seller of commodities in the markets in the time of ignorance: (IDrd, M, Ḳ:) and a dirhem which the collector of the poor-rate used to take after he had finished the receipt of that tribute: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or what is taken by the EaX-aAr, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or maAkis, (Ṣ,) or mak-aAs: (Mgh, Mṣb:) so [accord. to some] in the verse above cited: (Ṣ:) the tax, or impost, which he used to take: (TA:) and generally, what the Sultán's guards take wrongfully on an occasion of buying and selling: so [accord. to some] in the verse cited above: (Mṣb:) pl. mukuwsN. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.)
mak-aAsN (A, Mgh, Mṣb) and maAksN↓ (Ṣ) One who takes, or receives, what is termed makos: (Mgh, Mṣb;) i. e., (Mgh,) i. q. EaX-aArN. (Ṣ, Mgh.)
maAkisN: see mak-aAsN.

1. malaOa, aor. _a {yamolaOu}, inf. n. maloCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maloOapN and miloOapN; (Ḳ;) and maliYa; (TA;) and ml-O↓, inf. n. tamoliYapN; (Ḳ;) He filled (Ḳ;) a vessel, &c. (Ṣ, TA.) You may also say malaOotuhu malFA, for maloYFA, (TA.)
malaOa AlEayona ‡ He satisfied [or glutted] the eye by his comeliness of aspect. (TA.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce EaqibN.
malaOotu minohu EayoniI ‡ [I satisfied, or glutted, my eye by the sight of his comeliness]. (TA.)

maluWa, aor. _u {yamoluOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. malaMCapN and malaMCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and malaOa, aor. _a {yamolaOu}; (Ḳ;) the former is that which commonly obtains; (TA;) He became rich, wealthy, &c., syn. SaAra maliyYFA. (Ḳ.)
kalimapN tamolaOu Alfama † [A word, or saying, that fills the mouth;] i. e., gross, and abominable; not allowable to be spoken; that fills the mouth so that it cannot articulate. (TA, from a trad.)
UimolaWuwA OafowaACakumo mina AlquroMni † [Fill your mouths with the Ḳur-án]. (TA.)
muliYa ruEobFA, and maluWa rEbA, ‡ He was filled with fright. (A.)
malaOa viyaAbiI ‡ He sprinkled my clothes with mud, &c. (A.) malaOa raAkibahu [He (a camel) bespattered his rider with his ejected cud]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. zrd.)
malaOa EinaAnahu † He made, or urged, his beast to run vehemently. (TA in art. En.)
muliYa, like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] and maluWa, ‡ He had the disease called mulaMCap. (A, Ḳ.)
See 3.
2. ml-O furuwja farasihi He made his horse to run at the utmost rate of the pace termed HuDor. (TA.)
And see 1, and 4.

3. mAlOhu EalaI AlOamori, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mumaAlaOapN; (Ṣ;) and malaOahu↓; (Ḳ;) but this latter the lexicologists do not hold in good repute; (TA;) He aided, or assisted, him, and conformed with him, to do the thing. (IAạr,* AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. AmlO Aln-azoEa fiI qawosihi, (Ṣ,) and AmlO fI qwsh, and ml-O↓ fI qwsh, (Ḳ,) ‡ He pulled his bow to the utmost. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
AmlOhu Qll-ehu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UimolaACN, (TA,) † God affected him with the disease called mulaMCap. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tml-O mina AlT-aEaAmi waAlX-araAbi He became full of food and drink. (Ṣ.)
See 8.
tml-O gayoZFA, and AmtlO↓, ‡ He became filled with rage. (Ṣ.)
tml-O XibaEFA, and AmtlO↓, He became filled to satiety. (TA.)
tml-O He put on himself a mulaMCap; i. e., a covering of the kind so called. (TA.)
6. tamaAlaWuwA EalaI AlOamori They agreed, or conspired together, to do the thing: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) they aided, or assisted, [and conformed with,] one another to do the thing. (TA.)
8. AmtlO and tml-O↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and maliYa, aor. _a {yamolaOu}; (Ḳ;) It (a vessel, &c., TA) became full. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 5.

AmtlO XabaAbFA † [He became full of sap, or vigour, or youth, or young manhood]. (The Lexicons, &c., passim.) And AmtlO AlX-abaAbu † [The sap, or vigour, of youth, or young manhood, became full, or mantled, in a person.] (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. gTI.) [And AmtlO, alone, He was, or became, plump.]
AmtlO EinaAnuhu † The utmost of his power, or ability, was accomplished. (TA in art. En.)

10. AstmlO fiI Ald-ayoni signifies jaEala dayonahu fiI mulaOLCa (CK, and a MṢ copy of the Ḳ) [app., He made wealthy persons, or honest wealthy persons, his debtors: but in one copy of the Ḳ, for mulaOLCa, we find mulaMCK, which affords no sense that seems admissible here: and in another, diyn seems to be put in the place of dayon, in both the above instances; and malaMCK in that of mulaOLCa; for Golius renders the phrase AstmlO fI Aldyn by opulentiæ studuit in religione sua: i. e., religionem suam in illa posuit: a meaning which IbrD rejects].
miloCN [A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of a vessel, &c., or] the quantity that a vessel, &c., holds when it is filled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OaEoTihi miloOahu wamiloOayohi wavalaAvapa OamolaMYihi Give it (i. e., the cup, TA) what will fill it; and what will twice fill it; and what will thrice fill it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
HajarN miloCu Alkaf-i A stone that fills the hand. (TA.)
laka AlHamodu miloCu Als-amawaAti waAlOaroDi To Thee be praise that shall fill the heavens and the earth. (TA.)
miloCu kisaAYihaA A fat woman; that fills her ksAC when she covers herself with it. (TA, from a trad.)
malaON An assembly, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) absolutely, (TA,) [whether of nobles or others]: pl. OamolaMCN. (IAạr.)

Nobles; chiefs; princes; syn. OaXoraAfN and EiloyapN; (Ḳ;) principal persons; persons whose opinion is respected. (TA.) (AlmalaOu AlOaEloIa [The most exalted princes; i. e.] the angels that are admitted near [to the presence of God]; or the archangels. TA.) See samEahu, for other explanations.

A people of comely appearance, figure, attire, or adornment, united for some purpose or design; expl. by qawomN cw AlX-aArapi wAlt-ajam-uEi liloUiraAdapi: (Abu-l-Ḥasan, Ḳ:) [but this is wrong, see Beyd, ii. 247.]
Thus it is of a different class from rahaTN, though, like this word, a quasi-pl. n. It is an epithet in which the quality of a substantive predominates. (Abu-l-Ḥasan.)

‡ Consultation. (Ḳ.) [You say,] maA kaAna hecaA AlOamoru Eano malaUK min-aA ‡ This thing was not the result of a consultation and consent on our part: [and] OakaAna hecaA Eano malaUK minokumo ‡ Was this the result of a consultation of your nobles, and of your assembly? said by ʼOmar when he was stabbed: asserted to be tropical in this sense by Z and others. (TA.) taHad-avuwA malaOF They conversed, consulting together. (Ṣ.)
Opinion. (Ḳ.) [See a supposed example below.]

Disposition; nature; manners; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a nature rich in needful qualities: (T:) pl. OamolaMCN. (Ṣ.) [You say,] maA OaHosana malaOa baniI fulaAnK How good are the dispositions, or manners, and conversation, of the sons of such a one! (Ṣ.) El-Juhanee says,
tanaAdawoA yaAla buhovapa Uico raOawonaA
faqulonaA OaHosiniI malaOF juhayonaA : (Ṣ) [They called out, one to another, O Buhtheh! come to our aid! when they saw us: and we said,] Be of good disposition, or manners, O Juheyneh! or, accord. to some, Be of good opinion, O Juheyneh! (see above:) or, as some say, Aid well, O Juheyneh! taking mlO in the sense of mumaAlaOapF: [see 3]. (TA.)
OaHosinuwA OamolaMCa kumo Amend your manners; or have good manners. From a trad. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also malaON A coveting. (Ḳ.)
muloOapN A tremulousness and flabbiness and swelling of the flesh, in a camel, in consequence of long confinement after a journey. (Ḳ.)
See mulaMCapN.
miloOapN The manner in which a thing is filled. (Ḳ.) [You say,] Uin-ahu laHasanu AlmiloOapi (not Alt-amal-uWi) Verily it is well filled. (Ḳ.)
miloOapN An oppression occasioned by repletion with food. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also mulaMCapN.]
malaMCN and malaMCapN↓ Richness, wealthiness, &c.: (Ḳ:) or trustiness, or honest. (Ṣ.) [See maliIoCN.]
mulaMCN: see mulaMCapN.

maliIoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also written and pronounced maliI-N, (Nh,) A rich, wealthy, opulent, man: (Ḳ:) or trusty, or honest: (Ṣ:) or trusty, or honest, and rich: (TA:) or a rich man, or one not literally rich, who is honest, and pays his debts well, without giving trouble to his creditor: (Ḳ,* TA:) or an able, rich, man: (Mṣb:) [a solvent man:] pl. milaMCN and OamoliYaMCu and mulaOLCu. (Ḳ.)
Also mulaOLCu Chiefs: so called because rich in needful things. (TA.)

hom.sense: mulaMCapN (Ḳ) and muloOapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mulaMCN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ A defluxion, or rheum, syn. zukaAmN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) occasioned by repletion, or a heaviness in the head, like a defluxion, or rheum, (zkAm,) from repletion of the stomach. (A.) [See also miloOapN.]

mulaMCapN A piece of drapery which is wrapped about the body; i. q., UizaArN (TA) and rayoTapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the mlACp is a covering for the body formed of two pieces; (TA;) composed of two oblong pieces of cloth sewed together; (Mṣb, in art. lgq;) and the ryTp is of a single piece. (TA.) [It appears to have been generally yellow, (see warosN, and Oaworasa,) and was probably otherwise similar to the modern milaAyap, which is described and represented in my work on the Modern Egyptians, part i., ch. 1.] Pl. mulaMCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.; or a coll. gen. n., of which mlACp is the n. un.;] or, accord. to some, mulaON; but the former is better established. (TA.) Dim. mulayoYapN; for which mulay-apN was also used, accord. to a tradition. (TA.)
mulaMCapu AlHusoni ‡ Fairness of complexion. (TA.)
AlmulaMCu↓ AlmaHoDu ‡ Simple dust. (TA.)
Also mulaMCapN The skim that forms on the surface of milk. (El-Moajam.)

entry.sense: maloMnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) [and maloMnu, as it forms in the] fem. maloMnapN (Ḳ) and maloOaI; (Ṣ;) pl. milaMCN; (Ḳ;) Full: (Ṣ, Ḳ) said of a vessel, &c. (Ṣ, TA.) The masc. is also written and pronounced malaAn; and the fem., malaA: (TA:) and the vulgar say UinaACN malaA A full vessel. (Ṣ, TA.)
maloMnN mn Alkarami ‡ [Full of generosity]. (TA.)
See mamoluwoCN.
maAliYN ‡ A majestic person: one whose aspect satisfies the eye. (TA.)
maAliYN AlEayoni, and maAliYN liloEayoni, ‡ A person whose aspect satisfies the eye by his comeliness, &c. (TA.)
fulaAnN OamolaOu liEayoniI mino fulaAnK ‡ Such a one is more satisfactory to my eye by his comeliness than such a one. (TA.)
hecaA AlOamoru OamolaOu bika This thing is better for thee, and more satisfactory: expl. by Oamolaku [which is said to have this signification]. (TA.)
mamoluwoCN, pass. part. n. of malaOa, Filled. (Ṣ.)
Also, † Having the disease called mulaMCap: as part. n. of maliYa. (A.)

Also, (and accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, maloMn↓,) Affected by God with that disease: extr. [with respect to rule], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as it is used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of OamolaOa: by rule it should be mumolaON. (TA.)
mumoliYN An ewe in whose belly are water and matter [such seems to be the meaning of OagoraAsN in the explanation] so that one thinks her to be pregnant. (Ḳ.)
XaAb-N mumotaliYN [A youth in the full bloom of his age. See art. EaboEabN.]
malaAbN: see art. lwb, in which, as well as here, it is mentioned in the Ḳ.

1. malata, aor. _i {yamolitu}. (inf. n. malotN, TA.) He put [a thing] in motion, or into a state of commotion: (ISd, Ḳ:) like matala: also mentioned by IDrd, who expresses uncertainty as to its correctness. (TA.)
mil-iytN i. q. snofu Almaroxi; (Ḳ;) i. e., The leaves of the tree called marox. (TA.)
OamoluwtN an epithet applied to a mafaAzap [or water-less desert]. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ.)
OamaAliytu Swift camels. (Ḳ.) It is said to be a quasi-pl. n.: or a pl. that has no sing.: or its sing. is OumoluwtN or UimaliytN: some of the lexicologists reject it. (MF.)

1. malavahu, aor. _u {yamoluvu}, inf. n. malovN, He soothed, or tranquilized his mind, with words; spoke to him sweetly, or pleasantly; soothed him with agreeable words; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not meaning to fulfil his words: as also malacahu, aor. _u {yamoluvu}, inf. n. malocN: (TA:) ex. saOalotuhu HaAjapF famalavaniI I asked him to do a thing that I wanted, and he soothed my mind by a promise, not meaning to fulfil it. (A.)

In like manner, He made him a promise, (as though he would repel him from him, Ṣ,) not meaning to fulfil it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Accord. to Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, He made him a concealed promise: but this is a strange explanation. (MF.)
malava, inf. n. malovN, He lied; as also malaca. (TA, art. mlc.)
malava AlZ-alaAmu The darkness became mixed with the light: this happens at nightfall and at daybreak. (AZ.)
malavahu biAlX-ar-i He aspersed him, or bespattered him with evil. (A.)
malavahu, [aor. _u {yamoluvu},] inf. n. malovN, He beat him lightly; (Ḳ;) like magavahu, q. v. (TA.)
malava He (a hare, TḲ,) was unable to run; too weak to run. (Ḳ.)
3. mAlvhu, (inf. n. milaAvN, TA,) He treated him with dissimulation, and jested, or joked, with him. (Ḳ.)

malovN and malavN↓ and mulovapN↓ The first, or commencement, of the blackness of night: (Ḳ:) or it is after the sadaf: (TA:) or the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the place of sunset: when it has become intense, and the last EiXaMC has come, it is called malas. (IAạr.)

Oatayotuhu malava↓ AlZ-alaAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and malova AlZlAm, (Ḳ,) and Einoda mlvihi, (TA,) I came to him at the period when the darkness became confused, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and had not yet become very intense, [as it has] when thou sayest Oaxuwka Oami Alc-iYobu [(Is this) thy brother, or the wolf?]; (Ṣ;) i. e. at the time of the prayer of sunset, and after it. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
SlAp Almlvi The prayer of sunset: in the dial. of Rabee'ah. (A.)
maA kaAna Eahoduhu Uil-aA walovFA wawaEoduhu Uil-aA malovFA [His compact was not otherwise than weak, and his promise not otherwise than one not meant to be fulfilled]. (A.)
milovN One who does not become satiated with coitus. (Ḳ.) You say rajulN milovN and UimoraOapN milovN. (TḲ.)
malavN See malotN.
mulovapN See malotN.

1. malaja Oum-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoluju}; and malijahaA, aor. _?; (Ḳ;) inf. n. malojN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He (a child) sucked [the breast of] his mother: (Ṣ:) or he took his mother's teat with the extremity of his mouth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And malaja Aln-aAqapa, said of a young camel, He sucked the she-camel; like salajahaA. (L, TA, in art. slj.)
4. Oamolajatohu Oum-uhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. UimolaAjN, (Ṣ,) His mother suckled him. (Mṣb.) [The masc. form of the verb is mentioned in the Ḳ.]
8. Amtlj He sucked milk: (Ḳ:) or he (a young weaned camel,) sucked what was in the udder. (Ṣ.)
mulujN Sucking kids. (Ḳ.)
malojapN A single suck. (Mṣb.) [See also maloHapN.]
malojaAnu A man who sucks the teats of his camels, (or of his sheep or goats, TA,) by reason of his avarice; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not milking them lest he should be heard: (TA:) as also maS-aAnu. (Ṣ.)
maliyjN A foster-brother; syn. raDiyEN. (Ḳ.)
An illustrious man. (Ḳ.)
maAlajN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and maAlajapN, (Ṣ, in art. syE,) [A plasterer's trowel;] a thing with which one plasters: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an arabicized word, from the Persian, (Ṣ,) [originally maAlaho].
OumoluwjN [Sugar-candy]: see OuboluwjN.
UimolaAjapN A single act of suckling. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., lA tuHar-imu AlUimolaAjapu walaA AlUimolaAjataAni, (Ṣ,) i. e. One act of suckling, or the giving one such, does not bar [the two parties from marrying each other], nor do two acts of suckling, or the giving two sucks, like as complete suckling does. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. malaHato fulaAnapN lifulaAnK, (aor. _a {yamolaHu} and _u {yamoluHu}, L,) ‡ Such a woman suckled, or gave suck, for such a one. (A, L.)
malaHonaA lifulaAnK, inf. n. maloHN, (Ṣ,) We [meaning the wife of one of us] suckled, or gave suck, for such a one: (Aṣ, L:) or we suckled such a one. (Ṣ.)
malaHa Alwalada [app. He caused the child to be suckled;] syn. with OaroDaEahu. (Ḳ.) [See OaroDaEa.]

maluHa; (L;) and ml-H↓, inf. n. tamoliyHN; and tml-H↓; (L, Ḳ;) the last said to be formed by transposition from tHl-m; but ISd, sees no reason for this assertion; (L;) ‡ He (a camel. L,) became fat. (L, Ḳ.) ml-Ht↓ she (a camel destined for slaughter) became fat: (El-Umawee, Ṣ:) or, became a little fat: (Ḳ:) She (a camel) became fat in a small degree. (L.) Also tml-Ht↓ ‡ They (lizards such as are called DibaAb) became fat; as also tHl-mt. (L.)

maluHa, aor. _u {yamoluHu}, inf. n. muluwHapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and malaAHapN; (Ḳ;) this form of the verb is of the dial. of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh; (Mṣb;) and malaHa, aor. _u {yamoluHu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muluwHN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and malaHa, aor, _a; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and AmlH↓, inf. n. UimolaAHN, of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; (Mṣb;) It (water) was salt: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or AmlH↓ signifies it became salt, having been sweet. (Ḳ.)

maluHa, aor. _u {yamoluHu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. malaAHapN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and muluwHapN (Ṣ) and miloHN, the first of which is the most common, and the last the least common, (TA,) ‡ It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Mṣb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious. (The lexicons passim.)

malaHa Alqidora, aor. _a {yamolaHu} and _i {yamoliHu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. maloHN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He put salt into the cooking-pot: (Ḳ:) or put a proper quantity of salt into it: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) and accord. to Sb, ml-H↓ and AmlH↓ signify the same as malaHa: (ISd:) or mal-aHahaA, inf. n. tamoliyHN, and OamolaHahaA, signify he put much salt into it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that it [meaning its contents] became spoiled. (Ṣ, A.)

malaHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. maloHN; (Ṣ;) and ml-H↓, inf. n. tamolyHN; (TA;) He fed camels or sheep or goats with salt earth, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or with earth and salt, the salt being more in quantity. (TA.) This is done when the animals cannot procure plants of the kind called HamoD. (Ṣ.)
Also ml-Hhu↓, inf. n. tamoliyHN, He rubbed his (a camel's, or sheep's, or goat's,) palate with salt. (TA.)

maliHa, aor. _a {yamolaHu}, inf. n. malaHN, ‡ He, or it, (a man, &c.,) was blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; (Mṣb;) as also UimolaH-a↓, inf. n. UimoliHaAHN; and OamolaHa↓. (TA.)

Also, ‡ He was black, with whiteness overspreading his hair: or, of a dusty white colour: or, of a clear white colour: (Mṣb:) [and in like manner,] UimolaH-a↓, inf. n. UimoliHaAHN, he (a ram) was of a white colour intermixed with black. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maliHa, aor. _a {yamolaHu}, inf. n. malaHN, He (a horse) had the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: See 1, in six places.

ml-H ‡ He (a poet) produced, or said, something goodly, beautiful, pretty, [or facetious]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and AmlH↓ he produced, or said, a goodly, beautiful, or pretty, [or a facetious,] word, or saying, or speech. (Lth.)

3. maAlaHotu fulaAnFA, (A,) inf. n. mumaAlaHapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ I ate with such a one. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of this, saying that a verb of this form is only derived from an inf. n., as in the cases of DaAraba and qaAtala; whereas this is derived from miloHN, a subst. [But his objection seems to me invalid: this may be an anomalous instance, and yet of classical authority, like many others.]

maAlaHahu, inf. n. mumaAlaHapN and milaAHN, ‡ He was, or became, his foster-brother. (L, TA.) [AlmilaAHu is explained in the Ḳ by AlmuraADaEapu: Lth explaines it by Alr-aDaAEu, as is mentioned in the TA: AlmumaAlaHapu is explained in the A, Mgh, L, and other lexicons by AlmuraADaEapu: in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, by Alr-aDaAEu; and so in one copy of the Ṣ: in another copy of the Ṣ written Alr-iDaAEu; and in another Alr-DaAE, without any vowel to the r: AlrDaAEu, syn. with AlmuraADaEapu, is evidently the right reading.] Abu-l-Kásim Er-Zejjájee disapproves of the verb used as signifying the act of two men's sucking each other; [but this is not what is meant by AlmrADEp;] and pronounces it a post-classical word. (TA.) You say bayonahumaA Huromapu AlmumaAlaHapi Between them two is the sacred or inviolable bond, or obligation, which is the consequence of their being fosterbrothers. (A.)

hom.sense: 4: See 1, in four places, and 2.
AmlH Alqawomu † The people possessed milk; ‡ the people had fat camels or other beasts. (L.)
AmlH ‡ He (a camel) carried fat; (L;) [meaning was fat]. AmlH Alqidora ‡ He put some fat [which is termed miloH] into the cookingpot. (AA.)
AmlH AlUibila He gave the camels salt water to drink. (Ḳ.)
AmlHt AlUibilu The camels came to salt water to drink. (Ṣ.)
