maA OamayoliHa zayodFA ‡ [How very goodly, or beautiful, or pretty, is Zeyd! a diminutive form, meant to denote the contrary of the sense of a dim., being what is termed taSogiyru taEoZiymK, from maA OamolaHahu:] (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the verb is here put into the dim. form, being meant to be used as an epithet, as though they said mulayoHN: (T:) it is the only instance of a verb put into this form, except maA OuHayosinahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, as some say, maA OuHayolaAhu. (TA.) This is said accord. to the doctrine of the Basrees, who assert the AfEl of wonder to be a verb: but as to the Koofees, who say that it is a noun, [meaning an epithet,] they allow the formation of the dim. from it without restriction; and from its admitting the dim. form, they argue that it is a noun. (MF.)
maA OamolaHa wajohahu, and fiEolahu, ‡ How goodly, beautiful, or pretty, is his face! and how good is his action! (A.)
OamoliHoniI binafasika ‡ Grace me, or recommend me, (zay-in-iI,) [by thy speech]. (T, L.)

entry.sense: 5: See 1, in two places.
fulaAnN yataZar-afu wayatamal-aHu ‡ [Such a one affects to be clever, or graceful, and to be goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious]. (A.)
9: See 1, in two places.
10. AstmlHhu † He esteemed him, or it, goodly, beautiful, or pretty; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [pleasing to the eye or ear: (the lexicons passim:)] or found him, or it, to be so (TA.)
maloHN: see miloHN.

hom.sense: miloHN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and maloHN↓ (M) ‡ The act of sucking the mother or any nurse; syn. raDaAEN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) a child's sucking its mother. (Abu-l- Kásim Ez-Zejjájee.)

miloHN ‡ Milk. (IAạr.) The following verse of Abu-t-Tamahán, who had some camels, of the milk whereof he gave to drink to a people that afterwards made an attack upon them, and took them, is cited by Aṣ, [app., accord. to the Ṣ, as an ex. of mlH in the sense of raDaAE; but as MF observes, it may be taken as an ex. of that word in the sense of milk;]
wiUin-iI laOarojuw miloHahaA fiI buTuwnikumo
wamaA basaTato mino jildi OaXoEava OagobaraA . (Ṣ, L.) The poet says, Verily I hope that ye may regard (Oano taroEawoA [which is understood]) the milk which ye have drank, of these camels, [lit., their milk in your bellies,] and the skins which they have expanded, of a people with matted and dusty hair, and of a dusty hue; as though their skins had dried up, and they had fattened upon them. [Another explanation will be noticed below.] IB says, that the last word should be read Oagobari, for the sake of the rhyme; for each verse of the poem to which it belongs ends with kesreh. (L.)
miloHN a thing well known, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [Salt;] that with which food is made pleasant: (L:) of the fem. gender (Z) generally; (O;) sometimes masc.: (Ḳ:) pl. milaAHN. (Mṣb.) Dim. mulayoHapN. (Mṣb.)

maMCN miloHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) originally maliHo↓, from the verb maluHa, like xaXinN from xaXuna, contracted because of the frequency of its usage; (Mṣb;) and mAC maliyHN↓, (Ḳ,) and maAliHN↓; (IAạr, ADk, Az;) [respecting which last, see what will be found after the explanation;] Salt water. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) J says, that maAC mAlH is not allowable, except in a bad dial.: but Az says, that, though rarely found in the language of the Arabs, it is not to be rejected; and IB says, that it occurs in verses of chaste poets; and may be considered as used after the manner of a rel. n., [meaning cuw miloHK,] like rajulN taArisN, i. e. cuw turosK, and daAriEN, i. e. cuw diroEK: (TA:) it is a chaste word, of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, but extr., being from OamolaHa AlmaMCu, like as you say baAqilN from Oaboqala AlmawoDiEu; and when it is said that it is rare, it is meant that it is not agreeable with its verb, not that it is rare with respect to usage, seeing that it is of the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz, who selected the most chaste words of the various dialects: or it is regularly formed from malaHa AlmaOCu, a form of the verb sometimes used. (Mṣb.) The pl. of miloHN is miloHapN and milaAHN and milaHN: (L, Ḳ:) and sometimes is said OamowaAhN miloHN salt waters; and rakiy-apN miloHapN a salt well. (L.)
milaAHN Salt waters. (T, Ḳ.) qaliybN malyiHN↓ A well of salt water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OaqolibapN milaAHN, occurring in a verse of 'Antarah. (Ṣ.)
miloHN † Knowledge; science; learning; syn. EilomN. (IKh, Ḳz, Ḳ.)
† Men of science; learned men; syn. EulamaMCu. (IKh, Ḳz, Ḳ.)
‡ Goodliness, or beauty. (Ḳ.) [Accord. to the TA, it is an inf. n.: see maluHa.]
‡ Fat, as a subst. (Sh, Ḳ.)
‡ Fatness: (Ḳ:) or a small degree of fatness. (TA.)

miloHN and miloHapN↓ ‡ A sacred or inviolable bond, or the like, or any compact, bond, or obligation, which one is under an obligation to respect, or honour, or the cancelling or breaking of which renders one obnoxious to blame; syn. HuromapN and cimaAmN; and a compact, or confederacy; syn. HilofN. (Ḳ.) In some copies of the Ḳ, for HilofN is put HalfN. (TA.)

Accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, this is the signification of the former word in the verse of Abu-t-Tamahán cited above, and the poet means, I hope that God may punish you for your perfidious violation of the sacred obligation to their owner, which they imposed upon you. You say bayona fulaAnK wafulaAnK miloHN, and miloHapN↓, There is a sacred or inviolable bond, &c., between such a one and such a one. [This meaning is derived from miloHN as signifying “salt;” the eating of which with another imposes upon the two parties a sacred mutual obligation.] The Arabs, says Abu-l-ʼAbbás, pay a high respect to salt and fire and ashes. (L.) [You say,] miloHuhu EalaI rukobatihi, so in the copies of the Ḳ, but correctly ElI rukobatayohi, as in all the other lexicons, (TA,) ‡ [lit., His salt is upon his knees;] meaning he has no good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, or engagements: (Ḳ:) or he has little good faith, so as to fulfil his promises, &c., for the Arabs swear by salt, and by water, because of their respect for them: (IAạr:) or he violates the obligation imposed by such, the smallest thing making him forget it, like as the least thing scatters salt if a person puts it upon his knees: (T:) or he is fat: (Ḳ:) Aṣ says, that in the following verse,
laA talumohaA Uin-ahaA mino nisowapK
miloHuhaA mawoDuwEapN fawoqa Alr-ukabo
[Blame her not; for she is of women whose fat is placed above the knees;] the woman meant was of the people called Ez-Zenj, whose fat is in their thighs, and mlHhA signifies their fat: (TA:) or he is sharp in his anger: (Ḳ:) or he is of evil disposition, rendered angry by the least thing; like as salt upon the knee is scattered by the least thing: (T:) or he is frequently engaged in altercation; as though his knees were much wounded by his long kneeling in altercation, and by his long striking his knees against those of another, and he therefore put salt upon them to cure them. (A.) [See also rukobapN.]
nabotN miloHN, and maAliHN↓, A plant of the kind called HamoDN. (ISk, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: malaHN: see muloHapN.

A certain disease and fault in the kind leg of a beast of carriage; (TA;) a swelling in the hock, or hock-tendon, (Euroquwb,) of a horse; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) less than what is called jaracN; which is a name given to it when it has become violent. (Ṣ.)
maliHN: see miloHN.

hom.sense: maloHapN ‡ A single feed taken by a child from the breast. malojapN, with j, signifies a single suck. (TA.)
maloHapN The main body of the sea; or the fathomless deep of the sea; or a great expanse of sea of which the extremities cannot be seen. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: muloHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and malaHN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ A white colour intermixed with black: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) whiteness overspreading blackness in the human hair, and in anything: or a dusty white colour: or a clear white colour: or whiteness inclining to any kind of redness; like the colour of the antelope. (L.) [See also OamolaHu.]

Also, muloHapN ‡ The utmost degree of blueness or grayness, [app. meaning the latter, from miloHN as signifying “salt,” as salt in the state in which it is commonly used in Arabia is of a pale gray colour,] OaXad-u Alz-arqi: (Ḳ:) or blueness, or grayness, (zuroqap,) of such a degree as to incline to whiteness. (Ṣ.) [See OamolaHu.]

muloHapN ‡ A goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, story, or narrative, and word, or saying, or speech; a bon-mot; (L;) waAHidapu AlmulaHi mina AlOaHaAdiyvi; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [what is deemed beautiful, elegant, facetious, or the like, of stories, &c.: (IbrD:) and so OumoluwHapN↓, coupled with OufokuwhapN in art. fkh in the TA:] also said to signify a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word, saying, or speech; a meaning taken from a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, who applied this term [perhaps ironically] to a bad answer which she had given in consequence of her having misunderstood a question put to her: (L:) pl. mulaHN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Aṣ said nilotu biAlmulaHi [I have attained to the station, or rank, to which I have attained by means of goodly, or facetious, sayings, &c.] (Ṣ.) Had-avotuhu biAlmulaHi ‡ [I related to him goodly, beautiful, pretty, or facetious, stories.] (A.)
[A curiosity, an extraordinary thing.]
miloHapN: see miloHN.
maloHaAnu: see miloHaAnu.
[A sucker: see maS-aAnN in art. mS.]

miloHaAnu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes written maloHaAnu↓, (TA, art. Xyb, voce XiybaAnu,) [written in both these ways in a copy of the Ṣ in my hands,] ‡ A name given to one of the winter-months, because of the whiteness of its snow: (Ṣ:) the month called Jumáda-l-Ákhireh, jumaAdaI AlMxirapN, (Ḳ,) [in the old Arabian calendar;] because of its whiteness; Jumáda-l-Oolà, jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI, being called XiybaAnu: or this was a name of Kánoon el-Owwal, kaAnuwnu AlOaw-alu; (TA;) and miloHaAnu was Kánoon eth-Thánee, kaAnuwnu Alv-aAniI: (Ḳ, TA:) [but see XiybaAnu:] or XiybaAnu and miloHaAnu were names applied to the days when the earth was white with hoar-frost, or rime. (ʼAmr Ibn-Abee-ʼAmr, Az.)
mulaAHN: see maliyHN.

maliyHN and mulaAHN↓ and mul-aAHN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but the last signifies more than the first, (T, Ṣ,) ‡ Goodly; beautiful; pretty; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and beautiful of colour; or beautiful and bright; (Mṣb;) pleasing to the eye or ear; facetious: (the lexicons passim:) fem. of the first with p {maliyHapN}: (Mṣb:) pl. of the same, milaAHN and OamolaAHN; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of mulaAHN, mulaAHuwna; and of mul-aAHN, mul-aAHuwna. (Ḳ.)
See miloHN.
[Facetious speech.]

One in whose counsel, or advice, one seeks a remedy; acc. to AA: hence the phrase qryX mlH AlnAs: acc. to some, one with whom one finds, or esteems, it pleasant to sit and converse. (IB, in TA, voce niqaAbN.)
Oabuw AlmaliyHi [the bird Sifrid]: see SiforidN.
milaAHapN and mal-aAHiy-apN↓: see mal-aAHN.

mulaAHiI-N, sometimes written mul-aAHiI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) occurring in poetry written in the latter manner, (Ṣ,) A kind of white, long-shaped, grape: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called from [the colour termed] AlmuloHap; (Ṣ;) or from the [plant called] mul-aAH, because of its taste. (AḤn.)
Also, A kind of fig, (Ḳ,) small, of the colour termed OamolaH, very sweet, and which is dried. (TA.)
Also, A species of the tree called OaraAk in which is whiteness and redness and the colour termed Xuhobap. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
mal-aAHN A seller of salt: or a possessor of salt: (IAạr, Ḳ:) as also mutamal-iHN↓: (Ḳ:) which also signifies one who provides himself with salt for travelling-provision: or a trader in salt. (TA.)
mal-aAHN A sailor; a shipman; a seaman, or mariner: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because constantly upon the salt water. (T.)
Also, One who constantly attends to a river (nahor; in some copies of the Ḳ, baHor; TA) to put its mouth into a right or proper state. (Ḳ.)
His occupation is called milaAHapN↓ and mal-aAHiy-apN↓. (Ḳ.)
mul-aAHN: see maliyHN.
mal-aAHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mamolaHapN↓ (Ḳ) A place where salt is generated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mal-aAHiy-apN: see mal-aAHN.
maAliHN: see miloHN and mamoluwHN.

OamolaHu ‡ A ram, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a he-goat, (Ṣ,) of a white colour intermixed with black: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) any hair, and wool, and the like, in which are whiteness and blackness: (TA:) that in which are whiteness and blackness, the former colour predominating: (AZ, Ks and others:) or of a dusty white colour: or of a clear white colour: (Mṣb:) fem. maloHaMCu; applied to a ewe of a white colour intermixed with black: (Ḳ:) or black, with its hair pervaded by whiteness. (TA.) Aboo-Dhubyán Ibn-Er-Raabal employs AmlH as one of four epithets which he applies to those old men most hateful to him. (Ṣ.)
Also, ‡ Blue, or gray, [see muloHapN,] in such a degree as to incline to whiteness; an epithet applied to a man, &c. (Mṣb) OamolaHN AlEayoni Having the eye of that colour. (Ṣ.)

Hence, katiybapN maloHaMCu [meaning ‡ An army, or a troop of horse, appearing of a white and black, or gray, hue, by reason of their glittering weapons; see also katiybapN XahobaMCu]: (Ṣ:) or one that is white and great: (TA:) or, great. (Ḳ.)

OamolaHu † Dew that falls in the night upon leguminous plants: so called because of its whiteness. (L.) Er-Rá'ee says, describing some camels,
OaqaAmato bihi Had-a Alr-abiyEi wajaAruhaA
Oaxuw salowapK mas-aI bihi All-ayolu OamolaHu
meaning [by AmlH] dew: [They remained in it during the period of the season called AlrbyE, and their preserver from thirst was attended by comfort, being dew brought by the night]: he says, they remained in that place during the days of the season called AlrbyE, and while the dew lasted, so that he was (fahuwa [but this appears to be a mistake for fahiIa, “so that they were,”]) in a comfortable state of life: and he says ms-I bh because the dew falls in the night: (Ṣ, L:) by jArhA he means the night-dew which preserved them from thirst. (L.)
AlmaloHaMCu was also the name of a particular troop belonging to the family of El-Mundhir, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the Kings of Syria, who had another called AlX-ahobaMCu. (TA.)
namirapN maloHaMCu A burodap with black and white stripes. (L.) XajarapN maloHaMCu † A tree of which the leaves have fallen, (L, Ḳ,) the branches, or twigs, remaining green. (L.)

AlmaloHaMCu (in a camel, L) † Certain flesh in the back, (situate within, L,) extending from the withers (AlkaAhil) to the rump: (L, Ḳ:) or the middle of the back, between the withers (AlkAhl) and the rump: (T, Ṣ [in neither of which is reference made here to a camel]:) or the part between the hump of a camel and its rump:
or the vertebræ of a camel over which is the hump: (L:) or, in a camel, the part beneath the hump; containing six vertebræ (maHaAlaAt): pl. maloHaAwaAtN. (T.) faArsu AlmaloHaMCi The fat of the hump. (L.)
OamolaHu A horse having the kind of swelling called malaHN. (TA.)
OumoluwHapN: see muloHapN.
mamolaHapN: see mal-aAHapN.
mimolaHapN A thing [or vessel or the like] in which salt is put. (Ṣ, A.)

hom.sense: mamoluwHN and mumal-iHN↓ ‡ A fat camel. (L.)
mumal-iHN↓ ‡ A camel destined for slaughter that is fat: (Ṣ:) or having some remains of fatness. (L.)

samakN mamoluwHN, and maliyHN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and miloHN↓, (Mṣb,) Salted fish; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. mumal-aHN↓. (Ḳ.) You should not say maAliHN. As to the saying of ʼOdháfir,
baSoriy-apN tazaw-ajato baSoriy-aA
yuToEimuhaA AlmaAliHa↓ wAlT-ariy-aA
[A woman of El-Basrah who married a man of El-Basrah: he fed her with salted and fresh], it is not an evidence. (Ṣ.) ISd says, that some have disapproved of this word, as also of mlyH, not regarding the above verse as an evidence. You says, that mlyH and mmlwH are better than mAlH. (TA.)

entry.sense: mumal-aHN and mumal-iHN: see mamoluwHN.
mutamal-iHN: see mal-aAHN.

hom.sense: 1. malaxa, aor. _a {yamolaxu}, inf. n. maloxN; (Ḳ;) and Amtlx↓; (L;) He pulled, or drew, a thing, grasping with the hand, or biting, (L, Ḳ,) and so pulling or drawing it out. (L.)

Amtlx↓ He pulled out a thing; (L, Ḳ;) drew it forth: or drew it forth quickly. (L.) He drew his sword. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) He pulled out his tooth: (Ṣ:) and his eye. (Lḥ.) It (an eagle) pulled out an eye; (Ṣ;) as also tml-x↓. (Ḳ, TA.) He pulled away his hand from the hand of a person grasping him. (L.) He pulled out a ripe date from its skin. (L.) He pulled off flesh from a bone. (L.) He pulled off the bridle and bit from the head of a beast of carriage. (L, Ḳ.)

malaxa, aor. _a {yamolaxu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. maloxN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He went, or journeyed, at a vehement rats: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, at an easy rate: and, sometimes, vehemently: (ISd:) or, quickly: (TA:) or he (a beast) stretched forth his arms in the pace called HuDor, in any way, well or ill. (Ibn-Hánee.)
malaxa fiI AlOaroDi He went away journeying through the land, or earth. (TA.)

fulaAnN yamolaxu fiI AlbaATili, (Ṣ,) inf. n. maloxN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Such a one goes to and fro, and occupies himself much, in vain affairs: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or goes quickly and easily therein: (Sh:) or plays, or sports, and perseveres, therein. (L.)
maloxN AlbaATili i. q. Alt-abaxoturu [Walking in an affected manner] (L, in art. Dndd.)
malaxa Alqawomu maloxapF SaAliHapF The people, or party, went, or journeyed, far in the land. (Ṣ.)
malaxa He (a man) fled (IAạr; and Az, from several Arabs of the desert.)
maluxa, aor. _u {yamoluxu}, inf. n. malaAxapN, It (flesh-meat) was, or became, tasteless, or insipid; (Ṣ;) [i. q. masuxa]. See salaAxapN.

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
8: see 1.

maliyxN, applied to flesh-meat, (Ṣ,) or, accord. to some, specially to a new-born camel that is slaughtered when it falls from its mother's belly, (L,) That has no taste; tasteless; insipid; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) i. q. masiyxN. (Ṣ.) See saliyxN.
Corrupt: (L, Ḳ:) or any corrupt food. (IAạr, L.)
maliyxN Milk that slips from the hand. (L.)
[maluwxiy-apN Corchorus olitorius, or Jews' mallow: so used in the present day. See xub-aAzN.]
mal-aAxN Vehement in journeying, or in his pace. (Ṣ,* TA.)
A slave who runs away often. (L, Ḳ.)
maAlixN Fleeing; as also maAxilN and xaAmilN. (Az.)
mumotalaxu AlEaqoli ‡ A man deprived, or despoiled of his reason. (Ṣ, TA.)
mutamal-ixi↓ AlS-ulobi A man weakened, or enervated, in the back-bone, or back; (Ḳ;) as though it were pulled asunder. (TA.)
mutamal-ixN: see mumotalaHN.

1. malida, [aor. _a {yamoladu},] (TA,) inf. n. maladN (Ḳ, TA) and maladaAnN, (M,) It (a branch, M, TA) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate; (M, Ḳ;) and quivered, shook, or played loosely. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
Also, inf. n. maladN, ‡ He (a youth) was, or became, soft, tender, or delicate. (T, Ṣ, L.)
See also maladN, below.
maladahu He drew or pulled it; strained it; or extended or stretched it; syn. mad-ahu. (Ḳ.)
2. ml-dhu, inf. n. tamoliydN, It (the imbibing of moisture) rendered it (a branch) soft, tender, or delicate. (T, L.)
He softened it, namely a tanned skin or hide. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
malodN: see OumoluwdN.
Also, The [creature called] guwl; (Ḳ;) i. e., i. q. siEolaApN; or an enchantress of the jinn. (TA.)
maladN: see malida.
maladN, (M, L, Ḳ,) and maladaAnN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ Youth, or youthfulness; and its softness, tenderness, or delicateness. (M, L, Ḳ.* [In the CK, for naEomap, is erroneously put niEomapN.])
maladaAnu: see maladN.
Oamoladu, OumoludN, &c.: see OumoluwdN.

OumoluwdN (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ) and UimoliydN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) and OamoladN↓ (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and OumoludN↓ and OumoludaAnN↓ and OumoludaAniI-N↓ and malodN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) Soft, tender, or delicate; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) and lithe or limber: (M, Ḳ:) the first (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and second, (M, L, Ḳ,) or all, (Ḳ,) applied to a branch: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) and the first and third, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) or all, (M, L, Ḳ,) applied in the same sense to ‡ a man, or young man: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) or OumolwdN, applied to a young man, ‡ beardless: (A:) or perfect in make, or full-grown, pubescent, and well-formed: (T, L:) and OumoluwdN (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and OumoluwdapN (M, L, Ḳ) and OumoludaAniy-apN (M, L) or OumoluwdaAniy-apN (Ḳ) and malodaMCu (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and malodaAniy-apN (M, L, Ḳ) [in the CK muloda Aniy-apN] applied to a woman, or a damsel, ‡ soft, tender, or delicate; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) and of just stature: (L:) pl. of OumoluwdN (A, TA) and of UimoliydN (TA) OamaAliydu; (A, TA;) and of malodN, OamolaAdN. (M, L.) The O in Amlwd and Amlyd is to render them quasi-coordinate to words of the classes of EusoluwjN and qiTomiyrN; as is shown by their having the augmentative letters w and I. (IJ, M, L.)
UimoliydN: see OumoluwdN.
Also, applied to a desert (SaHoraMC) i. q. UimoliysN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) i. e., Bare, in which is nothing. (L.)
1. malaca, aor. _u {yamolucu}, inf. n. malocN, He was quick in coming and going. (M, L.) This is the original signification. (L.)
He (a horse) was quick in his running. (Ḳ, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.)

He (a-horse) stretched forth his arms, (mac-a DaboEayohi, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) in running, (Ṣ,) to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, (Hat-aI laA yajida maziydFA lil-iHaAqK, M, L, Ḳ,) and contracted, or drew in, (Habasa, [perhaps a mistake for xanasa, which may mean either contracted, or threw back,]) his hind legs to a degree that he could not exceed, to overtake, without any confusion [in his motions]. (M, L.)

malacahu, aor. _u {yamolucu}, inf. n. malocN and malaAcapN, He contented him with courteous and soothing speech, and made him to hear that which rejoiced him, without doing, or performing, anything. (T, L.) Accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, the c in this word is a substitute for v. (M, L.) See malavahu.
malaca, inf. n. malocN, He lied; (Ḳ;) as also malava. (TA.)
malacahu, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. malocN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He smote him and pierced him with a spear. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
malacaAnN and malacaAniI-N and malaAcaAniI-N: see mal-aAcN.
maluwcN: see mal-aAcN.

mal-aAcN A man who says but does not act, or perform; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) a liar; (Ṣ, L;) who behaves in an artificial manner, and is not true in his affection; (M, L, Ḳ;) as also maluwcN↓ (M, L [in the Ḳ milowacN, and said to be of the same measure as minobarN; but this seems to be a mistake]) and malacaAnN↓ and malacaAniI-N↓ (M, L, Ḳ) and malaAcaniI-N↓: (M, Ḳ:) [in some copies of the Ḳ, by a mistake in the last vowel-sign, each of the last three of these epithets is as though it were syn. with malocN, the inf. n of malaca, “he lied”, &c.:] or a liar, who, if asked, will not tell truly whence he comes; as also all the above epithets: (M, L:) and malacaAnN↓ one who makes a show of sincerity, faithfulness, or honesty, concealing, or meditating, what is different therefrom. (Ṣ, L.)
Also mal-aAcN Stealthy, (M, L,) and light, or active; applied to a wolf. (M, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. malusa, aor. _u {yamolusu}; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and malisa, aor. _a {yamolasu}; (Mṣb;) or the second form is malasa, aor. _u {yamolusu}; (Ḳ;) [but the last of the inf. ns. here following seems to indicate that malisa is correct;] inf. n. malaAsapN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and muluwsapN, (M, Ḳ,) [accord. to rule, both of the first,] and malasN, (M, TA,) [accord. to rule, of the second;] It was, or became, smooth, sleek, or free from asperities; the inf. n. being the contr. of xuXuwnapN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) it had in it nothing upon which to lay hold; it was, or became, smooth to the feel; (Mṣb;) and AmlAs-↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. UimoliysaAsN; (Ṣ;) and Amls-↓: (so in a copy of the A) and [in like manner] tml-s↓ (Ṣ, A) and Uim-alasa↓, of the measure UinofaEala, the n being incorporated into the m, both signify it was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth,, &c. (Ṣ.) See also 4.

malasa, aor. _u {yamolusu}, inf. n. malosN, ‡ He (a man) went away quickly, or swiftly: (TA:) and malasati Aln-aAqapu, (M,) and AlUibilu, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as before, (M,) ‡ the she-camel, (M,) and the camels, (A,) went quickly, or swiftly: (M, A:) or malosN signifies the going easily, or gently: and also, contr., the going vehemently: (M:) or a gentle mode of going or journeying: (IAạr:) and the being light, or active, and quick. (TA.) It is said in a trad., siro valaAvFA malosFA, i. e., valaAva layaAlK cawaAti malosK; or valaAvFA sayorFA malosFA; ‡ [Journey thou three nights of quick, or of easy, journeying; or with a quick, or an easy, journeying;] or mlsA signifies a certain mode of going or journeying; and is in the accus. case as an inf. n. (TA.) malasa, aor. and inf. n. as above, also signifies † It (a thing) went back, or retired, (Uinoxanasa,) quickly; (M;) and so Uim-alasa↓. (M, TA.)

malasa AlZ-alaAmu, [aor. _u {yamolusu},] (TḲ,) inf. n. malosN, (A, Ḳ,) or malasN, (Ṣ, M,) The darkness became confused; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also Oamolasa↓, (TḲ,) inf. n. UimolaAsN: (Ḳ:) or became in the state after that which is termed malavN, (M,) or malovN. (TA.) See malosN below.

2. ml-shu, inf. n. tamoliysN, He rendered it smooth, sleek, or free from asperities. (Ṣ.) You say, ml-s AlOaroDa, (TA,) biAlomal-aAsapi, (A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [He smoothed the land with the ml-Asp;] he drew the mimolaqap [or ml-Asp] over the land, [and so made it smooth, or even,] after the ploughing and sowing thereof. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He made him to escape; or to be, or become, or get, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; mina AlOamori from the thing, or affair; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and mno yadi gayorihi from the hand of another. (A.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
Oamolasato XaAtuka The wool of thy sheep, or ewe, fell off: (Ḳ:) from Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tml-s: see malusa.
It (a smooth thing) slipped forth from the hand [&c.]. (Ḥar, p. 119.)

And hence, (Ḥar, ubi supra,) ‡ He escaped; got away; or was, or became, or got, clear, quit, free, or at liberty; (Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) as also Anmls↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and Uim-alasa↓, of the measure UifotaEala, [or rather UinofaEala,] and AmlAs-↓; (Ḳ;) mina AlOamori from the thing or affair; (Ṣ, A, TA;) and mino yadiI from my hand. (A.)
[Hence,] tml-s mina AlX-araAbi † He recovered from the wine. (AḤn, M.)
7. Anmls and Uim-alasa: see malusa:
and malasa:
and 5.
8: see 5.
Oumotulisa baSaruhu ‡ His sight was suddenly taken away. (M, A, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 9: see malusa.

hom.sense: 11: see malusa:
and 5.
malosN: see Oamolasu.

Also, malosN, (A, Ḳ,) or malasN↓, (Ṣ, M,) The confusedness of the darkness: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or it is after the malav, (M,) or malov: (TA:) the mlv is the first, or commencement, of the blackness of the west; and the mls is when the blackness has become intense, so that the time of the last EiXaMC comes; then the mls becomes confounded with the mlv, and the one is not distinguished from the other. (IAạr.) You say, Oatayotuhu malasa↓ AlZ-alaAmi, (Ṣ, M,) or malosa AlZlAm, (TA,) I came to him when the darkness had become confused; (Ṣ, TA;) when the night had become confused with the earth. (TA.) The word is used adverbially and otherwise. (M.) See malasa AlZ-alaAmu.
malasN: see UimoliysN, in two places:
and malosN, throughout.
malasaI: see UimoliysN.

Also, † A man who will not remain firm to a compact, covenant, engagement, or promise; like as the smooth thing will not remain firm. (M.) It is said in a proverb, (El-Aḥmar, M,) alluding to dislike, or hatred, of faults or the like, (El-Aḥmar, TA,) AlmalasaI laA Eahoda lahu † [He who will not remain firm to a compact,, &c., for him there is no compact,, &c.]; (El-Aḥmar, M;) meaning, that he has got out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him. (El-Aḥmar, TA.) [But see what here follows.]

It is said in a proverb, applied to him in whose fidelity one does not trust, (TA,) AlmalasaI laA Euhodapa lahu, meaning cuw AlmalasaI; (Az, L, Mṣb, TA;) i. e., † He who steals a commodity, and sells it for less than its price, and escapes immediately and hides himself, so that if he who has a just claim to it come, he finds his property in the hand of him who purchased it, he takes it, and the price which the thief gained goes for nought, and the purchaser cannot return to him to recover the price: (Az, TA:) or it means, † he who goes away privily, gets out of the affair in safety, there being nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him: or AmlsI means, a † man's selling a commodity which he has stolen, and abating the price, and then absenting himself; so that when it is plucked from the hand of the purchaser, he cannot sue the seller as responsible for the loss thereof: (Mṣb:) or ‡ the sale to which attaches no claim upon the seller for having acted unjustly: (A, TA:) or † the selling a thing without making one's self responsible for any loss or the like that may be occasioned by it. (TA.) One says, also, in selling, malasaI laA Euhodapa, meaning, that he has escaped from the affair, or become quit of it; that there is nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him: [i. e., † I am quit of the affair: no claim shall be made for indemnification.] (Ṣ.)
You say, also, OabiyEuka AlmalasaI laA Euhodapa, meaning, ‡ [I sell to thee on the condition that] thou shalt get thee away, and not return to me, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) nor have any claim upon me for indemnification. (Mṣb.) [In some copies of the Ṣ, here and in art. Ehd, the verbs by which the meaning is explained are of the third person, as though referring to the things sold; but the right reading I hold to be that which I have followed. See also art. Ehd.]

entry.sense: maluwsN: see malasaI.

hom.sense: maliysN: see Oamolasu, in two places:
and UimoliysN.

entry.sense: mulayosaMCu: dim. of malosaMCu, fem. of Oamolasu, which see, in two places.
mal-aAsapN An implement (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) of wood (A, TA) with which land is made smooth, or even; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also mimolasapN↓. (A, TA.)

Oamolasu Smooth; sleek; free from asperities; [contr. of xaXinN;] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) having in it nothing upon which to lay hold; smooth to the feel; (Mṣb;) and maliysN↓ signifies the same; (TA;) and malosN↓ [in like manner], anything smooth or soft: (TA:) fem. of the first, malosaMCu: (M, A, &c.:) and pl. mulosN. (A.) You say, vawobN Oamolasu [A smooth garment, or piece of cloth]. And SaxorapN malosaMCu [A smooth rock]. (A, TA.) And qawosN malosaMCu and maliysN↓ A bow in which is no crack. (M.) And Darabahu EalaI malosaMCi matonihi and mulayosaAYihi↓ He struck him upon the even and smooth part of his back. (M.)

‡ A camel (A) having a sound back, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) free from mange or scab. (A, TA.) So in the proverb, (Ṣ,) haAna EalaI AlOamolasi maA laAqaI Ald-abiru ‡ [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to him who has an ill concern for his companion. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN malosaMCu: see UimoliysN.
sanapN malosaMCu ‡ A year without herbage: (A:) or a year of sterility: pl. OamaAliysu, contr. to rule. (M.)
AlmalosaMCu ‡ The lowest heaven. (TA, art. jrb.)
qahowapN malosaMCu (A) or xamorN malosaMCu (Ḳ) ‡ Wine easy to swallow; (A;) wine that descends easily in the throat. (Ḳ.)
jiloduhu Oamolasu ‡ He has no blame attaching to him. (A, TA.)
ximosN Oamolasu ‡ A fatiguing, severe [journey such as is called] xms. (Ḳ.)

UimoliysN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with p {UimoliysapN}, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) ‡ A desert in which is no herbage: pl. OamaAliysu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OamaAlisu, [the latter] contr. to general rule, (Ḳ,) the I being suppressed by poetic licence: (TA:) or OamaAlisu signifies land in which are no trees, nor fresh nor dry herbage, nor wild animals; sing, UimoliysN; app. from malaAsapN, [inf. n. of malusa,] i. e., smooth land, in which is nothing: (Sh, L, TA:*) or OamaAliysu is pl. of OamolaAsN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of malasN↓, meaning, an even place, (M, TA,) in which is no herbage; (TA;) and the pl. of mult. is muluwsN: and you say also, OaroDN malasN↓ and malasaI↓ and malosaMCu↓ and UimoliysN, meaning, land that produces no herbage; (M, TA;) and the pl. is OamaAlisu and OamaAliysu, contr. to analogy [unless pls. of UimoliysN, in which case the former only is so]. (TA.)

You say also, rum-aAnN UimoliysN (T, M, TA,) and UimoliysiI-N↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) as though the latter were a rel. n. from UimoliysN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) not, as is implied in the [Ṣ, and] Ḳ, as meaning a desert, but as syn. with UimoliysiI-N↓; (TA;) † A sweet pomegranate, having no stones: (T, M, TA:) and accord. to Lth, rum-aAnN maliysN signifies † the sweetest kind of pomegranate, which is that without stones. (TA.) [See XanobaMCu, voce OaXonabu.]
UimoliysapN: see UimoliysN.
UmoliysiI-N: see UimoliysN.
mmolasapN: see mal-aAsapN.

hom.sense: 1. maliSa, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamolaSu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. malaSN, (Ṣ, M,) It (a thing, Ṣ, M, or a rope, Lḥ, M, A, and a bridle, Lḥ, M,) slipped; (Ṣ;) or fell, slipping; (Ḳ;) or got loose or free, or escaped, and slipped [away]; (A;) or slipped out by reason of its smoothness; (M;) from one's hand; (Ṣ, M, A;) as also Uim-alaSa↓, and tml-S↓: (M:) or AnmlS↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also written Uim-alaSa, (Ṣ,) signifies it (a thing, Lth, Ṣ,) escaped, or got loose or free, (Lth, Ṣ,) from one's hand, after having been seized or grasped: (Lth:) and [in like manner] tml-S↓, it, and he, (a thing, Ṣ, or a rope, TA, and a man, Ṣ, A,) became safe or secure or free, or escaped, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) from one's hand. (TA.) You say, maliSati Als-amakapu mino yadiI and AnmlSt↓ The fish escaped and slipped from my hand. (A, TA.) And maA kidotu Oatamal-aSu↓ mino fulaAnK I hardly escaped, or became secure, from such a one. (Ṣ, A.*)
He went back, or retreated, fleeing; as also maliza, inf. n. malazN. (TA.)
malaSahu He set it loose, or free. (TA.)
malaSa bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit: (Ḳ:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád: but in the Tekmileh, malaSa bisahomihi he shot his arrow. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AmlS, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UimolaASN, (TA,) It (a thing) made, or caused, to slip. (Ḳ.)

Hence, (TA,) AmlSt janiynahaA, (Mgh, TA,) or bijanyinihaA, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA,) or biwaladihaA, (Ṣ,) or AmlSt [alone], (M, A, Ḳ,) She (a woman, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, and a camel, M, TA) brought forth her fœtus, or offspring, prematurely, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh,) or dead: (Ḳ:) i. q. Oazolaqato bihi and Oasohalato bihi and HaTaOato bihi. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, TA.)
AmlS also signifies He (a man) became poor, needy, or indigent. (TA.)
5: see 1, in three places.
7. AnmlS and Am-lS: see 1, in three places; and see 7 in art. dlS.

maloSN ‡ Naked: [in the present day commonly preceded by EuroyaAn (vulgarly pronounced EaroyaAn), and with it signifying stark naked:] as though become divested of his clothes like a rope that is become divested of its villous coating. (TA.)

maliSN A thing that slips out from one's hand by reason of its smoothness; as also maliySN↓ and OamolaSu↓: (M:) a rope from which the hand slips, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not being able to keep hold of it; (Ṣ, TA;) as also maliySN↓. (TA.) You say, samakapN maliSapN (M, A) A fish that slips from the hand by reason of its smoothness: (M:) or that gets loose or free, or escapes, and slips [away]: (A:) or, accord. to AA, (TA,) AlmaliSapu signifies AlOaTuwmu mina Als-amaki [app. meaning a kind of thick-skinned fish]. (Ḳ, TA.)
maliySN: see maliSN, in two places:
and see mumolaSN, in two places.
OamolaSu: see maliSN. You say also, rajulN OamolaSu Alr-aOosi, i. e. OabolaTuhu [app. meaning A smooth-headed man.] (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Also, Tender; or soft. (TA.)

mumolaSN Brought forth prematurely; as also maliySN↓: (M, TA:) an abortion. (TA.) You say, Oaloqato waladahaA mumolaSFA She cast her young one prematurely; (TA;) as also maliySFA↓ and maliyTFA. (Ḳ, TA.)
mumoliSN A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead: (Ḳ:) pl. mamaAliySu, with I. (M, TA.)
mimolaASN A woman, and a she-camel, (M,) that usually brings forth her offspring prematurely, (M,) or dead.. (Ḳ.)

dictScrap.note: [Several points of resemblance, and some of exact agreement, will be observed between this art. and art. mls.]

hom.sense: 1. maliTa, aor. _a {yamolaTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. malaTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and muloTapN, (Ḳ,) He (a man) had little, scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks: (Ṣ [which indicates that it is like mariTa:]) or had no hair upon his body, (Ḳ, TA,) but only upon his head and beard. (TA.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 4. OamolaTato, (Ṣ,) or AmlTt janiynahaA, (Ḳ.) She (a camel) cast her fœtus (Ṣ, Ḳ) before it had hair growing upon it; (Ṣ;) without any hair upon it: (Ḳ:) [like OamoraTatohu] and malaTatohu↓ Oum-uhu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yamoluTu}, (TA,) she brought it forth in an imperfect state. (Ḳ.)
OamolaTa [perhaps a mistake for OabolaTa] He became poor, needy, or indigent; like OamolaSa. [TA, art. mlS.]
5. tml-T It (an arrow) was, or became, without feathers upon it. (Ḳ.)
It [a thing] was, or became, made, or rendered, smooth; syn. tml-S. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
8. AmtlThu He seized it, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares,; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) like AmtrThu. (TA.)
milaATN [gypsum]: see XiydN.
The shoulderblade; syn. katifN: (TA, art. srH:) or the humerus, or upper bone, of the arm; syn. EaDudN. (T, ibid.) of a camel. (ISh, ibid.)
maliyTN The fœtus of a camel having as yet no hair grown upon it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that is cast prematurely; as also maliySN. (Ḳ, TA, in art. mlS.)
Also, A lamb or kid: or one just born. (TA.)
See also what next follows.
OamolaTu A man having little, or scanty, or thin, hair upon the sides of his face, or of his cheeks; like OamoraTu: (Ṣ:) or having no hair upon his body, (Lth, Ḳ,) except the head and beard. (Lth.)
An arrow of which the feathers have fallen off; like OamoraTu: (Ṣ:) or an arrow having no feathers upon it; as also maliyTN↓. (Ḳ.)
mumoliTN [like mumoriTN] A she-camel casting her fœtus without any hair upon it: pl. mamaAliyTu, (Ḳ, TA,) with I. (TA.)
mimolaATN [like mimoraATN] A she-camel that usually casts her fœtus without any hair upon it. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. manaOa, aor. _a {yamonaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. manoCN, (Ṣ,) He soaked a hide in tanning-liquid, or ooze. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
manaOahu He conformed with him in what he did. (TA.)

entry.sense: maniyoYapN A hide in the first stage of tanning: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is next called OafiyqN; and then OadiymN: (AZ, Ṣ:) or a hide as long as it remains in the tanning-liquid. (TA.)
A place where hides are tanned. (Aṣ, Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, accord. to some, Tan, or that with which one tans. (TA.)
This word is not to be pronounced without C, because maniy-apN signifies “death.” (MF.)
mamonaOapN A black land: (Ḳ:) also without C. (TA.)
[manojaniyqN, as described in art. jnq (q. v.), seems to be the engine called by the Romans Onager: see Kitto's Pict. Bible, ii. 499: but was probably applied also to the balista.]

1. manaHahu, aor. _a {yamonaHu} and _i {yamoniHu}, inf. n. manoHN, He lent him a she-camel, and a sheep or goat; (L;) that he might have the milk thereof, and return the animal after a certain period: this is the original signification: (L:) or he lent to him a she-camel, assigning to him her soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring: (Lḥ, L, Ḳ:) and in like manner, he lent him a piece of land, that he might cultivate it and have the produce thereof: (L:) he lent him money or the like, to be repaid. (A, TA.)
manaHahu, aor. _a {yamonaHu} and _i {yamoniHu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. manoHN, (Ṣ,) He gave him a thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he gave him a thing as a free gift. (A, TA.)

tamonaHu AlmaroOapu wajohahaA AlmiroMpa The woman imparts somewhat of her beauty to the mirror: or directs her face towards the mirror. And in like manner, accord. to some, you say, when you direct anything (taqoSidu bihi) towards another thing, manaHotuhu Uiy-aAhu. (L.)
3. mAnHhu, inf. n. mumaAnaHapN, He aided him, or assisted him, reciprocally, with a gift. (A.)
mAnHt, inf. n. minaAHN and mumaAnaHapN, ‡ She (a camel) yielded plenty of milk in the winter, after the milk of the other camels had passed away. (L.)
‡ It (the eye) shed tears continuously. (Ḳ.)
4. AmnHt She (a camel) was near to bringing forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Sh says, I know not AmnHt in this sense: but Az says that it is correct, and that the objection of Sh does not invalidate it. (TA.)
5. taman-aHotu AlmaAla ‡ I fed others with the property. So in the trad. of Umm-Zarạ, waMkulu faOataman-aHu ‡ And I eat, and then feed others. (Ḳ, TA.)
8. UimotanaHa He took or received, a gift. (Ḳ.)
OumotuniHa maAlFA He was supplied with property, or wealth, by God. (Ḳ.)

10. AstmnHhu He asked, desired, or sought, a loan, or gift, (minoHap,) of him; i. e., asked, desired, or sought aid, or assistance, from him; syn. Uisotarofadahu; (Ṣ;) or asked, &c., a gift from him. (Ḳ.)

minoHapN A loan, or lending, of a she-camel or sheep or goat, that the person to whom the loan is granted may milk her for a certain period and then restore her to the lender: (AʼObeyd:) [and in like manner,] maniyHapN↓ a gift (minoHap) of milk; as a she-camel or sheep or goat that is given to another that he may milk her and afterwards restore her to the lender: (Ṣ:) or minoHapN signifies a ewe or a she-goat or a she-camel, which her owner lends to a man that he may drink her milk and restore her when her milk ceases to flow: (Mṣb:) or both words signify a she-camel or sheep or goat whose milk is given to another: (A:) or a she-camel of which the soft hair (wabar) and milk and offspring are conceded by the owner to another: (Ḳ:) or maniyHapN↓ signifies a she-camel or sheep or goat that is lent for the sake of her milk [&c.]; and minoHapN, the profit which the lender thereof bestows upon the borrower. (Lḥ, L.) The Arabs have four words which they use in the place of EaAriy-apN, viz. maniyHapN↓, Eariy-apN, UifoqaArN, and UixobaAlN. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)
minoHapN mino layanK Milch sheep or goats; (L;) [app. meaning, that are lent to a person].
Also minoHapN A loan of land, and of money. (L.)
Also, A gift, or thing given; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also maniyHapN↓: (TA:) a free gift: (AʼObeyd, L:) pl. minaHN; (A;) and pl. of maniyHapN, manaAYiHu. (TA.)
manuwHN: see mumaAniHN.

AlmaniyHu An arrow (of those used in the game called Almayosir, Ṣ) which has no lot, or portion, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) unless the person to whom it pertains be given something: (Ṣ:) it is the third of the arrows to which the term gufolN is applied, which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine; these being only added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play]: it is one of four arrows to each of which is assigned no portion and no fine; the first is called AlmuSad-aru; the next, AlmuDaE-afa; the next, AlmnyH; and the last, Als-afiyHu: (Lḥ:) accord. to some, (TA,) an arrow that is borrowed because it is regarded as fortunate: (Ḳ, TA:) or an arrow which has a portion assigned to it. (Ḳ.)

kunotu maniyHa OaSoHaAbiI yawoma badorK † I was, among my companions, like the arrow called AlmnyH, on the day of the battle of Bedr; i. e., by reason of my youth, I was like the arrow that neither gains nor loses. (L, from a trad.)
maniyHapN: see minoHapN.
man-aAHN One who gives many gifts. (TA.)
mumoniHN A she-camel near to bringing forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mimonaHN and mamaAniHu: see mumaAniHN.

mumaAniHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and manuwHN↓ (Ṣ) ‡ A she-camel whose milk remains, (Ḳ,) or that yields plenty of milk in the winter, (Ṣ,) after the milk of the other camels has passed away; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like mujaAliHN. (Ṣ.) You say also nuwqN mamaAniHu↓ [app. pl. of mimonaHN, which is perhaps not used]. (TA.)
Also the former, ‡ Rain that does not cease: (Ḳ:) and ‡ wind of which the rain does not cease. (TA.)

munodu is a simple word; (Ḳ;) or, accord. to some, a compound word, as will be explained hereáfter: (TA:) Sb says, that it is with respect to time like mino with respect to place: (Ṣ, L:) it is indecl., [generally] with damm for its termination; and muco is indecl. also, [generally] with its final letter quiescent, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [unless followed by a quiescent letter, when it is movent in different manners which will be shown below,] and it is formed from munocu by elision: (M, L, Ḳ:) mnc is also written and pronounced minocu, (M, L, Ḳ,) in the dial. of the Benoo-Suleym; (M, L;) and mc, mico, (M, L, Ḳ,) in the dial. of the tribe of 'Okl. (M, L.) Each may be a prep., governing what follows it in the gen. case, and used in the same manner as fiI [signifying In, or during, or from the beginning of]: and in this case, each is prefixed only to that which denotes present time: thus you say, maA raOayotuhu mucu All-ayolapi [I have not seen him in this night; or simply I have not seen him this night]: (Ṣ, L:) or each is followed by a noun in the gen. case, and in this instance is a prep., in the sense of mino [meaning Since, or lit., from,] when relating to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]; and in the sense of fiI [meaning In, or from the beginning of,] when relating to the present time; and in the sense of mino and UilaI together [meaning From the beginning to the end of; or during the whole course of; or simply during, or for;] when relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like: ex. [relating to a past time,] maA raOayotuhu munocu yawomi Alxamiysi [I have not seen him since Thursday, UilaI QloMna to the present time]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and [relating to the present time,] munocu yawominaA or EaAminaA [in, or from the beginning of, (this) our day, or (this) our year;]; and, [relating to a computed period of time, or number of days or the like,] munocu valaAvapi Oay-aAmK [from the beginning to the end of, i. e., during, or for, three days]. (Mughnee.) Each may also be a noun, governing the noun which follows it in the nom. case, as signifying a particular day or the like, or as signifying a definite length of time: in the case of a noun signifying a particular day or the like, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco yawomu AljumoEapi [I have not seen him (since the commencement of a space of time); the commencement of the space of time thereof (i. e., Oaw-alu mud-api Eadami ruWoyatiI Uiy-aAhu the commencement of the space of time of my not seeing him) was Friday; meaning, since Friday]: and, in the case of a noun signifying a definite length of time, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco sanapN, meaning, Oamadu celika sanapN, [I have not seen him (during, or for, a time); the time thereof (i. e., Oamadu Eadami ruWoyatiI Uiy-aAhu the time of my not seeing him) is a year; meaning, during, or for, a year;] and the noun in this latter case can only be indeterminate; for you cannot say, muco sanapu kacaA: (Ṣ:) when followed by a noun in the nom. case, as in the instance of munocu yawomaAni [or, accord. to more approved usage, muco yawomaAni, as will be shown below, The time is two days, meaning during, or for, two days], each is an inchoative, and what follows it is an enunciative; and its meaning is the time with respect to what is present, and to a computed period, or a number of days or the like; and the commencement of the space of time with respect to a past time [such as a particular past day or the like]: or each is an adv. n. [of time], an enunciative, of which what follows is the inchoative, and meaning bayona wabayona, as in the instance of laqiytuhu munocu yawomaAni, [or, rather, muco yawomaAni,] i. e., bayoniI wabayona liqaAYihi yawomaAni [Two days have been between the time in which I now am and (the time of) my meeting him]: (Ḳ:) but this opinion is rejected by Ibn-Hájib. (TA.) Accord. to some of the Arabs, for they differ on this point, mc governs in the gen. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: and accord. to some of them, mnc governs in the nom. case a noun signifying a past time and one signifying a time not past: (M, L:) but the general and most approved way is to make mc govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past, and in the nom. case one signifying a time past; and to make mnc govern in the gen. case a noun signifying a time not past and one signifying a time past: (T, M, L:) most of the Arabs hold, that each must govern in the gen. case a noun signifying the present time; and that it is preferable to make mnc govern in the same case, and to make mc govern in the nom. case, a noun signifying a past time: (Mughnee:) [they therefore say, munocu All-ayolapi and mucu All-ayolapi, and munocu yawomi Alxamiysi and munocu yawomayni; but they say, muco yawomu Alxamiysi and muco yawomaAni.] Some [or, rather, most] say, lamo Oarahu muco yawomaAni, and lamo Oarahu munocu yawomayni, [I have not seen him for, or during, two days;] making mc [in these instances] to govern the nom. case; and mnc, the gen. case. (L.) Such is said when the period of separation is a day and part of a day. (Mṣb, art. Xhr.) The Benoo-Dabbeh and Er-Rabáb make mc to govern the gen. case in every instance. (M, L.) The phrases, maA raOayotuhu muco EaAmN Oaw-alu, and muco EaAmN Oaw-ala, (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. wOl; and L,) and muco EaAmu AlOaw-ali, and muco EaAmFA Oaw-ala, [I have not seen him since last year,] are also mentioned by different authors. (L.) The Arabs generally agree in pronouncing mnc with damm to the c when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter; (T, M, L;) as in lamo Oarahu munocu yawomK, and munocu Alyawomi: (T, L:) and to pronounce mc with the c quiescent when it is followed by a movent letter, (T, M, L,) and with damm and [sometimes] with kesr when it is followed by a conjunctive A; (M, L;) as in lamo Oarahu muco yawomaAni, and lamo Oarahu mucu Alyawomi, [and muci Alyawomi]: (T, L:) and so say most of the grammarians. (T.) Lḥ says, The Benoo-ʼObeyd, of the tribe of Ghanee, make the c of mc movent when it is followed by a movent or a quiescent letter, and make the noun following it to be in the nom. case, saying mucu Alyawomu; and some of them pronounce it with kesr when followed by a quiescent letter, saying muci Alyawomu; but this is not the proper way. (M, L.) In the phrase maA raOayotuhu mucu Alyawomi, the Arabs make the c movent because of the occurrence [otherwise] of two quiescent letters together; and they [generally] give it not kesr, but damm, because the latter is the final vowel of its original mnc. (M, L.) One says also, maA laqiytupu munoca Alyawomi, and muca Alyawomi, which fet-ḥ to the c in each. (Ḳ.) The Benoo-Suleym are related to have used the expression maA raOayotuhu minocu sit-N [by st- meaning six nights], with kesr to the m of mnc, and with the noun following it in the nom. case: and the tribe of 'Okl are related to have used the expression micu yawomaAni, with the n elided, and with kesr to the m, and damm to the c. (M, L.)

Each of the two words mnc and mc is also followed by a verbal proposition, as in the instance
maA zaAla muco Eaqadato yadaAhu UizaAzahu
[He has not ceased, since his two hands tied his wrapper of the lower part of the body]: or a nominal proposition, as in the instance
walaA zilotu OabogiI AlmaAla muco OanaA yaAfiEN
[And I ceased not to seek wealth from the time of my being a youth, or young man]: in such cases, each is an adv. n. prefixed to the proposition [and governing it virtually in the gen. case], or to a noun significant of time [understood as] prefixed thereto [in the same manner]: or, as some say, each is an inchoative. (Ḳ.)

The original of mc is mnc, because they restore the dammeh to the c in the case of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; as in the instance of mucu Alyawomi, for were not its original with damm, they would give it kesr: [but this some do, as has been shown above:] and because its dim. is munayocN: (Ḳ:) for when mc is used as a proper name of a man, its dim. is thus formed, by restoring the n, that it may be of the measure fuEayolN: (IJ, M, L:) or when mc is a noun, it is originally mnc; and when it is a particle, it is itself original. (Ḳ.)

Accord. to some, mnc (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and mc (Ḳ) are originally mino and Uico, which are made one word, (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by eliding the hemzeh, and then giving damm to the c because of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; (Ḳ;) munocu kaAna [and muco kaAna] meaning mino Uico kaAna: (T, L:) but there is nothing to indicate the truth of this opinion: (Ṣ, L:) or, as some say, mnc and mc are originally the prep. mn and cw in the sense of Al-aciI (L, Ḳ) in the dial. of Teiyi: so says Fr.; adding, that when either governs a gen. case, it is used in the manner of mano; and when it governs a nom. case, it is as though one said, [in using the expression munocu Oawo muco yawomaAni,] mina Ql-aciI huwa yawomaAni; and that the former government prevails in the case of mnc because the n is not suppressed: (L:) or, as some say, they are originally mino and the noun of indication caA; so that in the phrase maA raOayotuhu munocu yawomaAni, [accord. to more approved usage, muco yawomaAni,] we virtually say, mino caA Qlowaqoti yawomaAni: but each of these assertions is a deviation from the plain way. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. mahaja, aor. _a {yamohaju}, (inf. n. mahojN, TA,) He sucked [the breast of his mother].
mahaja Inivit ancillam suam. (Ḳ.)
mahaja He became goodly in countenance after disease. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. Oamotuhija ‡ His soul was torn from him. (A, Ḳ.)

muhojapN Blood: or the blood of the heart: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. muhajN. (A.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, dafanotu muhojatahu, meaning damahu: so in the Ṣ: but in a marginal note in a copy of that work, it is said that this is a mistake; and that the correct expression, as mentioned by IḲt and others, is dafaqotu muhojatahu I poured forth, or shed, his blood: and so it is in the copies of the A. (TA.) In like manner, dafaqa Qll-ehu muhojatahu ‡ May God destroy him! (A. [See also dafqa.])
Also, ‡ The soul, or spirit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. xarajato muhojatuhu ‡ His soul went forth, or departed. (Ṣ.) OunotuziEato muhojatuhu ‡ His soul was torn from him. (Ḳ.)

Also, ‡ One's self: the best of one's self, and one's powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy. (L.) Ex. bacalotu lahu muhojatiI ‡ I gave, or gave up, myself, and the best of my powers, efforts, endeavours, or energy, to him, or it. (T.)
Also, ‡ The purest, choicest, or best, of anything. (L.)
Also, † The heart. (MF.)
maAhijN: see OumohujN.

OumohujN (Ḳ) and OamohujaAnN↓ and maAhijN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) Thin milk: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, the first and second, milk free from water: and, the second, milk of which the froth has become still, and which is clear, and not thick: and, the last, thin milk, of which the taste has not changed; as also OumohuwjN↓. (TA.)
Also, the first, Thin fat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also the second and third: (Ḳ:) or raw fat. (M.)
The first is an epithet of a form not mentioned by Sb. (TA.) It may be a contraction of OumohuwjN. (IJ.) [And the like may be said of OumoludN.]
OumohujaAnN: see OumohujN.
OamohuwjN: see OumohujN.
mamohuwju AlbaToni Lax in the belly. (Ḳ.)

1. mahada, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamohadu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. mahodN [q. v. infra]; (Ṣ, L;) and mh-d↓, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. tamohiydN; (TA;) He made plain, even, or smooth, this is the original signification: he made a place plain, even, or smooth, [makaAnFA being understood,] linafosihi for himself: (L:) he spread a bed, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and made it plain, even, or smooth. (Ṣ, L.)
mahada lahu † He did well, or kindly, in his affair in his absence; like fahada and faOada. (L, art. fhd.)
mahada, aor. _a {yamohadu}, (inf. n. mahodN, L,) He gained, or earned, or sought to gain sustenance, and worked, (L, Ḳ,) linafosihi for himself. (L.)
mahada linafosihi xayorFA, and Amthdhu↓, ‡ He prepared for himself good, good things, or the like. (L.)
mh-d↓ lahu manozilapF saniy-apF ‡ [He prepared, or established, for him a high station]. (A.)

maA Qmotahada↓ fulaAnN EinodiI yadFA ‡ [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, a benefit, for me to owe it him]: you say this when one has not conferred upon you a favour or kindness. (AZ, L.) And maA Qmotahada↓ fulaAnN EinodiI mahoda caAka ‡ [Such a one has not prepared for himself, with me, that thing, that I should owe it him]; is said on one's asking a kindness without having previously conferred a benefit; (AZ, JK, L;) and with reference to one who acts in an evil manner, when asking a kindness, or when a kindness is asked for him. (AZ, L.)
2. mh-d, inf. n. tamohiydN, ‡ He adjusted, or arranged, an affair, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and made it plain, (A, Mṣb,) and easy. (Mṣb.) See 1.
mh-d nafosahu lifiEoli AlOamori † He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to do the thing. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* Mṣb, art. wTn.)
mh-d, inf. n. tamohiydN, ‡ He accepted, or admitted, an excuse. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, mah-adotu lahu AlEucora ‡ I accepted, or admitted, his excuse. (Mṣb.)
5. tmh-d and Amthd↓ It (a bed) became spread, and made plain, even, or smooth. (A.)
tmh-d lahu AlOamoru ‡ The affair became adjusted, or arranged, and made plain, and easy, for, or to, him. (Mṣb.)
tmh-d firaAXFA [He spread for himself a bed, and made it plain, even, or smooth]. (A.)
tamah-adato lahu EinodiI HaAlN laTiyfapN ‡ [A genteel situation was prepared for him with me, or at my abode]. (A.)
tmh-d † He (a man, TA) became possessed of authority and power; syn. tamak-ana. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
tmh-dt nafosuhu † His mind, or he, became disposed and subjected [lifiEoli AlOamori to do the thing; see 2]; syn. tawaT-anato. (Ḳ, art. wTn.)
8. Amthd It (a camel's hump) became spreading and high. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) See 1 in three places.
10. Astmhd firaAXFA [He asked, or desired, that a bed should be spread for him, and made plain, even, or smooth]. (A.)

mahodN [A child's cradle, or bed;] a place prepared for a child, and made plain, even, or smooth, (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ,) that he may sleep in it: (L:) a bed; a thing spread to lie, recline, or sit, upon; (A, Mṣb;) as also mihaAdN↓; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so called because of its plainness, evenness, or smoothness: (L:) Az says, that the latter word is more comprehensive than the former: (L:) it is applied to the ground, or earth; [meaning a plain, an even, or a smooth expanse; see a verse of Lebeed cited voce xawaAliqu:] (Az, L, Ḳ:) and so is mahodN: (Ḳ:) some say, that mahodN and mihaAdN↓ are [originally] two inf. ns., of the same meaning: or that the former is an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst.: or that the former is sing., and the latter pl.: (MF:) the pl. of the former [in common use] is muhuwdN, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and mihaAdN; and of the latter, [pl. of pauc.,] OamohidapN (L, Ḳ) and [of mult.,] muhudN. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Oalamo najoEali QloOaroDa mihaAdFA↓ [Ḳur, lxxviii. 6,] Have we not made the earth an expanse (bisaAT) adapted to be travelled over. (Ḳ, TA.)
labiYosa AlmihaAdu↓ [Ḳur. ii. 202,] ‡ Evil is that which he hath prepared for himself in his final place. (Ḳ.) Such is said to be the meaning. (TA.)
sahodN mahodN Good; goodly: the latter word is an imitative sequent. (L.)

muhodN Elevated ground or land: (IAạr, L, Ḳ:) or depressed and smooth and even ground or land; (Ḳ;) as also muhodapN↓: (En-Naḍr, Ḳ:) pl. mihadapN and OamohaAdN: (Ḳ:) but the former of these pls. is doubtful. (TA.)
muhodapN: see muhodN.
mihaAdN: see mahodN.
mahiydN Pure butter: (L, Ḳ:) or the purest of butter when melted, and that which has the least milk. (L.)
mumah-adN ‡ Lukewarm water; neither hot nor cold. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. mahara AlmaroOapa, (AZ, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yamoharu} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yamohuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mahorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) He gave the woman a mahor [or dowry]: (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he assigned to her (jaEala lahaA) a mahor: (Ḳ:) and OamoharahaA↓ signifies the same as maharahaA, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, and the more usual: (Mṣb:) or maharahaA has the first of the above significations, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or signifies he set apart for her a mahor: (Mṣb:) and OamoharahaA↓ signifies he named for her a mahor and married her to himself for it; (A, Mgh;) or he married her to another man for a certain mahor; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or he sent for her a mahor. (TA.)

mahara AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and fiyhi, and bihi (Ḳ,) and tmh-r↓ fiyhi, (Ḳ,* TA,) and mahara SinaAEatahu, (A,) and fiyhaA, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and bihaA, and tmh-r↓ fiyhaA, (A,) and mahara fiI AlEilomi wagayorihi, (Mṣb,) aor. _a {yamoharu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mahaArapN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mihaArapN (L) and muhuwrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and mahaArN and mahorN, (Ḳ,) He was, or became, skilled, or expert, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in his art, or craft, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and in science, &c., (Mṣb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. Hacaqa. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
2. mh-r, inf. n. tamohiyrN, He desired a colt: (Ḳ, TA:) he procured for himself a colt. (JK, Ḳ, TA.) [In the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, we find Almahor put by mistake for Almuhor.] Aboo-Zubeyd says, describing a lion,
Oaqobala yarodiI kamaA yarodiI AlHiSaAnu UilaI
musotaEosibK OaribK minohu bitamohiyri
He came [beating the ground with his feet] like as a horse comes [so beating the ground] to a man borrowing him for covering, wanting by his means to procure for himself a colt. (TA.) [In the L, and TA, yarowiI is put for yrdI in both instances: but it is corrected by SM in the margin of the L.]

hom.sense: 4. Amhr AlmaroOapa: see 1, in two places.

Amhr Aln-aAqapa He called, or rendered, (jaEala) the she-camel a mahoriy-ap: (Ḳ:) [it has sometimes, if not always, the latter meaning; for] it is said of the breaker, or trainer; and is like OaroHalahaA. (TA, in art. rHl.)
Amhrt Alfarasu The mare had a colt following her. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.

mahorN A dowry; a nuptial gift; a gift that is given to, or for, a bride; syn. SadaAqN: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. muhuwrN, (Ḳ,) or muhuwrapN, like as buEuwlapN is pl. of baEolN, and fuHuwlapN of faHolN. (Mṣb.) zawojN mahorK A husband from whom a dowry is got: (Ṣ, art. bhr:) or a husband who has not nobility of race, and who therefore doubles the dowry to make himself desired. (TA, same art.) See bahorN.
The hire of a prostitute. Ex. nahaI Eano mahori AlbagiI- He forbade [receiving] the hire of the prostitute. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

muhorN A colt; the male foal of a mare; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of a mare kept for breeding: (TA:) or the first male offspring of a mare or other animal; (Ḳ;) i. e., of a tame ass;, &c.: (ISd, TA:) fem. with p {muhorapN}; a filly: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and dim. muhayorN: (JK:) pl. masc., (of pauc., TA,) OamohaArN, and (of mult., TA) mihaArN and mihaArapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and pl. fem. muharN and muharaAtN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

UibilN mahoriy-apN Camels of Mahreh; i. e. certain camels, so called in relation to Mahreh Ibn-Heydán, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a tribe, (Ḳ,) or a great tribe, (TA,) or the father of a tribe of El-Yemen: (Ṣ:) or in relation to Mahreh, a district of 'Omán: (Mṣb:) they are excellent camels, that outstrip horses; and some add, that they are unequalled in quickness of running, understanding what is desired of them with the least training, and having names, by which being called, they answer quickly: (Mṣb:) [and hence, any such like camels; i. e. any excellent, fleet, camels: (see 4:) n. un. mahoriI-N:] pl. mahaAriI-u [which is irreg. like ZahaAriI-N] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mahaArK (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mahaAraI, (Ḳ, TA,) written in the L mahaAriI, (TA,) [and so in the CK,] or mahaAraA, the I being changed into A, (Mṣb,) [but it generally retains the form of I, though pronounced A.] See also HuwXiI-N.
mahiyrapN [A woman to whom a dowry has been given: and hence,] a free [married] woman: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) opposed to sur-iy-apN: (A:) pl. mahaAYiru. (A, TA.) And, (TA,) One whose dowry is dear. (Ḳ, TA.)

maAhirN Skilled, or skilful, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fI SinaAEatihi, in his art, (A, Mṣb,) and bkul-i EamalK, in every work, (A, Ḳ,) fiI Eilomi wagayorihi in science, &c., (Mṣb,) knowing its abstrusities and niceties, or having learned the whole of it; syn. HaAciqN: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ,) in most instances, (TA,) [but only when used absolutely,] a good swimmer; (JK, Ḳ;) as also mutamah-irN↓: (Z, TA;) pl. maharapN: (A, Ḳ:) also mutamah-irN↓ a lion skilled in slaying his prey. (Ḳ.)
mumohirN A mare having a colt or foal. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

mamohuwrapN A woman dowered; to whom a dowry has been given; or for whom a dowry has been set apart. (Mṣb.) It is said in a proverb, kaQlomamohuwrapi UiHodaI xadamatayohaA [Like her who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or OaHomaqu mina Qlomamohuwrapi UiHodaI xadamatayohaA [More stupid than she who has been dowered with one of her two anklets]: (Mgh:) applied to him who has reached the utmost degree of stupidity: from the following case: (TA:) a stupid woman demanded of her husband her dowry, (Ḳ, TA,) when he paid her his first visit, and she said, I will not obey thee unless thou give me my dowry: (TA:) so he pulled off one of her two anklets (Ḳ, TA) from her foot, (TA,) and gave it to her, and she was content with it. (Ḳ, TA.) In like manner, a certain man gave to another property, and he married with it the daughter of the giver, and then reproached her for the dowry he had given her: so they said, kaQlomamohuwrapi mino maAli OabiyhaA [Like her who has been dowered from the property of her father]: (Ḳ, TA:) [a proverb] applied in relation to him who reproaches for that which is not his own. (TA.)
mutamah-irN: see maAhirN, in two places.

1. maMCa, aor. yamuwoCu, inf. n. mawoCN (Ḳ, TA: in the CK muwoCN) and muWaMCN (but see below) or (as in some copies of the Ḳ) muwaMCN; (Ḳ;) and OamowaOa↓; (AA;) It (a cat) mewed: (Ḳ:) like maOaI, (TA,) and OamaA. (Ṣ in art. Amw.)
4. AmwO: see 1.
Also, He (a man) mewed like a cat. (Ḳ.)
muWaMCN, accord. to the Ḳ, an inf. n. of maMCa; but accord. to the L and other lexicons, The mew of a car; a word expressing the sound of mewing. (TA.)
maWuwoCN (in some copies of the Ḳ, mawuwoCN,) A mewing cat. (Ḳ.)
maAYiYapN and maAYiy-apN and maAYiyapN [and epithet of] A cat. (Ḳ.)

1. maAta, aor. yamuwtu, (inf. n. mawotN; Mṣb,) and maAta, (originally mawita, like xaAfa, originally xawifa, MF) [sec. per. mit-a,] aor. yamaAtu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which latter is of the dial. of Teiyi; (TA;) and maAta, (in which the medial radical letter is originally I, like baAEa, MF) aor. yamiytu, (Ḳ,) a form which some have disapproved; (MF;) and maAta, (originally mawita, Kr,) sec. pers. mit-a, aor. yamuwtu, like daAma, (originally dawima, Kr,) aor. yaduwmu, (Kr, Mṣb, &c.,) and like the sound verbs naEima, aor. yanoEumu, and faDila, aor. yafoDulu, (TA,) of the class of words in which two dial. forms are intermixed; (Mṣb;) He died; contr. of HayiI. (Ḳ,)

[maAta Eano baniyna wabanaAtK He died having passed away from, i. e. leaving behind him, sons and daughters. And maAta Eano vamaAniyna sanFp He died having passed beyond eighty years; i. e. being eighty years old.]

All-abanu laA yamuwtu [The milk will not die], in a saying of ʼOmar, in a trad., means, that if a child sucks the milk of a dead woman, it becomes unlawful for him afterwards to marry any of her relations who would be unlawful to him if he sucked her milk while she was living: or it means, that, if milk taken from the breast of a woman is given to a child to drink, and he drinks it, the consequence is the same; that the effect of the milk in producing this consequence is not annulled by its separation from the breast; for whatever is separated from a living being is termed myt, or dead, except the milk and hair and wool on account of the necessity of making use of these. (TA.)
maAtati AlOaroDu, inf. n. mawataAnN and mawaAtN, ‡ The land became destitute of cultivation and of inhabitants. (Mṣb.)
maAta ‡ It (soil) became deprived of vegetable life. Hence an expression in the Ḳur, xxx. 18. (Az, Er-Rághib.)
maAta ‡ He became deprived of sensation; [dead as to the senses]. So in the Ḳur, xix. 23: [but this appears to me doubtful]. (Az, Er-Rághib.)
maAta ‡ He became deprived of the intellectual faculty; [intellectually dead;] or ignorant. Hence an expression in the Ḳur, vi. 122; and another in the Ḳur, xxvii. 82; and xxx. 51. (Az, Er-Rághib.)
maAta ‡ [He became as though dead with grief, or sorrow, and fear;] he experienced grief, or sorrow, and fear, that disturbed his life. Hence what is said in the Ḳur, xiv. 20. (Az, Er-Rághib.)
maAta ‡ He or it, was or became, still, quiet, or motionless. (Ḳ.)
mAtati Alr-iyH ‡ The wind became still, or calm. (TA.)
maAta ‡ He slept. (AA, Ḳ.)
maAtati Aln-aAru, inf. n. mawotN, ‡ [The fire died away;] the ashes of the fire became cold, or cool, and none of its live coals remained. (TA.)
maAta ‡ It (heat or cold) became assuaged. (TA.)
maAta ‡ It (water) became dried up by the earth. (TA.)
maAta (and AstmAt↓, TA.) ‡ It (a garment, TA,) wore out; became worn out. (A, Ḳ.)
mAt ‡ It (a road) ceased to be passed along. (TA.)
baladN tamuwtu fiyhi Alr-iyHu [A town, or country, &c., in which the wind becomes broken, or loses its force]. (TA.)
maAta fuwqu Alr-ajuli ‡ The man slept heavily; became heavy in his sleep. (TA.)
yamuwtu mina AlHasadi ‡ [He dies, or will die, of envy]. (TA.)
maAta ‡ He became poor; was reduced to poverty: he became a beggar. (TA.)
‡ He became base, abject, vile, despicable, or ignominious. (TA.)
‡ He became extremely aged, old and weak, or decrepit. (TA.)
‡ He became disobedient, or rebellious. Iblees is said, in a trad., to be Oaw-alu mano maAta because he was the first who became disobedient, or rebellious. (TA.)
maAta † He (a man) became lowly, humble, or submissive, to the truth. (TA.)
2. maw-atati Ald-awaAb-u The beasts of carriage died in great numbers; or deaths amongst them were frequent. (TA.)
See 4.

3. [mAwthu,] inf. n. mumaAwatapN, He vied with him in patience, (Ḳ,) and in firmness, or steadiness, or the like. (TA.) [In the Ḳ, the inf. n. is expl. by muSaAbarap; and in the TA, by muvaAbatap also.]
4. AmAthu and mw-thu↓ (but the latter has an intensive signification, Ṣ,) He (God) caused him to die; put him to death; killed him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AmAt ‡ He (a man) lost a son, or sons, by death. (ISk, Ṣ.)
AmAt fulaAnN baniyna Such a man lost sons by death. (A.)
AmAtt She (a woman, AO, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a camel, Ṣ, Ḳ.) lost her offspring by death. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AmAtwA Death [or a mortal disease] happened among their camels. (Ḳ.)

maA Oamowatahu signifies maA Oamowata qalobahu [‡ How dead is his heart!] for one does not wonder at any action that does not increase: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) therefore what is here meant is not literally death. (TA.)
AmAthu ‡ He (God) rendered him poor; reduced him to poverty. (TA, from a trad.)

AmAthu ‡ He [or it] caused him to sleep. Ex., in a prayer said on awaking, AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-aciI OaHoyaAnaA baEoda maA OamaAtanaA Praise be to God who hath awaked us after having caused us to sleep! (L.)
yumiytu All-ayola † He sleeps during the night. (W, p. 9.)

AmAt All-aHoma, (and mw-thu↓, TA,) He took extraordinary pains in thoroughly cooking, and in boiling, the meat. (Ḳ.) And in like manner, onions, and garlic, so as to deprive them of their strong taste and odour. (TA.)
Oumiytati Alxamoru The wine was cooked, and ceased to boil. (TA.)
[AmAthu is also employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the primitive verb.]
6. Darabotuhu fatamaAwata ‡ I beat him and he feigned himself dead, being alive. (TA.)
‡ He pretended to be weak and motionless by reason of acts of devotion and fasting: [see the act. part. n. below]. (TA.)
10. AstmAt [He sought death:, &c.: see musotamiytN].
UisotamiytuwA Sayodakumo, and daAb-atakumo, Wait until ye ascertain that your game, and your beast of carriage, has died. (A.)
AstmAt [properly, He sought, or courted, death;] i. q. Astqtl; (Ṣ, Ḳ; in art. qtl;) meaning he cared not for death, by reason of his courage. (JM, in art. qtl.)
AstmAt † He (a man) was pleased with death; content to die. (TA.)
AstmAt † He (a man, TA.) tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking a thing. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
AstmAt, inf. n. UistimaAtN, (occurring thus with the final p elided, TA,) † He (a man, and a camel, IAạr,) became fat after having been emaciated, (IAạr, Ḳ.)
AstmAt ‡ It (a thing) became relaxed, loose, or flabby. (A.)

AstmAt liynFA † It attained the utmost degree of softness: said of a fine skin, that is likened to the thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg: and of other things, as also AstmAt fiI All-iyni: and in like manner, fiI AlS-alaAbapi, in hardness. (TA.) See musotamiytN
And see 1.

mawotN (and mawataAnN↓, TA,) Death; lifelessness; contr. of HayaApN: (Ṣ, TA:) as also muwaAtN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mamaAtN↓. [Occurring in the Ḳur, vi. 163, xvii. 77, and xlv. 20,] (Ṣ,* TA, in art. HI, and Jel, in vi. 163.) [See also muwtaAnN, below: and see 1.] Or mawataAnN↓, signifies much death, like as HayawaAnN signifies much life. (Mṣb, in art. HI.)
Almawotu AlOaboyaDu, and AljaArifu, and All-aAfitu, and AlfaAtilu, Sudden death. (IAạr, in T and TA, art. flt.)
Almawotu AlOaHomaru Death by slaughter with the sword. (IAạr, in T, TA, art. flt.)
Almawotu AlOasowadu Death by drowning, and by suffocation. (IAạr, in T and TA, art. flt.)
banaAtu Almawoti † [The daughters of death;] meaning deadly arrows. (A, TA, voce jaEobapN, q. v.)
mayotN: see may-itN.
OaroDN mayotapN: see mawaAtN: Unfruitful land; like as ArD Hay-apN means fruitful land, or land abounding with herbage. (TA, in art. HI.)
mayotapN Carrion: whatsoever hath not been killed in the manner prescribed by the law. (Ḳ, Jel, ii. 168.) See may-itN.

muwtapN ‡ A fainting, or swoon; (Ḳ;) and languor in the intellect: (TA:) or [an affection] like a fainting, or swoon: (Lḥ:) madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession; syn. junuwnN; (AO, Ḳ;) because it occasions a stillness like death: (TA:) or a kind of madness or diabolical possession (junuwnN), and epilepsy, that befalls a man; on the recovery from which, his perfect reason returns to him, as to one who has been sleeping, and to one who has been drunk. (Ṣ.) [See humozN.]
miytapN A kind, mode, or manner, of death: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. miyatN. (TA.)
maAta fulaAnN miytapF HasanapF Such a one died a good kind of death. (Ṣ.)
maAta miytapF jaAhiliy-apF He died a pagan kind of death, in error and disunion. (TA, from a trad.)

mawotaAnu AlfuWaAdi ‡ A man who is [dead, or] not lively, in heart: (A:) a man who is stupid, dull, unexcitable, or not to be rendered brisk, sprightly, or lively; (Ṣ,. Ḳ;) as though the heat of his intelligence had cooled and died: (TA:) fem. with p {mawotaAnapN}. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See muwtaAnN and mawaAtN.

muwtaAnN (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and mawotaAnN↓ (Ḳ) and muwaAtN↓ (Fr) Death, [or a mortal disease, or a murrain,] that befalls camels or sheep or the like. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) The first is of the dial. of Temeem: the second, of the dial. of others. (Et-Tilimsánee.)
waqaEa fiI AlmaAli muwtaAnN, and muwaAtN↓, Death [or a mortal disease] happened among the camels, &c. (Fr.)

Also, The like among men. Ex., from a trad., yakuwnu fiI Aln-aAsi muwtaAnN kaquEaASi Alganami There will be, among men, a mortality, or much death, [or mortal disease], like the quEaAS that befalls sheep or goats. (TA.)

mawataAnN † Inanimate things, or goods; dead stock; such as lands and houses [&c.]; (Ṣ;) contr. of HayawaAnN [q. v.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is made of this measure to agree in measure with its contr. HywAn: both these words deviate from the constant course of speech; being of a measure properly belonging to inf. ns. (TA.) [See also mawaAtN.]
UiXotari AlmawataAna walA taXotari AlHayawaAna Buy lands and houses [or the like], and buy not slaves and beasts of carriage [&c.]. (Ṣ.)
rajulN yabiyEu AlmawataAna A man who sells utensils or furniture or the like, and anything but what has life. (L.)
See also mawotN.
mawaAtN That wherein is no spirit or life; an inanimate thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also mawataAnN.]

mawaAtN (you say OaroDN mawaAtN, TA,) ‡ Land that has no owner (Ṣ, Ḳ) of mankind, and of which no use is made, or from which no advantage is derived, (Ṣ,) and in which is no water: such as is also called OaroDN mayotapN↓: (En-Nawawee:) land that has not been sown, nor cultivated, nor occupied by any man's camels, &c.: mawataAnN↓ signifies the same as muwaAtN (mawaAtN?), namely, land that is no man's property; and is also written mawotaAnN: (L:) or mawataAnN signifies land that has not yet been brought into a state of cultivation: (Fr, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) in a trad. it is said, that such land is the property of God and his Apostle; and whosoever brings into a state of cultivation such land, to him it belongs. (Ṣ.)
muwaAtN: see mawotN and muwtaAnN.

may-itN and mayotN↓ signify the same, [Dead, or dying]: (Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former is originally mayowitN, of the measure fayoEilN: (Ṣ:) the latter is contracted from the former; and is both masc. and fem.; (Zj, Ṣ;) as is also the former. (Zj.) 'Adee Ibn-Er-Raalà says,
layosa mano maAta faQsotaraAHa bimayotK↓
Uin-amaA Almayotu may-itu AlOaHoyaMCi
[He who has died and become at rest is not dead: the dead is only the dead of the living]. (Ṣ, TA.) Or mayotN↓ signifies One who has died (actually, TA,); and may-itN, as also maAYitN↓, one who has not yet died, (Ḳ,) but who is near to dying: or, accord. to a verse cited by AA, to Kh, mayotN is applied to him who is borne to the grave; [i. e., who is dead, or lifeless]; and may-itN, to him who [is dying, but] has life in him. (TA.) Fr says, you say of him who has not died, Uin-ahu maAYitN↓ Eano qaliylK and may-itN; but you do not say of him who has died hcA maAYitN↓: (Ṣ:) but some say, that this is an error, and that may-itN is applicable to that which will soon die. Those who assert that my-t is applicable only to the living adduce the following words of the Ḳur, [xxxix. 31,] Uin-aka may-itN waUin-ahumo may-ituwna: (TA:) i. e. Verily thou wilt die, and verily they will die. (Mṣb.) MF observes, that mayotN is asserted to be contracted from may-itN; and if so, that there can be no difference in their meanings: that the making a difference between them is contrary to analogy; agreeably with which, they should be like hayonN and hay-inN, and layonN and lay-inN: and also contrary to what has been heard from the Arabs; for they made no difference in their use of these two words. (TA.) [See also what is said of mayotapN, below.] The pls. are OamowaAtN and mawotaI and may-ituwna and mayotuwna. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The first of these is pl. of may-itN, and consequently of mayotN, because this latter is contracted from the former: as may-itN is of the measure fayoEilN, and this measure resembles faAEilN, it has received a form of pl. which is sometimes applicable to the measure fAEl: (Sb:) or AmwAt is [only] pl. of mayotN. (Mṣb.) [The second form (which is applied to rational beings, Mṣb,) is also pl. of my-t and myt.] The third and fourth are [only] applied to rational beings. (Mṣb.) The fem. epithet is may-itapN and mayotapN and may-itN (Ḳ, TA) and mayotN. (TA; and so in some copies of the Ḳ, in the place of may-itN.) may-itapN is an epithet applied to a female rational being; [and its pl. is may-itaAtN:] mayotapN, to a female brute, for the sake of distinction; and its pl. is mayotaAtN: the latter is contracted because it is more in use than the former epithet applied to a female rational being: (Mṣb:) the pl. of my-t and myt as fem. epithets is as above [OamowaAtN and mawotaI]. (TA.)

mayotapN↓ signifies That which has not been slaughtered (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) [in the manner prescribed by the law, i. e., carrion]: or that of which the life has departed without slaughter: so in the classical language and in the language of practical law: all such is unlawful to be eaten, except fish and locusts, which are lawful by universal consent of the Muslims: (En-Nawawee:) or, in the common acceptation of the language of law, what has died a natural death, or been killed in a state or manner different from that prescribed by the law, either the agent or the animal killed not being such as is so prescribed; as that which is sacrificed to an idol, or slaughtered [by a person] in the state of UiHoraAm, or not by having the throat cut, and that which it is unlawful to eat, such as a dog: (Mṣb:) [and any separated part of an animal of which the flesh is not lawful food: see EaAjN.]
baladN may-itN A tract of land without herbage, or pasture, (Mṣb, in art. bld.)
may-itN † An unbeliever; like as HaI-N means a Muslim. (TA, in art. HI.)
[may-itN and mayotN are employed in various other senses, agreeably with the senses of the verb.]
maAYitN: see may-itN.
fulaAnN maAYitN fI Algam-i ‡ [Such a one is dying, or absorbed, in grief]. (TA.)
mawotN maAYitN A severe, painful, or violent, death: (TA:) like layolN laAYilN: the latter word being added to corroborate the former. (Ṣ.)
mamaAtN: see mawotN.
mumiytN and mumiytapN ‡ A woman, and a she-camel, that has lost her offspring by death: (Ṣ:) and a woman who has lost her husband by death: (TA:) pl. mamaAwiytu. (Ṣ.)
mutamaAwitN ‡ [Feigning himself dead].
