‡ An epithet applied to A hypocritical devotee, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who pretends to be like one dead in his devotion, who lowers his voice, and moves little: as though he were one who put on the outward appearance of devotees, and constrained himself to characterize himself by the characteristics of the dead, that he might be imagined to be weak by reason of much devotion. (TA.)

hom.sense: musotamiytN A courageous man, who seeks, or courts death: (Ḳ:) a man who seeks to be slain; who cares not, in war, for death: (Ṣ:) abandoning, or devoting, himself to death, (msotarosilN lilomawoti,) as also musotaqotilN. (A.)
† Abandoning, or devoting himself to a thing, or affair; syn. musotarosilN liOamorK. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
hawa musotamiytN UilaI kacaA, as also musotaholikN, ‡ He [is devoted to such a thing, so that he] imagines that he shall die if he do not attain it. (A.)

Ru-beh says,
wazabadu AlbaHori lahu katiytu
waAll-ayolu fawoqa AlmaACi musotamiytu
[And to the froth of the sea there was a sound like that of boiling, and night impended over the water]. (Ṣ.) [It is implied in the Ṣ that mstmyt here signifies musotarosil.]
† One who feigns himself to be insane, or possessed by a devil; not being really so. (TA.)
† One who feigns lowliness, or submissiveness, in voice, &c., to this man until he feeds him, and to this until he feeds him, and, when he is satiated, is ungrateful to his benefactors. (TA.)
† One who makes a show of being good and quiet or tranquil, and is not so in reality. (Ibn-El-Mubárak.)
musotamiytN The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (Ḳ.) [See 10: and see also musotamiyvN, in art. myv.]

entry.sense: 1. maAva, aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN (and in the CK mawavN) and mawavaAnN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also maAva, aor. yamiyvu; (TA;) and AmAv↓; (Hr;) but this is disapproved by IAth; He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also art. myv.]
See also 7.
mAvati AlOaroDu The land became soft and even. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1.

7. AnmAv, inf. n. AinomiyaAvN, It (a thing) was steeped in water, and mashed with the hand: (TA:) it was mixed and moistened in water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also art. myv.] maAva↓, aor. yamuwvu, is also [thus] used intransitively. (Mṣb.)
miyvaACu, with kesreh, of the measure mifoEaAlN Soft and even land. (Mṣb.) [See also mayovaACu, in art. myv.]

1. maAja, aor. yamuwju, inf. n. mawojN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and mawajaAnN and muWuwjN; (TA;) It (the sea) was in a state of commotion; was tumultuous; (Mṣb;) was agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tmw-j↓: (TA;) or this latter signifies it (the sea) was, or became, very tumultuous. (Mṣb.) [You say,] maAja Almawoju The waves were in a state of commotion; were tumultuous; conflicted, or dashed together. (TA.) [And hence,] maAja Oamoruhumo † Their affair became in a confused and disturbed state. (TA.)
maAja, inf. n. mawojN and mawajaAnN, † It (anything) was in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.)
maAja ‡ He was in a state of commotion, or agitation, and confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (IAạr.)
Aln-aAsu yamuwjuwnN ‡ The people, or men, are in a state of commotion, or tumultuous. (Ṣ.)
maAjati Aln-aAsu ‡ The people were in a discordant and disturbed state of affairs. (Mṣb.)
maAja Eani AlHaq-i, inf. n. mawojN, ‡ He declined from the truth, or from the true, right, or just, course. (A, Ḳ.)

maAjati Ald-aAgiSapu, inf. n. muWuwjN, ‡ The patella, or knee-pan, moved backwards and forwards, or from side to side, between the skin and the bone, or, as in one copy of the Ḳ, flesh: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner Als-iloEapu [the ganglion]. (TA.)
5: see 1.
farasN gawojN mawojN: see art. gwj. mwj is here an imitative sequent. (TA.)
mawojapu AlX-abaAbi ‡ The prime of youth. (Ḳ.)

nAqp mawojaI † A swift (naAjiyap: in the CK naAjibap) she-camel, whose OanosaAE [or woven thongs of the fore girth] have moved round (jaAlat) by reason of the backward and forward motion (AixotilaAf) of her fore and hind legs. (Ḳ.)
maw-aAjN [A sea tumultuous with waves]. (Ḳ, art. rd.)
maAYijN A sea in a state of commotion; tumultuous; agitated with waves, conflicting, or dashing together. (TA.)
Also, and mutamaw-ijN↓, A man in a state of commotion, or agitation. (TA.)
mutamaw-ijN: see maAYijN.
1. maAca, [aor. yamuwcu,] He lied. (L.)
maAcN Good in natural disposition, happy in spirits, cheerful in mind, merry, jocose, (L, Ḳ,) and pleasant in speech. (L.) See TaAbN.
maAciI-N (Ḳ) and maAciy-apN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) A soft coat of mail, easy to the wearer; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and [so] the former, any weapon: (Ḳ:) or the latter, a white coat of mail. (Mṣb.)
Hence, (Mṣb,) the latter, White honey: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or [in the CK and] new honey: or pure honey: or excellent honey. (Ḳ.)
Also, the latter, Wine. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

1. maAra, aor. yamuwru, inf. n. maworN, It moved from side to side, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like the knee-pan on the knee; (A;) or to and fro, like as the tall palm-tree moves; (Ṣ;) as also tmw-r↓: (Ṣ:) it came and went; (T;) as also tmw-r↓. (Ḳ.) You say of a camel, tamuwru EaDudaAhu The upper bones of his two arms move from side to side. (Ṣ, TA.) And maAra Als-inaAnu fiI AlmaToEuwni [The spear-head moved from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) And AlT-aEonapu tamuwru The thrust inclines to the right and left. (TA.) And Aln-ujuwmu tamuwru The stars come and go. (TA.) And maAra AlgubaAru, inf. n. maworN, The dust moved to and fro: or became raised by the wind. (M, Ḳ.)

It moved round about, (T, TA,) and to and fro: (TA:) it was in a state of commotion; in a state of tumult: (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) said of the sea, (Mṣb,), &c.: (M:) it was in a state of quick motion or commotion. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., that when the soul, or spirit, was blown into Adam, maAra fiI raOosihi faEaTasa It circulated, and moved to and fro, in his head, and he sneezed. (TA.) And in the Ḳur, [lii. 9,] yawoma tamuwru Als-amaMCu maworFA On the day when the heaven shall actually be in a state of commotion, or tumult: so accord. to Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák: or shall move from side to side: so accord. to AO and Akh: (Ṣ:) or shall come and go; or move to and fro; or reel. (T.) And in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, bikataAYiba tamuwru karijoli AljaraAdi With troops moving to and fro, in a state of commotion, like the leg of the locust, by reason of their multitude. (TA.) You say also, maArati Aln-aAqapu fiI sayorihaA The she-camel was in a state of commotion, and reeled, in her pace, or going: and in like manner you say of a mare. (TA.)

maA OadoriI OagaAra Oamo maAra, a saying of the Arabs, related by IAạr, (TA,) I know not whether he have come to low country, or turned and returned to high country (najod): (Ṣ, TA:) or have come to the low country, or come to the high country. (IAạr, Ḳ,* TA.)

maAra Ald-amu (Ṣ, &c.) The blood ran, or flowed, upon the surface of the ground; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and in like manner you say of tears, meaning they flowed: (M:) or the blood poured upon the surface of the ground, and went hither and thither, (TA,) sideways. (A.)
See also 4.

4. AmAr Als-inaAna fiI AlmaToEawni [He made the spearhead to move from side to side in the person pierced]. (A.) AmArt Alr-iyHu AlgubaAra The wind made the dust to go to and fro: or raised the dust. (M, Ḳ.)
AmAr Ald-ama He made the blood to run or flow; (T, Ṣ,* IḲṭṭ, Mṣb;) as also maArahu↓, (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb,) inf. n. mayorN. (IḲṭṭ. [as in the TA; but this seems to be a mistake for maworN.])
5: see 1, in two places.
maworN A road: (T, Ṣ:) or a trodden and even road: (M, Ḳ:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: because people come and go upon it. (TA.)
muwrN Dust moving to and fro (M, Ḳ) in the air: (TA:) or raised by the wind: (M, Ḳ:) or carried to and fro by the wind. (T, Ṣ.)
See also maw-aArN.
maw-aArN, (TA,) or maw-aAru AlmilaATi, (Ṣ, TA,) A camel that moves the upper bones of his two arms from side to side; (Ṣ, TA;) and maw-aAru AlD-aboEayoni [signifies the same]. (A.)
maw-aArapN, (M, Ḳ,) or maw-aArapu Alyadi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) A she-camel quick in her pace: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or easy in her pace, and quick. (M, Ḳ.)
riyHN maw-aArapN Wind that blows the dust to and fro: or that raises the dust: pl. riyaAHN muwrN, which is extr. [with respect to rule]. (M.)

maAYiraAtN Bloods [flowing, and running hither and thither]. So in the following verse (of Rusheyd Ibn-Rumeyd El-'Anazee, TA; not of El-Aạshà [as it is said to be in the Ṣ in art. EwD;] Ṣgh, in TA, art. EwD:)
Halafotu bimaAYiraAtK Hawola EawoDK
waOanoSaAbK turikona ladaI Als-aEiyri [or Als-uEayori, i. e., I swore, or I swear, by bloods flowing and running hither and thither, around 'Owd, and stones set up to be worshipped, left by Es-Sa'eer or Es-So'eyr]. 'Owd and Es-Sa'eer [or Es-So'eyr] were two idols. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also another verse, cited in art. Ez.]

mawozN A certain kind of tree, (Mgh,) or fruit, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [the fruit of the banana-tree, or musa paradisiaca;] i. q. TaloHN [in one of the acceptations of this latter word]: (Mṣb:) it is lenitive, diuretic, provocative of venery, and augments the spermatic fluid and the phlegm and the yellow bile, and the eating much of it is very oppressive, (Ḳ,) for it is slow of digestion: (TA:) the tree grows in the manner of the barodiI-, [i. e., papyrus, or perhaps other rushes,] and has a long and broad leaf, which may be three cubits by two cubits, (AḤn, Mgh, TA,) the mawoz [i. e., the fruit] is found, where it grows, throughout the whole year, (AḤn, as cited by ʼAbd-El-Laṭeef,) and there may be on one of its racemes from thirty to five hundred fruits; (AḤn, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) this is seen in the districts of Makdishoo [between Abyssinia and the country of the Zenj]; (TA;) and when this is the case, the raceme is propped up; (AḤn, Mgh;) it rises to the height of the stature of a man, [and higher,] and its offsets continually grow around it, every one of them smaller than another; and when it has produced its fruit, the mother-tree is cut down at the foot, and its offset that has attained to its height fructifies, and becomes a mother, the rest remaining its offsets, and thus it continues: whence the saying of Ash'ab, to his son, as related by Aṣ, Wherefore dost thou not become like me? to which he answered, Such as I is like the mawozap, which does not attain to a good state until its mother dies. (AḤn, TA.) mawozapN is the n. un. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
maw-aAzN A seller of mawoz [or fruit of the bananatree]. (Ḳ.)

1. maAsa, aor. yamuwsu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. mawosN, (Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He shaved (Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) the head, (Ṣgh, Mṣb,) or the hair: (Ḳ:) but Ṣgh says, that its correctness requires consideration, and it was doubted by IF. (TA.) See muwsaI, below.

AlmaAsu, not OalomaAsN, (Ḳ,) i. e., with the disjunctive hemzeh, (TA,) for this is an incorrect pronunciation, (Ḳ,) of the vulgar, as Ṣgh and others have plainly asserted; but IAth says, I think that the hemzeh and lám in it are radical letters, as they are in AlyAs, [i. e., UiloyaAs or OaloyaAs,] and it is not Arabic; and if so, its place is under the letter hemzeh, because they say OalomaAsN; but if they be [prefixed] for the purpose of rendering the word determinate, the present is its [proper] place; (TA;) [The diamond;] a certain precious stone, (Ḳ,* TA,) reckoned among jewels, like the yaAquwt and the zumur-urc, (TA,) the largest of which is like the walnut, (Ḳ, TA,) or the egg of the pigeon, (TA,) and this is rare, or very rare, (Ḳ, TA,) the only instance being said to be the one called Alkawokabu Ald-ur-iI-u, which is suspended at the tomb of the Prophet: (TA:) it breaks all stony bodies, and the holding it in the mouth breaks the teeth, and fire has no effect upon it, nor iron, but only lead breaks it and powders it, [a strange mistake, for it is well known that it is powdered by being pounded in a steel mortar,] after which it is taken [in the state of powder] upon drills, and pearls, &c. are drilled with it. (Ḳ.)

muwsaI [A razor;] a certain instrument of iron, (M, Mṣb, TA,) with which one shaves: (Lth, L, Ḳ, TA:) of the measure fuEolaI, (Ks, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from Almawosu, [inf. n. of maAsa,] so that the m is a radical letter, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (TA,) [for] Lth says, (L, TA,) Almawosu is the root (taOosiys [lit. foundation]) of AlmuwsaI, (L, Ḳ, TA,) the thing with which one shaves; (L, TA;) therefore, (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) it is imperfectly decl., because of the short fem. A [written I], (Mṣb,) without tenween; (Az, Ḳ;) and Fr cites a verse [of obscene meaning] in which it is made fem.: (TA:) or it is from Oawosayotu raOosahu, meaning “I shaved his head,” (ISk, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure mufoEalN, (ISk, Mṣb, TA,) so that the I is a radical letter, as El-Umawee and Yz say, and Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-el-Alà inclined to think it so, (TA,) and therefore it is perfectly decl., (Mṣb,) with tenween, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) when indeterminate; (Mṣb;) or it is of the measure mufoEalN because this measure is more common than fuEolaI, and because it is perfectly decl. when indeterminate, whereas fuEolaI is not so when indeterminate and when determinate: (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, TA:) but IAmb says, that it is masc. and fem., and perfectly decl. and imperfectly decl.: ISk says, that the approved way is to make it perfectly decl.: (Mṣb:) [but] he says that it is fem. [also, and if so it is imperfectly decl.]: (TA:) and it is related of AʼObeyd, in the Bári', that he said he had not heard it made masc. except by El-Umawee; (Mṣb;) who asserted it to be masc. only: (TA:) the pl., accord. to him who makes it imperfectly decl., is muwsayaAtN; and accord. to him who makes it perfectly decl., mawaAsK. (Mṣb.) The dim. of mwsI, in the sense above explained, [not as a proper name, in which case it is muwsaI only, without tenween, and has no relation to the same word signifying a razor,] is muwayosiyapN, [but by rule it should be muwayosaI, like HubayolaI,] accord. to him who says hecihi muwsaI; and muwayosK accord. to him who says hecaA muwsFI. (ISk, TA.)

hom.sense: maAXN [Indian peas;] a certain grain, well known, (Ṣ in art. myX, and Ḳ,) round, smaller than the Him-aS [or chick-pea], of a tawny colour inclining to greenness; it is in Syria and India; and is sown; (TA;) also called maj-N and xul-arN and zin-N: (TA, art. mj:) it is of moderate temperature; and the mixture made thereof is commended, being beneficial to him who is fevered, and him who is affected with rheum; it is lenitive; and when cooked with vinegar, it is beneficial for purulent pustulous mange or scab; and an external application thereof strengthens feeble limbs: (Ḳ:) the word is arabicized [from the Persian maAXo], or post-classical. (Ṣ.)

Utensils and furniture, of the meaner sort, of a house or tent. (IAạr, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, AlmaAXu xayorN mino laAXa, [in one copy of the Ḳ I find laAXK, but the former seems to be the right reading,] meaning, [Mean household utensils and furniture are better than nothing; or] what is in the house, or tent, of worthless utensils and furniture, is better than its being empty: (Ḳ, TA:) lAX is here contracted [from laAXaIoCa] for the sake of its resembling mAX. (TA.) And xaAXa maAXa and xaAXi maAXi signify the same as maAXN thus used: (Ḳ, TA in art. xwX:) or the refuse, or meanest sort, of people, or of mankind; as in the M. (TA.)

entry.sense: mayobapN A certain remedy, or medicine: (Ḳ:) [an arabicized word] from the Persian maIo “a beverage,” and biho “a quince:” quince-beverage; diacydonium; a medicine prepared of the juice of quinces: some of it is raw; and some, not raw: some is perfumed; and some, not perfumed. (TA, from the book entitled Má lá yesa'u, &c.)
1. maAta, aor. yamiytu: see art. mwt.
dArI bimiytaACi daArihi, [as also bimiydaACi,] My house is opposite to his house. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art. AtI.]
miytaACu TariyqK The measure of the two sides, and the distance, of a road; as also miydaAC. (L, not in the TA.) [See also art OtI.]

1. maAva, aor. yamiyvu, (inf. n. mayovN, Ḳ,) i. q. maAva, aor. yamuwvu, inf. n. mawovN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [in the CK, for Almawovu is put Almawotu;] as also my-v↓, inf. n. tamoyiyvN; (Ḳ;) and AmAv↓, inf. n. UimaAvapN; but this is disapproved by IAth; (TA;) and AmtAv↓, inf. n. UimotiyaAvN; (Ḳ;) and Uim-aAva↓, [for UinomaAva,] inf. n. Uim-iyaAvN; (TA;) [but the last form I have only found used intransitively;] He steeped a thing in water, and mashed it with his hand: (TA:) he mixed and moistened a thing in water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or mAv and my-v↓, he steeped anything, such as saffron, and dates, and raisins, and the preparation of churned milk called OaqiT, in water, so that it dissolved, and mashed it with his hand. (Lth.)
maAva He dissolved salt in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner clay, or loam. (ISk.)
Qll-ehum-a mivo quluwbahumo kamaA yumaAvu AlmiloHu fiI AlmaACi [O God, dissolve their hearts, like as salt is dissolved in water!] (TA, from a trad.)
2. my-v: see 1.
‡ He rendered a man gentle. (TA.)
‡ He rendered a man submissive. (TA.)
‡ It (fortune, or misfortune,) rendered a man expert and submissive. (TA.)
[And so] tmy-v↓ ‡ He (a man) became submissive, and languid, or flaccid. (TA.)
4. Oamoyava see 1.
5. tmy-vt AlOaroDu The ground became softened (and cooled, Ṣ,) by rain. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also maAvati AlOaroDu, in art. mwv.] See 2.
7. AnmAv, [inf. n. UinomiyaAvN;] (ISk;) and Uim-aAva, inf. n. Uim-iyaAvN; (Lth;) It (salt) became dissolved in water; (ISk, Lth;) and in like manner, clay, or loam. (ISk.)
See 1.
8. AmtAv, (inf. n. UimotiyaAvN, TA,) He attained to an easy state of life; (Ḳ;) or a pleasant life. (TA.)
AmtAv He steeped in water, and mashed with his hand, and drank, the preparation of churned milk called OaqiT. (Ḳ.)
See 1.
may-ivN Soft. (Ḳ.)
rajulN may-ivu Alqalobi ‡ A man of soft, or gentle, heart. (TA.)

mayovaACu Even, or plain, or soft, land: pl. miyvN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you say, OaroDN mayovaMCu, and OaraADK miyvu: (A:) [see also miyvaMCu, in art. mwv:] an even, or a plain, or soft, tract of sand: and a hill of good soil: (L:) and a [water-course such as is called] taloEap, that becomes as large as half, or twothirds, of the valley. (L, Sh, in TA, voce tlEp.)
musotamiyvN The thin pellicle that adheres to the white of an egg. (AA, Ḳ.) [See also musotamiytN, in art. mwt.]

hom.sense: 1. maAHa, aor. yamiyHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mayoHN; (A, Ḳ;) and AmtAH↓; (A, [and the same seems to be indicated in the Ṣ, where it is said that UimotiyaAHN signifies the same as mayoHN;]) He descended into, (Ṣ, A,) or entered, (Ḳ,) the well, and filled the bucket: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) this is done when its water is little. (Ṣ.)
maAHa AlmaMCa, aor. yamiyHu; and AmtAHhu↓; He drew water by descending into the well and filling the bucket. (A.)

maAHa fiI miXoyatihi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,*) inf. n. mayoHN and mayoHuwHapN; (Ḳ;) and my-H↓, and tmAyH↓; (A;) ‡ He walked in a certain elegant manner, (Ḳ,) with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (Ṣ, A,) like as a duck walks. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mar-a yatamay-aHu↓ ‡ He passed along so walking, and looking at his shadow. (A.)

Also tmy-H↓ ‡ He inclined his body from side to side in walking: (Ḳ:) and tmAyH↓ he, or it, (a drunken man, and a branch, Ṣ,) inclined from side to side; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also my-H↓ and tmy-H↓: (TA:) which last is also said of a branch, or twig. (M, L, art. rOd.)
Als-akoraAnu yatamay-aHu↓, and yatamaAyaHu↓, ‡ [The drunken man reels, or inclines from side to side in walking]. (A.)
maAHati Alr-iyHu AlX-ajarapa † The wind made the tree to incline. (TA.)
mAHhu Einod Als-uloTaAni, aor. yamiyHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. mayoHN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He interceded for him with the Sultán. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maAHahu, aor. yamiyHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mayoHN and miyaAHapN; and AmtAHhu↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He gave him [a thing]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maAHa ‡ He conferred a benefit, favour, or kindness. (L.)

maAHa faAhu biQlomisowaAki, aor. yamiyHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mayoHN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with a toothstick: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [so accord. to the L; but in the Ḳ, and] he cleansed out the saliva from his mouth with the tooth-stick. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
3. mAyHhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mumaAyaHapN, (A,) ‡ He commingled, or conversed, or held intercourse, with him; (Ḳ;) namely, with a Sultán; and in like manner with women. (A.)
bayoniI wabayonahu mamaAyaHapN wamumaAlaHapN ‡ [Between me and him are a commingling, or converse, or intercourse, and fellowship in eating.] (A.)
5: see 1.
6: see 1.

hom.sense: 8. AmtAHhu: see 1.
‡ It (heat, and work or labour,) made him to sweat. (A.)
AmtAHt AlX-amosu ciforaI AlbaEiyri ‡ The sun drew forth the sweat from the protuberance of the camel's head, behind his ears. (Ḳ.)
See 10.

entry.sense: 10. AstmAHhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and AmtAHhu↓, (A,) ‡ He asked him for a gift. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) AmtAHhu↓ ‡ He came to him seeking his bounty. (L.)
AstmAHhu ‡ He asked him to intercede for him, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) Einoda Als-uloTaAni with the Sultan. (Ṣ, A.)
maAHN The yolk of an egg: or its white. (AA, Ḳ.) [See also muH-N.]
mayoHN ‡ Profit; advantage. (Ḳ.) See maAYiHN.
miyHN A bad kind of dates; i. q. XiySN (Ḳ.)
maAHapN The court of a house: (Ḳ:) a dial. form of baAHapN. (TA.)
may-aAHN ‡ A man who walks with a self-conceited gait, and with an affected inclining of his body from side to side: (L:) fem. with p {may-aAHapN}. (Ṣ, L.)
maAYiHN A man who descends into a well and fills the bucket, when its water is little: pl. maAHapN. (Ṣ.) The maAtiH is he who draws the water from the mouth of the well. (L.)
maAYiHN ‡ A tooth-stick; syn. siwaAkN: so called because it draws away the saliva, like as he who descends into a well ladles out the water: (L:) and so (accord. to some, TA) mayoHN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. maAda, aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mayadaAnN, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a thing) was, or became in a state of motion, or commotion; was, or became agitated: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, in a state of violent motion or commotion; or violently agitated. (El-Basáïr, TA.)
So in the expression in the Ḳur, [xvi. 15; and xxxi. 9;] Oano tamiyda bikumo Lest it (the earth) should be convulsed with you, and go round with you, and move you about violently. (El-Basáïr, TA.)
maAda It turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed. (IḲṭṭ.)
maAda fiI Alr-umoHi ‡ He (a man pierced) writhed upon the spear. (A.)
maAda It (the mirage, saraAb,) was in a state of commotion; it quivered, or trembled. (L, Ḳ.)
maAda † He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (TA.)

maAda, (aor. yamiydu, TA, inf. n. mayodN or mayadN, L,) ‡ He (a man, L,) became affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea. (L, Ḳ.)
You say also maAda bihi AlbaHoru, aor. yamiydu, inf. n. mayodN, ‡ The sea affected him with a heaving of the stomach, &c. (L.) And maAdato bihi AlOaroDu ‡ The ground went round with him. (A.)

maAdati AlHanoZalapu, (aor. yamiydu, L,) The colocynth became affected by day-dew, (L, Ḳ,) or by moisture, (L,) and in consequence, changed [in odour, or stinking]: (L, Ḳ:) and in like manner a date. (L.)
maAda, (Ṣ, A, L,) inf. n. mayodN (L) and mayadaAnN; (A;) and tmAyd↓; (A;) It (a branch) inclined from side to side. (Ṣ, A, L.)
‡ He inclined from side to side in walking. (L.)
maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It inclined to one side: as the earth is, in a trad., described to have done before the mountains were formed. (L.)

maAda ‡ He (a man, Ṣ,) affected a bending of his person, body, or limbs; (L;) he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and maAdato and tmy-dt↓ signify the same, said of a woman. (A.)
maAda He conferred, or bestowed, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours. You say, maAdaniI fulaAnN Such a one conferred a benefit or benefits upon me. (L.)
maAdah, (L, Mṣb,) and AmAdhu↓, (L,) He gave him. (L, Mṣb.)
maAda He furnished persons with, or gave them, provisions for travelling; syn. zaAda. (L.) [In the Ḳ, zaAra He visited.]
He brought a people wheat, or food; i. q. maAra, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of which it is a dial. form. (Ṣ.)
He trafficked as a merchant. (L.)
maAda, inf. n. mayodN and mayadaAnN, It increased, or grew; syn. raAEa and zakaA. (M, L, Ḳ.) [In the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, for rAE is put zAg.]

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
5: see 1.
6: see 1.
8. AmtAdhu He asked him, or desired him, to give him. (L.)
AmtAdhu He asked or desired him to bring him wheat, or food. (A.)

mayoda a dial. form of bayoda, (Ṣ,) in the sense of gayor: (Ṣ, L;) and in that of EalaI: (L:) or that of mino Oajoli. (Ṣ, L.) It is said in a trad., OanaA OafoSaHu AlEarabi mayoda Oan-iI mino qurayoXK wanaXaOotu fiI baniI saEodi boni bakorK [rendered in art. byd]. (Ṣ, L.) See what next follows.
faEalotuhu mayodaA celika, (M, Ḳ,) or mayoda clk, (L,) I did it on account, or for the sake, of that. (M, L, Ḳ.) mino mayodaA celika has not been heard. (M, L.)
mayodapN: see maAYidapN.

hom.sense: miydaMCN The amount, and measure, of a thing: (L, Ḳ:) and the two sides, and distance, or extent, of a thing, (L,) or of a road; (Ḳ;) and the surface of a road. (L.) One says, lamo Oadori maA miydaMCu celika I knew not what was the amount of that, and its measure: or, what was the measure of its two sides, and its extent: as also miytaAWuhu. (L.)
The extreme limit of the distance to which horses run; and so myiYotMCN. (Ṣ, TA, art. OtI.)

miydaMCN A mode, manner, fashion, or from. Ex. banuwoA buyuwtahumo EalaI miydaMCK waAHidK They built their houses, or constructed their tents, after one mode, &c. (L.) [See also miYotaMCN, in art. AtI.]

entry.sense: hecaA miydaAWuhu, [thus in the copies of the Ḳ and in the TA, app. a mistake for miydaMCahu, like tiloqaMCahu,] and bimiydaAYihi, and bimiydaAhu, This is opposite to, or facing, it. (Ḳ.) And daAriI bimayodaA daArihi, with fet-ḥ to the m; (as also bimiytaMCi dArh, L in art. myt; and bimiYotaMCi dArh, Ṣ in art. AtI;) My house is opposite to his house. (Yaạḳoob, L.)
miydaMCu AlTariyqi: see miYotaMCN in art. OtI, and miytaMCi in art. myt.

hom.sense: mayodaAnN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and miydaAnN↓ (Ḳ) A horse-course; race-ground; hippodrome: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. mayaAdiynu: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) of the measure faEolaAnN, (IḲṭṭ,) from mAd “it was in a state of motion;” because the sides of the horsecourse shake on the occasion of a race: (Mṣb:) or from mAd “it turned or twisted about, or became contorted and convulsed;” because the horses wheel about, and bend or convulse themselves, in the place so called: or of the measure faloEaAnN, from madFI “a limit, or goal;” because horses run to their goals in the place so called; originally madoyaAnN, the second and third radicals being transposed; as in biyzaAnN, originally buzoyaAnN: or of the measure fayoEaAlN, from madana “he abode, or dwelt;” because horses confine themselves especially to the place so called for wheeling about and the like. (IḲṭṭ.)
EayoXN mayodaAnN A delicate, a pleasant, or an ample and easy, life. (Ṣ, L.)
mayodaAnu AlxulafaMCi ‡ a term applied by historians to The period of the reign of Khaleefehs; from twenty to twenty-four years. (MF, TA.)

entry.sense: miydaAnN: see mayodaAnN.
mayuwdN That moves about, or is agitated, much; that vacillates much: (L:) an intensive epithet; applied in a trad. to worldly prosperity. (L., art. Hyd.)
may-aAdN: see maAYidN.
maAYidN ‡ A man affected with a heaving of the stomach, or a tendency to vomit, and a giddiness in the head, by reason of intoxication, or of voyaging upon the sea: pl. mayodaI. (L.)

maAYidN A branch inclining [from side to side: see 1]: (A, L:) as also may-aAdN↓: (L:) [or rather the latter signifies inclining much, or frequently, from side to side:] pl. [of the former] muy-adN. (TA.)

fulaAnN yamoXiI EalaI AlOaroDi fay-aAdFA may-aAdFA ‡ Such a one walks upon the ground with an elegant and a proud and a self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side. (A, Art. fyd.)

maAYidapN (and mayodapN↓, El-Jarmee, L, Ḳ) A table with food upon it: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) without food upon it, a table is not thus called, but is called xiwaAnN: (AAF, Ṣ, L:) or also applied to a table itself: (L:) MF says, that this latter application is allowable, considering that food has been, or is to be, placed upon the table: but El-Ḥareeree asserts it to be incorrect, and the former application only to be allowable: (TA:) mAYdp is thus used in its proper sense of an act. part. n., and is from mAd “it was in a state of motion;” as though the table [which was generally a round piece of leather or the like spread upon the ground] moved about with what was upon it: (Zj, L, Mṣb:*) or from mAd “he brought wheat or food;” because food is brought upon it [or as though it brought food]: (L:) or from mAd “he gave;” as though it gave of what was upon it to those around it: (El-'Ináyeh:) or it is of the form of an act. part. n. and used in the sense of a pass. part. n., from mAd “he gave,” (AO, Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) like raADiyapN in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN; (AO, Ṣ, L;) because what is thus called is given by its owner to the people [who are to eat]: (Mṣb:) also, food itself; (Akh, AḤát, ISd, L, Ḳ;) even if without a table: (L:) [pl. mawaAYidu]. See also faAvuwrN.
maAYidapN: ‡ A round piece of land or ground: (L, Ḳ:) likened to a table. (TA.)
mawaAYidu: see maAYidapN.
Also, Calamities: formed by transposition from maMwidu. (T, L.)
mumotaAdN Asking, or desiring, to give; asking or desiring, a gift. (Ḳ.) And Asked, or desired, to give; one of whom a gift is asked, or desired. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
mumotaAdN A man [asking, or desiring, and]
asked, or desired, to bring wheat or food. (Ṣ, L.)

1. maAra Oaholahu (T,* Ṣ, A, Mṣb,*) and EiyaAlahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yamiyru, (T, Ṣ, A, &c.,) inf. n. mayorN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, TaEaAm, [here meaning wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind, (see miyrapN,)] (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) to, or for, his family, (T,* Ṣ, A,) or his household: (M, Ḳ:) or he brought to them miyrap, i. e. TaEaAm: (As [accord. to whom, as I find in the TA, the aor. is yamuwru, but this I suppose to be a mistranscription,] T, Mgh, Mṣb:) or he gave them miyrap: (TA:) and OamaArahumo↓ signifies the same as maArahumo; (Ḳ;) and so AmtAr↓ lahumo: (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ:) or you say, humo yamotaAruwna liOanofusihimo they bring, or convey, or purvey, TEAm for themselves; (T;) and AmtAr↓ linafosihi, (A,) or AmtAr↓ Almiyrapa linafosihi, (Mgh, Mṣb,) he brought, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or conveyed, or purveyed, (A,) TEAm for himself. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.) See miyrapN.
4: see 1.
8: see 1.
mayorN: see miyrapN.

miyrapN: i. q. TaEaAmN [here meaning Wheat, or other corn, and food, victuals, or provision, of any kind,] (T, Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) which a man brings, or conveys or purveys (yamotaAruhu) [to be laid up in store for himself or his family or household, or for sale]; (Ṣ, TA;) and mayorN↓ signifies the same as miyrapN [in these senses, as will be seen from what follows], and is applied to victuals, or food, or aliment, syn. quwtN. (TA.) Ex. jaAlibu Almiyrapi, (Ḳ,) or Almayori↓, (M,) [The bringer, or conveyer, or purveyor, of wheat,, &c.] And OataAhu bimiyrapK He brought him TaEaAm. (T.) And jaAWuwA biQlomiyrapi [They brought, or conveyed, or purveyed, the wheat,, &c.] (A.) And maA Einodahu xayorN walaA mayorN↓ [He has not wealth, nor wheat,, &c.] (T, Ṣ, A.)

Also, (T,) The bringing, or conveying, or purveyance, of TaEaAm [here meaning as explained above] from another place (T, M, A, Ḳ,) [for one's self or family or household, (see 1,) or] for sale: (T:) pl. miyarN. (M, arts. dfO and Syf;, &c.) The first miyrap is the riboEiy-ap (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is the myrp in the beginning of [the season called] the XitaMC [or winter, i. e., in the latter part of December or in January, during the season of rains called Alr-abiyE, about which time, the species of millet called curap, which, as Niebuhr mentions, (Descr. de l'Arabie, p. 135, note,) is called in El-Yemen TaEaAm, is gathered in]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. rbE:) the second, the Sayofiy-ap, (M, arts, dfO and Syf,) also called the SaAYifap, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, art. Syf,) which is the myrp in [the season called] the Sayof [or spring], (Ṣ, M, art. Syf,) in the first part of the Sayof [i. e., in the latter part of March, about which time, wheat, and a second crop of millet (curap), and barley, are gathered in]: (M, art. Syf:) the third, the dafaYiy-ap, (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is [also] in the first part of [the season called] the Sayof [or spring, and consequently immediately after the Sayofiy-ap, commencing in the season of the dafaYiI- rains, and app. continuing during part of April, when the same grains are gathered in; or by the Sayof in this instance may be meant summer, but the more proper meaning is spring, and the term dafaYiy-apN seems already to point to the season of the dafaYiI- rains]: (M, art. dfO:) and the fourth, the ramaDiy-ap, (M, arts. dfO and Syf,) which is the myrp coming when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun, about July, when the month of ramaDaAn began at the period when the calendar by the months was fixed by Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, about two centuries before the Hijreh, and at which season of the year a third crop of curap is gathered in; for in some parts of Arabia they have three crops of this grain in the year; the second and third being sown immediately after, or produced by the grain which is let fall in cutting, the first and second]. (M, art. dfO.)
may-aArN: see maAYirN.

maAYirN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and may-aArN↓ (M, Ḳ) One who brings, or conveys, or purveys, miyrap, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or mayor: (M, L:) pl. of the former, muy-aArN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and may-aArapN, like raj-aAlapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say naHonu nanotaZiru muy-aAranaA, and may-aAratanaA, [We are expecting our bringers, or conveyers, or purveyors, of wheat,, &c.] (Ṣ.) The pl. may-aArapN is applied to A company of men who go together from the desert to the towns or villages to bring miyrap. (TA.) It is said in a trad. AlHamuwlapu AlmaAYirapu lahumo lAagiyapN, meaning, The camels that carry miyrap for them for sale and the like are exempt from the eleëmosynary taxation, because they are working beasts. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. maAzahu, aor. yamiyzuhu, inf. n. mayozN; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and my-zhu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tamoyiyzN; (Ṣ;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) He put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) from another thing, or other things; (Mṣb;) as also AmAzhu↓: (Ḳ:) [or the second, rather, he did so much, or greatly, or widely; like zay-alahu.] You say, maAzahu minohu, and my-zhu↓. (A.) Ex. maAza AlOacaI mina AlT-ar-iyq He put aside, or removed, what was hurtful from the road. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [viii. 38,] liyamiyza Qll-ehu Alxabiyva mina AlT-ay-ibi [That God may separate, or sever, the evil from the good]. (Mṣb.) [It seems also, from what is said in the A, that maAyazotu bayonahumaA signifies I separated them two: besides having another signification, which see below.] You say also maAza AlX-aIoCa, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) meaning, He separated one part of the thing from another; faSala baEoDahu mino baEoDK, (M, TA,) or Eano baEoDK: (as in a copy of the A:) expl. in the Ḳ as signifying faD-ala baEoDahu EalaI baEoDK [he judged, or made, part of the thing to excel, or to have excelled, another]; but the explanation in the M is the right. (TA.) And my-z↓ AlOaXoyaMCa He separated the things after knowledge of them. (Mṣb.)

[Hence, He distinguished it, or discriminated it, or discerned it. And maAza bayona AlOaXoyaMCi, and may-aza↓ bayonahaA, He distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between the things. This is what is meant by its being said,] Almayozu also signifies Alt-amoyiyzu bayona AlOaXoyaMCi. (TA.) You say also, maAyazotu↓ bayonahumaA [I distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned, between them two]. (A.) From my-z AlAXyMC, meaning as explained above, is [also], app., derived the phrase sin-u Alt-amoyiyzi, used by the doctors of practical law, as signifying, [The age of discrimination;] the age at which one knows what things are beneficial to him and what are hurtful to him: or, accord. to some, Alt-amoyiyz is a faculty in the brain whereby meanings are elicited. (Mṣb.)
maAza [is also intrans., and signifies] He (a man) removed from one place to another. (IAạr, Ḳ.) See also 8.

entry.sense: 2: see maAzahu, throughout.
3: see maAzahu, in two places.
4: see maAzahu, first signification.
5: see 8, throughout.
You say also, fulaAnN yakaAdu yatamay-azu mina AlgayoZi Such a one almost bursts asunder with wrath, or rage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) The like is said in the Ḳur, lxvii. 8, tropically, of hell. (A, TA.)
6: see 8, throughout.
7: see 8, throughout.

8. AmtAz, and tmy-z↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AnmAz↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and Uim-aAza↓, (Lḥ, TA,) [the last being a variation of that immediately preceding,]
and AstmAz↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; or removed; or separated; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) from another thing, or other things: (Mṣb:) and the last, AstmAz↓, he went, or withdrew, aside, or to a distance, (Ḳ, TA,) Eani AlX-aIoCi from the thing. (TA.) All these forms are syn.; but in the phrase mizotuhu falamo yam-azo [as though signifying I put it, or set it, apart,, &c., but it did not remain so] Lḥ allows the verbs to be only in these two forms: (TA:) [though AnmAz↓ is used in other cases; for] you say AnmAz↓ Eano muSal-aAhu He shifted from his place of prayer; or quitted it for another. (TA.) [See also 1, last signification.] You say also, AmtAr Alqawomu, meaning, tmy-z↓ baEoDuhumo mino baEoDK [The people were, or became, put, or set, apart,, &c., one from another]: (Ṣ, TA:) and, as also tmy-zwA↓, they became on one side: or they became alone, or separate: and the former, they withdrew, in a company or troop, aside; as also AstmAzwA↓: (TA:) and [in like manner] tmAyzwA↓ they became separated: (A:) and they formed themselves into separate companies, or troops, and went away, one from another. (TA. [Alt-amaAyuzu being there said to signify Alt-aHaz-ubu waAlt-anaAfuru.])

[AmtAz, and the other forms mentioned above, in the first sentence of the paragraph, as syn. with it, also signify It was, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, or discerned: in which sense, tmy-z↓ is the most common. You say also, tmy-z↓ fulaAnN biQlokarami Such a one was, or became, distinguished by generosity. And tamaAyazati↓ AlOaXoyaMCu and tumay-azat↓ The things were, or became, distinguished, or discriminated, one from another; or distinct.]
10: see 8, throughout.
mayozN inf. n. of 1, q. v.
Also, High or elevated rank or condition or state [by which one is distinguished from others]. (TA.)
miyzapN [The act of putting, or setting, apart, away, or aside; of removing, or separating]: a subst. from maAzahu. (TA.)
[Discrimination, or discernment: and hence,] understanding. (TA.)
rajulN may-aAzN, and mumay-izN↓, [A man of much discrimination or discernment.] (A.)
mumay-izN [Distinguishing, or discriminating: and hence, a rational animal]. rajulN mumay-izN: see may-aAzN.

1. maAsa, aor. yamiysu, inf. n. mayosN and mayasaAnN, He walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or so walked with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ; excepting that in the A the fem. forms of the pret. and aor. are given;) as also tmy-s↓: (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ:) accord. to the Lth, mayosN signifies a kind of mayasaAn, [app. a mistranscription for mayalaAn, or inclining,] with, or in, the gait and motion above described, like that of the bride, and of the camel; for he sometimes does this in going along with his hawodaj [or litter which serves as a vehicle for women]. (TA.)
4. OamaAsato jisomahaA [She (a woman) made her body to incline from side to side in walking in the manner above described.] (M.)
5: see 1.

mayosN A kind of tree, (AḤn, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of great size, (A, Hn, M, Ḳ,) resembling in its growth and its leaves the [kind of willow called] garab: when young, it is white within; but when it grows old, it becomes black, like Mbunuws [or ebony], and so thick that wide tables are made of it; (AḤn, M;) and camels' saddles (riHaAl) are made of it. (AḤn, Ṣ, M.)
Hence, A camel's saddle (raHolN), as being made of the kind of tree above described. (TA.)

Also, A species of grape-vine, that rises somewhat upon a trunk, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,*) not all of it spreading out into branches: (AḤn, M:) AḤn adds, its native place is the district of El-Jezeereh called Sarooa (saruwE), and it is related, of a person of knowledge, that he saw it at Et-Táïf: and hence the name of the raisins called mayosiI-↓: (TA:) [but ISd says, in continuation of AḤn's account of the former of the trees above mentioned, not of the latter,] an Arab of the desert informed me, that he had seen it at Et-Táïf, and hence, he said, the raisins called mayos [not mayosiI] are thus named: (M:) [and F says,] mayosN signifies a kind of raisins; as well as a species of grapevine, &c. (Ḳ.)
Also, [The pole of a plough;] the long piece of wood that is between the two bulls. (AḤn. M.)
mayosiI-N: see mayosN.
mayosaAnN: see may-aAsN.
mayosuwnN: see may-aAsN.
Also, A boy beautiful in stature and face. (Ḳ.)
mayuwsN: see may-aAsN.

may-aAsN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and mayosaAnN↓ (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ) and mayuwsN↓ and maAYisN↓ (Ḳ) One who walks with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait; or who so walks with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) [or the first and second and third, one who does so much, or often, or habitually: and the last, being a simple act. part. n., one so walking:] fem. of the first and second, with p {may-aAsapN and mayosaAnapN}: (A, TA:) and mayosuwn↓ signifies the same as may-aAsapN, in the sense explained above, applied to a woman, and is of one of the measures not mentioned by Sb, like zayotuwnN; or it is from masana, and therefore of the measure fayoEuwlN; but more probably from Almayosu. (M.)

Also, Almay-aAsu The lion that so walks; (Ḳ, TA;) an epithet applied to him because of his little regard for him whom he meets: (TA:) or the lion: (Ṣgh, TA:) and, (accord. to IDrd, TA,) the wolf; (Ḳ;) because he so walks. (TA.)
Also, guSonN may-aAsN An inclining, or a bending, branch. (M.)
maAYisN: see may-aAsN.

hom.sense: 1. maATa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yamiyTu, inf. n. mayoTN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and mayaTaAnN, (Ḳ,) He removed; retired, or went, to a distance; or became remote; (Aṣ, IAạr,* AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) Eanohu from him; (IAạr, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AstmAT↓; (TA;) and AmAT↓; (IAạr, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) but Aṣ disallows the last in this sense; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) it occurs, however, in a trad.: (TA:) also, he went away; (Ṣ, TA;) and so AmAT↓: (TA:) and it (a thing) went away. (TA.)
He, or it, inclined to one side; or declined; i. q., maAda, and HaAda. (TA.)
Also, aor. as above, inf. n. mayoTN, He declined, or deviated, from the right course; or acted unjustly; (AZ, Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ;) fiI Hukomihi in his judgment. (AZ, Ks, Ṣ.)
[See also mayoTN, below: and see 3.]

Also, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mayoTN; (TA;) and AmAT↓, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UimaATapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or the latter only, accord. to Aṣ; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA;) He removed, put away, or put at a distance, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) him, or it; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb;) and maATa bihi signifies the same as AmAThu; (Mṣb;) and some say may-aTotu↓ bihi [if this be not a mistranscription for miTotu bh] in the sense of OamaTotuhu. (TA.) You say, OamaATa↓ AlOacaI Eani AlT-ariyqi, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. UimaATapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He removed, or put away, or put at a distance, what was hurtful from the road, or way; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) and [some say] maATahu, inf. n. mayoTN. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., OamiTo↓ Ean-aA yadaka Remove thou from us thy hand. (TA.) And maATa bihi and AmAThu↓ signify He took away him, or it; syn. cahaba bihi and Oacohabahu. (TA.)

mayoTN also signifies The act of repelling, impelling, pushing, or thrusting; (Ṣ;) and so miyaATN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
and both signify the act of chiding: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former being an inf. n. of which the verb is maATa, aor. yamiyTu: (Ḳ:) [the latter, app., an inf. n. of which the verb, namely mAyT, is unused; the like being said of hiyaATN, which we find coupled with miyaATN.] You say, Alqawomu fiI hiyaATK wamiyaATK↓ The people, or company of men, are engaged in making a clamour, and repelling, &c.: (Ṣ, in the present art. and in art. hyT:) or hyAT and myAT, respectively, signify the most vehement driving in coming to water, and the most vehement driving in returning from water; (Fr, Ḳ;) and maA zalonaA biAlhiyaATi waAlomiyaATi means we ceased not to be engaged in coming and going: (Fr, TA:) or advancing (Lḥ, TA) and retreating: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or labouring, or striving, or conflicting, one with another, to overcome, (Lth, TA,) and inclining [one towards another]: (Lth, Ḳ:) or collecting together, in a neuter sense, and mutual retiring to a distance: or collecting themselves together for peace or reconciliation, and dissolving themselves from a state of peace or reconciliation: or raising a clamour, or confused noise; and retiring to a distance: or saying No, by God, and Yes, by God. (TA.) [See art. hyT.] You say also, maA zaAla fiI hayoTK wamayoTK, meaning He ceased not to be engaged in crying out, or vociferating, or calling for aid or succour, and in evil, or mischief, and raising a clamour, or confused noise. (Ḳ in art. hyT.)

entry.sense: 2. may-aTotu bihi: see 1.
my-T bayonahumaA, inf. n. tamoyiyTN, He wavered between them two. (TA.)
3. miyaATN: see 1, throughout the greater part of the latter half of the paragraph.
bayonahumaA mumaAyaTapN and muhaAyaTapN and muEaAyaTapN and musaAyaTapN are said to signify Between them two is low, faint, or gentle, speaking. (TA in art. hyT.)
4: see 1, in five places.
6. tmAyTwA They removed, retired, went to a distance, or became remote, one from another; and their mutual state became bad, disordered, or disturbed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of thAyTwA. (Fr, Ṣ, in art. hyT.)
10: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: mayoTN: see 1.
It also signifies Inclination: so in the trad., lawo kaAna Eumaru miyzaAnFA maA kaAna fiyhi mayoTu XaEorapK [If ʼOmar were a balance, there would not be in it the inclination of a hair]. (TA.)
Also, A state of mixture, or confusion: mentioned only by IF. (TA.)

entry.sense: maAYiTN and haAYiTN are explained by IAạr as signifying Coming and going. (TA.)
